"Lo, Lord, thou know'st, I've not refrain'd
"From publishing thy Grace.
"I have not hid within my Heart,
"Nor from the World conceal'd,
"Thy Faithfulness, and saving Health:
"But Grace, and Truth reveal'd.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Those tender Mercies I proclaim,
With hold not, Lord, from me;
But let thy Kindness, and thy Truth,
My constant Keepers be.
Numberless Evils me surround,
My Sins have seiz'd me fast;
They blind me, they exceed my Hairs,
Therefore my Heart's lay'd wast.
Be pleas'd, O Lord, in this Distress,
To come, and set me free;
O gracious God, make no Delays,
But hast to succour me.
Shame, and Confusion, be their Lot,
Who at my Ruin aim;
May they who wish, and seek, my Hurt,
Be driven back with Shame.
With Desolation them reward,
Who shamefully me treat;
That sport themselves, and Triumph make,
At mine afflicted State.
Let all that seek thy Face rejoice,
In Thee be satisfy'd;
Who thy Salvation love, still say,
"The Lord be magnify'd.
Tho' I am poor, distress'd, the Lord
Yet thinks on me alway:
For thou my Help, and Saviour, art,
My God, make no Delay.

div.head: PSALM XLI.
div.l: THrice bless'd the Man, whose thoughtful Mind
The Needy doth regard;
With Safety in the evil Day,
The Lord will him reward.
From Dangers he'll preserve his Life,
On Earth he bless'd shall be;
And none of all his spiteful Foes,
On him, their Will shall see.
Upon his Bed of Languishing,
The Lord will Strength supply;
In Sickness, kindly turn his Bed,
That he may easy ly.
"O Lord, be merciful to me,
(I thus myself expres • 'd)
"And h • al my wounded Soul, for I
"Against Thee have transgress'd▪
Mine Enemies, maliciously,
With Slanders me defame;
In Wrath, they say, "When shall he die,
"And perish shall his Name?
If e'er he comes no 〈◊〉 ,
His Speech is 〈◊〉 wi •• Fr •• d;
He gathers Evil to his Heart,
Then spreads it all •• road.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Who hate me whisper evil Things,
And do my Hurt devise.
"His Crimes have caught him fast, (say they)
"He's fall'n, no more to rise.
Yea, my familiar Friend, from whom
I nothing could conceal;
Who ate my Bread, yet basely has
Against me lift his Heel.
But thou, O Lord, be merciful,
To me, I humbly pray;
And raise me up, that I their Crimes,
With Justice, may repay.
That me thou favour'st, as thou said'st,
By this I surely know;
Because to triumph over me,
Thou suffer'st not my Foe.
For, as for me, thou dost uphold
〈◊〉 in mine Innocence;
〈…〉 me before thy Face,
〈◊〉 my Defence.
The Lord, the God of Isr'el's House,
Be bless'd by Sons of Men,
From Age to Age, till Time's no more.
Amen! O Lord, Amen!

div.head: PSALM XLII. SECOND BOOK.
div.l: AS pants the chased, thirsty, Hart,
After the cooling Brook;
So pants my Soul for Thee, O God,
For Thee I longing look.
My Soul for God, the living God,
Thirsts, while I'm exil'd here;
When shall I come, and in thy Courts,
Before my God appear?
My mourning Tears, by Day, and Night,
Have been my constant Food;
Whil •• with continual Insult, they
Have cry'd, "Where is thy God?
My Soul I pour out, when I think,
How to thy House I went,
With Multitudes; in Joy, and Praise,
Thy sacred Day we spent.
Why so dejected, O my Soul?
Why art thou restless grown?
Trust God; I yet shall sing his Praise,
For his Salvation shown.
Tho' O my God, my Soul's cast down;
Remember Thee I will,
From Iordan's Banks, and Hermon's Mount▪
And Misar's lowly Hill.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l:
Deep calls to Deep; thy Thunde •
〈◊〉
And pour'd the Waters down;
So o'er me have, with Force, and 〈◊〉
Thy Waves and Billows gone.
Thy Loving-kindness ye • , O Lord,
Shall brighten up the Day▪
Each Night I'll Anthems sing 〈◊〉 to Thee,
God of my Life, I'll pray.
I'll humbly say to God, my Rock,
"Why do'st forget me so?
"Why go I mourning, for the great
"Oppression of the Fee?
It pierc'd my Bones, as with a Sword,
To hear my Foes upbraid;
While daily they with impious Scoffs,
"Where is thy God? have said.
Why troubled? why cast down? my Soul!
Trust God: Thou yet shall sing
Loud Songs to him, who is thy God,
And Health's unfailing Spring.

div.head: PSALM XLIII.
div.l: JUdge me, O Lord, who only can
My Cause from cruel Men, defend;
From the deceitful, unjust Man,
O do thou me Deliv'rance send.
On Thee, O God, my Strength relies;
Why do'st thou cast me far away?
Oppress'd by cruel Enemies,
Why go I mourning, all the Day?
O, let thy Light, and Truth, appear;
Conduct my Steps, and be my Guide,
Unto thy holy Hill, and where
Thou, in thy Glory, do'st reside.
Then to thine Altars I'll repair,
〈◊〉 God, my most exceeding Joy;
〈◊〉 Thee, O God, my God, I'll there,
〈◊〉 Songs of Praise, my Harp employ.
Why so cast down, my Soul, and why
So restless, in thy frail Abode?
Trust God, for praise him yet shall I,
Who's my Deliv'rer, and my God.

div.head: PSALM XLIV.
div.l: O Lord, our Ears have often heard,
Our Fathers have us told
Thy mighty Works, wrought in their Days,
And in the Times of old.
How thou did'st punish, and eject,
With thine avenging Hand,
The heathen Nations; and did'st place
Thy People in their Land.
For they, Possession of the Land,
Gain'd not, by their own Sword,
Neither could their own Arm them save;
But thy Right-hand, O Lord,
Thine Arm, and Presence, with their Hosts,
And thy peculiar Grace.
Thou art my King; O God, command
Safety for Iacob's Race.
Then, in thy Strength, we'll still go on,
To push down all our Foes;
And, thro' thy Name, tread under Foot,
Such as shall us oppose.
For I'll not trust my Bow, nor Sword,
The Victory to gain.
But thou hast sav'd us from our Foes,
And made their Hopes in vain.
Therefore, in Thee, we make our Boast,
And glory all Day long;
Forever will we praise thy Name,
In our triumphant Song.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: But, now, thou hast rejected us,
With Shame, hast cast us down;
Our Armies thou no more dost lead,
Nor us with Vict'ry crown.
Therefore, before our Enemies,
Which spoil us, we have fled.
Thou, some, hast giv'n, as Sheep for Meat,
And others captive led.
Thy People thou hast sold for nought;
Nor art the richer found.
We're to our Neighbours a Reproach;
A Scorn to all around.
Thou us among the Heathen, hast,
A taunting Proverb, made;
By foolish People we're contemn'd,
They at us shake the Head.
Therefore, from Morn, to Night, our Eyes
See nothing but Disgrace;
And, cover'd with confounding Shame,
I'm forc'd to hide my Face.
Because I daily hear the Voice
Of our insulting Foe;
Who us reproach, and Thee blaspheme,
And all their Malice show.

div.head: Third PART.
div.l: Yet, we have not forgotten Thee;
Nor false in Cov'nant prov'd.
Our Heart's not turned back, nor St • ps,
From thy just Ways, remov'd.
Tho' thou hast sorely broken us,
Where cruel Dragons roar;
And with the gastly Shades of Death,
Thy People cover'd o'er.
Had we, our God's great Name, forgot,
Or to strange Gods bow'd down;
Would'st thou not this have searched out?
To Thee 〈◊〉 Hearts are known.
Yea, we're as Sheep for Slaughter mark'd;
For thy Sake, kill'd all Day.
Awake, why sleep'st thou, Lord, arise;
And cast us not away.
O wherefore do'st thou hide thy Face,
Unmindful of our Thrall?
Our Soul is bow'd to Dust, on Earth
Our Bodies prostrate fall.
Arise, and for our Help appear,
The heathen. Powers shake▪
Redeem us from our Enemies Hand,
For thy great Mercy's Sake.

div.head: PSALM XLV.
div.l: SUblimer Thoughts inspire my Breast;
My Tongue, in softest Notes, to sing,
Runs like a ready Writer's Pen,
A Poem sacred to the King.
There's none of all the Sons of Men
Can with thy matchless Form compare;
All Grace into thy Li • is pour'd,
Thee ever bless'd, doth God declare.
Gird then, O thou victorious Prince,
Thy conqu'ring Sword upon thy Thigh;
Appear, in all thy glorious State,
Adorn'd with royal Majesty.
In all thy Pomp, ride prosp'rous on,
The Truth, Meekness, and Righteousness,
Strongly assert; and thy Right-hand
Shall teach Thee Wonders to express.
Thy pointed Arrows wing their Way.
And peirce the stubborn Hearts of those
That set themselves against the King;
They fall, subdu'd, who were thy Foes.
Thy Throne, O God, thro' ev'ry Age,
Forever unremov'd shall stand;
Thy righteous Laws, and righteous Works,
Confirm the Scepter in thy Hand.
Thou Justice lov'st, and hatest Sin;
God, therefore, thine own God, hath shed,
Above what all thy Fellows claim,
The Oyl of Gladness on thy Head.
Myrrh, Aloes, and Cassia,
Their Perfumes to thy Robes impart,
As thou from th' Iv'ry Palace cam'st;
Whose fragrant Smell rejoice thy Heart.
The Queen, in well-wrought Ophir's Gold,
Fair Bride, is plac'd at thy Right-hand;
Kings Daughters, in her splendid Train,
As Maids of Honour, waiting stand.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: O Daughter hearken, and attend,
And to my Words encline thine Ear;
Thy native Land, and Friends, forget,
Thy Father's House, and Kindred dear.
So shall the King, with thy fresh Charms,
But have his Love enflam'd the more;
For he is now thy Head, thy Lord,
Him therefore worship, and adore.
The Tyrian Daughters shall approach,
And lay their Off'rings at thy Feet;
The wealthy Nations, with their Gifts;
Thy Royal Favour shall entreat.
The King's fair Daughter's glorious,
In all Accomplishments Divine;
Her Garments wrought with Phrygian Skill,
With purest Gold, illustrious shine.
Thus, to the King, in nuptial Robes,
By th' artful Needle curious wrought,
With Fellow-Virgins foll'wing her,
She shall, in royal Pomp, be brought.
Thro' shouting Crowds, and Peals of Joy,
In State moves on the glitt'ring Train,
Till the King's Palace them receive;
And nought but endless Joys remain.
From thee, a num'rous royal Race,
Shall, in thy Fathers Stead, descend;
Whose Fame, as mighty Princes, shall
Thro' universal Earth extend.
This Song shall spread thy great Renown,
Thro' ev'ry Age, O glorious King;
And Nations shall, while Time does last,
In Consort joyn, thy Paise to sing.

div.head: PSALM XLV. 2d Meetre.
div.l: MY Breast is inspir'd
With Thoughts more sublime;
My Tongue, in soft Notes,
Is ready to sing;
No Pen of swift Writer
Can with it keep Time;
A Poem most sacred
To Israel's great King.
Among all the Sons
Of Men, there is none
That can with thy Form,
So matchless, compare;
All heavenly Grace, in
Thy Lips, is pour'd down;
Thy God Thee forever
Doth blessed declare.
Thy Sword, on thy Thigh,
Gird, O mighty Prince;
With Glory adorn'd,
And Majesty crown'd.
Of Truth, Peace, and Justice,
Ride on the Defence;
Thy Right-hand shall teach Thee
Thy Foes to confound.
Thy sharp Arrows pierce
Their Hearts, with great Pain,
They fall at thy Feet.
Thy Throne, O God ever
Secure shall remain;
Thy Kingdom's just Laws are
Thy Scepter of State.
Thou Wickedness hat'st,
But Justice dost love;
God, therefore, thy God,
Anointed hath Thee,
With rich Oyl of Gladness,
In Measure above
All Those that esteemed
Thy Fellows may be.
Thy Garments perfum'd,
Their Fragrance out send,
From th' Iv'ry Palace,
With which they are glad.
For Maidens of Honour,
Kings Daughters attend
The Queen, at thy Right-hand,
In Ophir's Gold clad.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: O Daughter, attend,
And hear thou my Word;
Thy Kindred, and Land,
Forget thou must quite,
Him rev'rence, and worship,
Who now is thy Lord;
So the King in thy Beauty,
Shall greatly delight.
The Daughters of Tyre,
Their Presents shall bring
The Rich, with their Gifts,
Thy Favour entreat.
Within thou'rt all glorious,
Who sprang from a King;
Thy Garments embroider'd
With Gold, are mo •• neat.
She's led to the King,
In Needle Work Robes;
With Virgins, her Mates,
That on her attend.
They move on thro' Shoutings,
That ring thro' the Globes;
And enter the Palace,
With Joys that ne'er end.
In thy Fathers Stead,
From Thee, there shall spring
A Race, thro' the Earth,
Great Princes in Fame.
Thy Name, in this Form,
All Ages shall sing;
And Nations, forever,
Thy Praises proclaim.

div.head: PSALM XLVI.
div.l: GOD is our Refuge, where we're safe,
Our Strength by whom we stand;
He is a very present Help,
When Troubles are at Hand.
Therefore, we will not be afraid,
Tho' th' Earth should be displac'd;
Tho' Mountains, torn from their deep Roots,
Were in the Mid-Sea cast.
Should Storms ferment, and rouse the Deep,
And make the Waters roar;
And the swol'n Billows Mountains shake,
With Dashings on the Shore.
A River's gentle Streams makes glad
The City of our God;
There the Most-High, his sacred Tent,
Has fix'd, for his Abode.
God, in the Midst of her presides,
She unremov'd is stay'd;
From early Dawn of fittest Time,
God will afford her Aid.
The Heathen rag'd, Kingdoms were mov'd,
In Tumults were envolv'd;
But God gave forth his pow'rfull Word,
And all the Earth dissolv'd.
The Lord of Hosts is on our Side,
And will our Cause defend;
The mighty God of Iacob is
Our Refuge, and our Friend.
Come, see what wondrous Works, the Lord,
For us, hath newly wrought!
What dreadful Desolations, he,
Upon the Earth, hath brought!
He maketh Wars to cease, our Foes,
No more, our Hurt conspire;
He breaks the Bow, and Spear, and burns
The Chariot in the Fire.
Be still, and know that I am God;
I will exalt my Name,
In heathen Lands, and thro' the Earth,
Extoll'd shall be my Fame.
The Lord of Hosts is on our Side,
He will our Cause defend;
The mighty God of Iacob is
Our Refuge, and our Friend.

div.head: PSALM XLVI. 2d. Meetre.
div.l: OUR Refuge is in God,
In him our Strength is found;
He is a very present Help,
When Dangers us surround.
No Fears shall us dismay,
Tho' th' Earth's convuls'd, and torn;
Tho' Mountains, rent from their fix'd Roots,
Were to the Mid-Sea torn.
Should Storms enrage the Deep,
And make the Waters roar;
Should swelling Billows Mountains shake,
That border on the Shore:
A River's gentle Streams,
Are to God's City sent;
Which glads the Place, where the Most-High
Has fix'd his sacred Tent.
The Lord, in Zion, dwells,
She shall unmov'd abide;
In fittest Season, God, for her,
Will speedy Help provide.
The heathen Nations rag'd,
Kingdoms, in Wrath, combine;
But God, in hot Resentments, spake,
And melted their Design.
Iehovah, with his Hosts,
Engages on our Side;
Our Refuge is in Iacob's God,
In whom we safe abide.
Come, see the wondrous Works,
Which God, for us hath wrought!
What fearful Desolations, he,
Upon the Earth, hath brought!
Thro'out the jarring World,
Wars into Peace he turns;
He breaks the Bow, and cuts the Spear,
In Fire the Chariot burns.
Be still, and know I'm God;
I will exalt my Name,
In heathen Lands, and thro' the Earth,
I'll be extoll'd in Fame.
Iehovah, with his Hosts,
•• gages on our Side;
And Iacob's God our Refuge is,
In whom we safe abide.

div.head: PSALM XLVII.
div.l: CLap Hands, all People, shout to God;
With Voice of Triumph to him sing.
For God, most high, is terrible;
O'er all the Earth, he's a great King.
He makes the People to submit;
And Nations at our Feet couch down.
Our Heritage, for us, he chose;
His loved Iacob's glorious Crown.
God is ascended with a Shout;
Iehovah with the Trumpet's Layes.
Sing Praises to our God, Praise sing;
Sing Praises to our King, sing Praise.
For God, of all the Earth, is King;
Your deepest Skill in Praise be shown.
God reigneth over heathen Lands;
God sits upon his holy Throne.
Princes of Nations freely join,
To serve the God of Abraham;
For Shields of th' Earth to God belong,
Exalted greatly is his Name.

div.head: PSALM. XLVIII.
div.l: GREAT is the Lord, immensely great;
Greatly let them his Praise confess,
In City of our God who dwell,
That Mountain of his Holiness.
Mount Zion, Joy of all the Earth,
Most beautifully scituate;
There the great King, on her North Side,
His City built in royal State.
God in her Palaces is known
To be a Refuge strong, and high.
For, lo! when Kings against her came,
They only pass'd together by.
They came, they saw, they were amaz'd;
With Terror fill'd, confus'dly fled.
As Women in their Trav'ling Hours,
There were they seiz'd with Pain and Dread.
So the fierce boist'rous eastern Winds,
The Mid-land Sea to Fury wrought;
And the proud Fleets, from Tarshish Coast,
Were into sudden Ruin brought.
In City of the Lord of Host,
We've seen, what us our Fathers told;
God, his lov'd City, still preserves,
And will, thro' future Times uphold.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Therefore, in ev'ry new Distress,
We, to thy Temple, will repair;
Think on thy wondrous Grace, O God,
And wait for our Deliv'rance there.
O God, thy Praise, thro' all the Earth,
Extends, far as thy Name is known;
Thy Right-hand's full of Righteousness,
As thou hast said, so thou hast done.
O let Mount Zion shout for Joy,
And Iudah's Daughters loud repeat,
In chearful Songs, thy Judgments, L •• d▪
Which our Deliv'ranc • did compleat.
Thro' Zion walk, go round her Walls,
Her lofty Towers number well;
Her Forts, and Palaces observe,
And to your Sons this Wonder tell.
This God, who our Salvation wrought,
Thro' ev'ry Age, will be our God;
He'll guide us thro' the Vale of Death,
To Realms where none but Saints have trod.

div.head: PSALM XLVIII. 2d Meetre.
div.l: GReat is the Lord, supreamly great,
And greatly to be prais'd;
In Zion, in that holy Mount,
Let high his Fame be rais'd.
Mount Zion, Joy of all the 〈◊〉 ,
Th' imperial Seat of the great King,
On her North Quarter lies.
God, in her Palaces is known,
To be a Refuge high.
Confed'rate Kings against her came,
But hastily pass'd by.
For when they saw, they were amaz'd
And in Confusion fled.
Sudden, as Women with their Pains,
There, were they seiz'd with Dread.
So the tempestuous Eastern Winds,
When thou the Word do'st speak,
Rouse up the Mid-land Seas to Rage,
And Ships of Tarshish break.
In City of the Lord of Host,
We've seen, what we had heard;
God, his lov'd City, still preserves,
And is her constant Guard.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Therefore we, in thy Temple, bow,
Whenever we're afraid;
Think on thy former Acts of Grace,
And silent wait thine Aid.
Thy Praise, O God, thro' Earth extends,
Far as thy Name is known;
Thy Right-hand's full of Righteousness,
Thou faithfully hast done.
Zion, and Iudah's Towns, rejoice,
Because thy Works are true.
Thro' Zion walk, go round her Walls,
And all her Towers view;
Mark well her Forts, and Palaces;
Nor from your Sons it hide.
This God, forever, is our God;
To Death will be our Guide.

div.head: PSALM XLIX.
div.l: HEar this, all People, and give Ear,
All ye that dwell on Earth;
You're all concern'd, both high, and low,
Of base, or noble Birth.
My Mouth shall speak of weighty Things,
Which Wisdom will impart;
Of sacred Understanding are
The Musings of my Heart.
To search out secret Parables,
I will incline mine Ear:
And with soft Touches of my Harp,
Mysterious Truths declare.
Wherefore should I, in evil Days,
Be overwhelm'd with Fears;
When the Transgressions of my Heels
Encompass me with Snares?
There's none of those who trust in Wealth▪
And in their Riches boast,
Their Brother can redeem; or give
To God sufficient Cost;
(Life's of too great a Price for Wealth,
No Sum can equal be;)
That he should still forever live,
And no Corruption see.
'Tis daily seen, that Wise, and Fools,
Alike go to the Grave;
And all their Wealth, tho' ne'er so loth,
To their Successors leave.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Man vainly thinks, his House shall stand,
Forever fix'd in Fame;
And therefore calls his dwelling Place,
And Lands, by his own Name.
But Man, in Honour, soon decays;
And, like the Beasts, he dies.
Their Folly's great; and yet their Sons
Still think their Sayings wise.
Like Sheep, they're crowded in the Grave,
Death's Prey; o'er them the Just
Reign in the Morn; their Strength's consum'd,
Whose Dwelling's in the Dust.
But God will, in that glorious Day,
Me from the Grave retrieve;
Redeem me from the Pow'r of Death,
And to himself receive.
Their House in Glory rise.
Death strips them of their former Pomp,
Their Glory, with them, dies.
Tho' while he liv'd, he bless'd himself;
And Men his Skill shall praise.
He shall go to his Father's Race;
And ne'er see happy Days.
Man, that to Honour is advanc'd,
And is not truly wise:
As void of Understanding lives,
So like a Beast he dies.

div.head: PSALM L.
div.l: THE mighty God, Iehovah spake,
To the whole Earth did call;
From early'st Rising of the Sun,
Unto it's latest Fall.
From Zion, famous in Renown,
Whose Beauty is compleat;
The mighty God hath clearly shin'd,
In all his royal State.
Silent no more; our God shall come,
Before him Flames devour;
And Troops of raging Tempests, round
About him, fiercely pour.
Thro' Heav'n above, and Earth beneath,
His Summons he shall send;
That all his People, ev'ry where,
Before their Judge attend.
"Gather together, unto me,
"My Saints, (Iehovah said,)
"Those that, with me, a Cov'nant firm,
"By Sacrifice, have made.
The heav'nly Host, his Righteousness,
Shall clearly see, and own;
His spotless Justice shall appear;
For God is Judge alone.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: "Hear, O my People, and I'll speak;
"I'll swiftly testify
"Against Thee, O my Israel;
"God, ev'n thy God, am I.
"I'll not reprove thee with Neglects
"Of legal Sacrifice;
"Or Burnt Off'rings; the Smoke of these,
"Before me, daily rise.
"No Bullocks from thy Stall, or Goats
"From Fold, will I accept.
"The Forrest Beasts are mine, and Herds
"On Thousand Hills are kept.
"I know the Mountain Fowl; I claim
"The wild Beasts of the Fields.
"If hungry, need I beg? The World
"Is mine, and all it yields.
"Or eat the Flesh of Bulls, or drink
"The Blood of Goats, will I?
"Give Thanks to God, and daily pay
"Your Vows to the Most-high.
"In thy Distress, thy Heart to me,
"In Prayer, devoutly raise;
"Then I'll deliver from thy Fears,
"And thou my Name shall praise.

div.head: Third PART.
div.l: "But to the Wicked, God doth say,
"How dar'st thou to proclaim
"My Statutes? or, with thy vile Mouth,
"My sacred Cov'nant name?
"Seeing thou do'st Instruction hate;
"And cast my Word behind.
"When Thieves thou saw'st; thou did'st consent;
"And with Adult'rers join.
"Thy Mouth, in Slander, is employ'd;
"Thy Tongue doth Falshood frame.
"Thou'rt pleas'd thy Brother to reproach,
"Thy Mother's Son defame.
"This thou hast done; I silence kept;
"Thou did'st of me surmise,
"I'm like thyself; I'll thee reprove,
"And rank them in thine Eyes.
"Now then, consider this, ye Fools,
"Who God forgotten have;
"Lest I in Pieces should your tear,
"And there be none to save.
"The Man, that offers hearty Praise,
"Best glorifieth me;
"And him that ord'reth right his Ways,
"Shall God's Salvation see.

div.head: PSALM L. 2d Meetre.
div.l: THE mighty God, Iehovah spake,
Did thro' the Earth his Summons make,
From rising to the setting Sun.
From Zion, his peculiar Seat,
Whose Beauty's perfect and compleat,
God shines in glorious Renown.
Our God shall come, silent no more;
Devouring Fire shall march before,
And raging Tempests round him fly.
His solemn Judgment to attend,
Thro'out all Heav'n, and Earth, he'll send
His awful Summons, from on high.
"Let all my Saints assembled be,
"That Cov'nant have confirm'd with me,
"By Sacrifice; with Hopes t' at • one.
The heav'nly Hosts, who present are▪
His spotless Justice shall declare;
For God himself is Judge alone.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: "Attend my People, Isr'el hear;
"While I against thee Witness bear;
"I'm God, thy Cov'nant God am I.
"Of Sacrifice, and Burnt-Off'ring,
"I'll no Complaint against thee bring;
"These daily smoak before mine Eye.
"These Off'rings no Amends can make:
"No Bullock from thy Stall I'll take,
"Nor any He-Goat from thy Fold.
"The Beasts in Forrests more confin'd,
"And Herds on thousand Hills combin'd,
"They all belong to me of old.
I number all the Mountain-Fowl;
"Wild Beasts that in the Desart prowl,
"All subject stand my Face before.
"If I be pinch'd with Hunger cou'd,
"I need not ask of thee my Food;
"The World is mine, with all it's Store.
That I the Flesh of Bulls, do'st think,
Could eat? or Blood of Goats should drink?
Thy Heart in Thanks to God up raise;
Thy Vows unto the Highest pay.
Devoutly in thy Troubles pray;
I'll save; and thou my Name shalt praise.

div.head: Third PART.
div.l: The Wicked thus doth God impeach;
"What Right hast thou my Laws to teach?
"Or in thy Mouth my Cov'nant take?
"Tho' thou of sacred Things may'st prate;
"Yet my Instruction thou do'st hate,
"And cast my Word behind thy Back.
"When thou did'st see a Thief, thy Care
"Was to agree, and with him share;
"And with Adulterers did'st join.
"Thy Mouth thou gavest to Reproach,
"Thy Tongue Deceit, and Lies, did broach;
"And Mischief was thy chief Design.
"With Joy thou wound'st thy Brother's Name,
"Do'st thine own Mother's Son defame.
"This thou hast done; and did'st surmise,
While silent, I was like to thee;
"Now thou my sharp Reproof shalt see;
"I'll rank thy Sins before thine Eyes.
Mark this, ye who forgetful are
Of God; left I in Pieces tare,
And there to save shall none be found.
He honours me who offers Praise;
And he, who orders right his Ways,
With God's Salvation shall be crown'd.

div.head: PSALM LI.
div.l: O God, to me let Mercy flow,
For thou delight'st in Acts of Grace;
Thy many tender Mercies show,
And all my Trespasses erase.
Me throughly wash from all my Stains;
And from my Guilt me purify.
I own my Fault; my Sin remains,
With piercing Grief, before mine Eye.
I've sin'd against Thee, Thee alone,
And done this Evil in thy Sight;
Thy Sentence, Lord, is just, I own,
Thy heavy'st Judgments would be right.
I'm born defil'd, in ev'ry Part;
My Mother me conceiv'd in Sin.
Thou, Lord, desirest Truth of Heart;
O make me Wisdom know within.
With sprinkling Hysop purge my Soul,
Then shall I pure, and spotless, grow;
O wash away my Stains, most foul,
I then shall whiter be than Snow.
Let me, with Joy, hear thy kind Word;
So shall the Bones thou'st broken shout.
Hide from my Sins thy Face, O Lord;
And all my many Crimes blot out.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l:
Create, O God, in me clean 〈◊〉
▪
My Spirit • ight, within me, make.
Drive me not from thy Face apart;
Nor thy good Spirit from me take.
Salvation's Joy, to me, renew;
With thy free Spirit me sustain.
Transgressors then, thy Ways, I'll shew;
And they shall turn to God again.
Deliver me from Guilt of Blood,
O God, thou my Salvation's God;
My joyful Tongue shall then sing loud,
And spread thy gracious Acts abroad.
O Lord, my closed Lips inspire;
Then shall my Mouth thy Praises sing.
No Sacrifice, tho' burnt with Fire,
Could please; or else I would it bring.
A broken Spirit, in God's Sight,
Is the most pleasing Sacrifice;
An Heart that's broken, and contrite,
O God, thou never wilt despise.
Be Zion's Sons with Goodness fill'd,
In thy good Pleasure succour them;
Defend thy Church, and firmly build
The Walls of thy Ierusalem.
Then shalt thou, with right Sacrifice,
Be pleas'd, while Saints shall Thee invoke;
Then, from burnt Off'rings, Steams shall rise,
And Bullocks on thine Altars smoke.

div.head: PSALM LII.
div.l: WHerefore, O mighty Man, dost thou,
Thyself, in Mischief boast?
Uninterupted daily flows
God's Goodness, without Cost.
Thy Tongue, the Malice of thy Heart,
In Falshoods, spreads around;
Like a keen Ra • or, gives a deep,
And unexpected, Wound.
Thou lovest Evil more than Good,
Than right, more to speak wrong;
Devouring Words are thy Delight,
O thou deceitful Tongue.
Thee utterly shall God destroy,
And snatch thee from thy Place;
O'er throw thy House, and from the Earth.
Root thee, and all thy Race.
With Fear, the Righteous shall behold,
And thus, thy Fall, deride:
"Lo! this the Man! who God contemn'd,
"Nor on his Strength rely'd;
"But, in th' Abundance of his Wealth
"Himself secure he thought,
"And strengthen'd by his wicked Arts;
"Lo! how he's brought to nought!
But I shall to God's House return,
Fruitfull as th' Olive Tree;
For I have ever fix'd my Trust,
In God's Benignity.
I'll ever celebrate thy Praise,
For what thou did'st effect;
And patient wait thy promis'd Grace,
Which all thy Saints expect.

div.head: PSALM LIII.
div.l: FOOLS, in their Heart, say there's no God;
They so corrupt, and base, are grown;
They scatter loathsome Sin abroad,
Among them, that doth Good, there's none.
The Lord look'd down from Heav'n above,
On Sons of Men, with strict Survey▪
To see, if Reason they approve,
And seek the Lord, in his right Way.
But lo! they all were gone from God,
They wholly filthy were, and base;
Not one the Paths of Virtue trod,
Of all that vile degen'rate Race.
Are then those Fools so blindly led?
Do they so far from Reason stray?
That they my People eat as Bread,
And unto God no Homage pay?
When God dispers'd and broke their Strength,
That fearless Crew were then surpris'd
With horrid Fears; and sham'd at length;
For God their boasted Force despis'd.
Who'll Isr'el Help, from Zion, send?
When God shall back his Captives bring,
Then Iacob's Voice, in Shouts, ascend,
Glad Isr'el, loud, thy Praise, shall Sing.

div.head: PSALM LIV.
div.l: SAVE, me, O God, for thy Name's Sake;
Me by thy Pow'r defend,
Lord, hear my Pray'r; and let thine Ear,
Unto my Words, attend.
For Strangers, causeless, have combin'd,
They up against me rise;
Feirce Men thirst for my Life, who set
Not God before they Eyes.
The Lord's my Help, he'll head my Friends,
Who for my Life have stood;
My watchful Foes with Ill reward,
And all his Threats make good.
So will I Free-will Off'rings bring,
And to Thee sacrifice;
Thy Name I'll ever praise, O Lord;
'Tis pleasing in thine Eyes.
For he hath freed me from my Straits,
Which very great have been;
Mine Eyes, with Pleasure, thy Rebukes,
On all my Foes have seen.

div.head: PSALM LV.
div.l: GIVE Ear, O God, unto my Pray'r;
Nor hide from my Request.
Attend, and hear my mournful Cry;
I roar, I'm so distress'd.
My Foes reproach me, I'm oppress'd,
By a vile impious Crew;
Who load me with foul Crimes, in Wrath,
And Hatred, me pursue.
My Heart within me's greatly pain'd;
Death's Terrors seize me fast;
Trembling, and Fear, beset me round;
Horror is o'er me cast.
"Oh! had I Wings, like to a Dove,
(I said, while thus distrest,)
"Then would I fly from hence away
"And seek a Place of Rest:
"Far would I wander, and remain
"In some Desart alone;
"There swiftly 'scape, till furious Winds,
"And Tempests were o'er blown.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Confound, O Lord, their ill Designs,
Their plotting Tongues divide;
For Violence, and raging Strife,
I've in the City spy'd.
These, Day and Night, upon the Wall • ,
Compass the City round;
Mischief, and Sorrow, sprung from thence,
In Midst thereof abound.
There, Wickedness, in various Shapes,
An hearty Welcome meets;
There open Fraud, and practis'd Guile,
Depart not from her Streets.
Had a known Foe reproached me,
This I could bear with Ease▪
Should open Haters me insult,
I might have shunned these.
'Twas thou, perfidous Man, my Friend,
My Guide, mine Intimate.
Sweet Counsel took we, jointly went,
And in God's House we sat.

div.head: Third PART.
div.l: Death shall seize on them unawares,
And sink them quick to Hell;
For Wickedness doth in their Hearts,
And in their Houses, dwell.
But I will call on God; the Lord
Will for my Help appear.
At Ev'ning, Morn, and Noon, I'll pray,
And he my Voice will hear.
The Battle was against me aim'd,
But he hath set me free;
My Soul in Peace, and Safety, dwells,
For many join'd with me.
God, who abides of old, shall hear,
And smite them with his Rod;
Because they have no Changes felt,
Therefore they fear not God.
Against the Man at Peace with him,
His Hands he did extend,
In Wrath; and most profanely broke
His Cov'nant, with his Friend.
Smoother than Butter was his Speech▪
But War in's Heart was found;
His Words were softer than the Oyl,
Yet, like drawn Swords, they wound.
Thy Burden cast upon the Lord,
Who will sustain his own▪
He'll never suffer righteous Men▪
Tho' shook, to be o'er thrown.
God, to Destruction's Pit, shall bring
Men of Deceit, and Blood;
But I will trust in God.

div.head: PSALM LVI.
div.l: HAVE Pity, upon me, O God,
He daily striving for my Hurt,
Oppresses me with Pow'r.
My watchful Foes do, ev'ry Day,
To swallow me, devise
For they are many, O Most-high,
That up against me rise.
When I'm afraid, I'll trust in Thee.
In God I'll praise his Word;
Nor fear what Flesh can do to me,
For I trust in the Lord.
Each Day, they wrest my Words to speak,
And, my Destruction to contrive,
Their Thoughts are wholly bent.
They meet together, and consult,
And secretly debate;
They strictly all my Actions watch,
While for my Soul they wait.
Shall they, by all their Wickedness,
O God, in thy just Anger, cast,
This wicked People down.
Thou number'st all the wandring Steps,
From Place, to Place, I've took
Are not my Tears all safe preserv'd.
And entred in thy Book?
When'er I cry, my Foes shall flee,
I know; for God's mine Aid.
In God, the Lord, I'll praise his Word,
On which my Hopes are stay'd.
In God I trust; and will not fear
What Man can do to me.
Thy Vows are upon me, O God,
I'll render Praise to Thee.
Thou, who hast sav'd my Soul from Death,
My Feet from Falls defend;
That I may live, and all my Days
In thy bless'd Service spend.

div.head: PSALM LVII.
div.l: HAVE Mercy, Lord, Mercy I crave;
I cast my Soul on Thee;
Till these Calamity's are past,
To thy Wings Shade I flee.
To God, who over all presides,
I'll make my fervent Cry;
The God that well for me performs,
And will not me deny.
From Heav'n he'll send, and me protect,
Shame who would on me prey;
God will his Mercy, and his Truth,
On my Behalf display.
Fierce Lions, Men inflam'd with Rage,
My Soul doth dwell among;
Whose Teeth are Spears, and Arrows keen,
And as sharp Swords their Tongue.
Let thy great Name be high extoll'd,
Above the Heav'ns, O God;
And let thy Glory be display'd
Thro' all the Earth abroad.
They, for my Steps, had spread their Net,
My Soul almost dispair'd;
But they are fall'n into the Pit,
Which they for me prepar'd.
O God, my Heart's prepar'd, and fix'd,
I'll sing; and give Thee Praise.
Awake my Glory, Psalt'ry, Harp,
Myself I'll early raise.
Among the Tribes, and Nations, Lord,
Thy Praises sing will I.
Thy Mercy, Heav'ns high Arch, transcends,
Thy Truth, the starry Sky.
Be thou, above the Heav'nly Spheres,
Exalted high, O God;
And let thy Glory be display'd
Thro' all the Earth abroad.

div.head: PSALM LVIII.
div.l: DO ye speak Righteousness, indeed,
While ye confederate sit?
Or is, ye Sons of earthly Men,
Your Judgment just, and fit?
Yea, rather foul, malicious Deeds,
Your wicked Heart intends;
Thus sway'd, you openly weigh out
The Violence of your Hands.
Degen'rate Race! that, from the Womb,
Strangers to Virtue, rise;
As soon as born, they go astray,
And give themselves to Lies.
Their Words, like Serpent's Poison, wound;
Deaf Asps, they stop their Ear;
The Charmer's wisest Charms are vain,
They'l no Instruction hear.
O God, their Mouth, so us'd to Blood,
Of their sharp Teeth disarm;
Break the young Lyon's Teeth, O Lord,
Nor leave them Pow'r to harm.
Let them dissolve, as Mounts of Snow,
Away whose Waters soak;
May all his Arrows, when he brings
Them to his Bow, be broke.
As slimy Snails, which melt away,
So may they waste each one;
Like an untimely Birth, that dies,
And never sees the Sun.
Quicker than Thorns can seeth the Pot,
He'll seize on them alive;
In his hot Wrath away them chase,
And with a Whirlwind drive.
Such righteous Vengeance will excite,
The Triumphs of the Good;
Who, Victors o'er such wicked Men,
Shall wash their Feet in Blood.
Then Men shall say, "sure for the Just,
"There is a kind Reward;
"Sure, there's a God, who judgeth right,
"And doth the Earth regard.

div.head: PSALM LIX.
div.l: SAVE me, my God, from all my Foes;
Thy high Defence I crave,
From evil Workers set me free;
From bloody Men me save.
Lo! for my Soul they lye in wait,
And mighty Men combine
Against my Life; not for my Fault,
Lord, nor Offence of mine.
They run upon me unprovok'd,
And all their Force prepare;
See, Lord, my Danger, stir thyself,
And for mine Aid appear.
Wake, Lord of Hosts, thou Isr'el's God,
None of the Heathen spare;
No longer let thy Patience, with
Such bold Transgressors, bear.
When Ev'ning comes, they fresh return,
Their Rage admits no Change;
They bark, and snarle, and growl, like Dogs,
And round the City range.
Their Mouth impetously pours out
Words bitter, hard to bear;
Between their Lips are pointed Swords;
"For who (say they,) doth hear?
But thou, O Lord, shall laugh at them;
And all the Heathen scorn.
O thou my Strength, I'll on Thee wait;
For God's my Safety's Horn.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: The God of all my Mercy will,
To help me, interpose;
He shall, with Pleasure, let me see
His Justice on my Foes.
Lest we too soon forget thy Works,
Them slay not with one Blow;
But, Lord, our Shield, by thy great Pow' •
Disperse, and bring them low.
Because their Mouth, and Lips, abound
With grievous Sin; surprise,
And take them in their Pride, who speak
Such hideous Oaths, and Lies.
Consume, and waste them, in thy Wrath,
And all their Pow'r restrain;
That they may know, in Iacob, God,
And thro' the Earth doth reign.
At Ev'ning, then, let them, like Dogs,
Return, and meet, and howl;
And, tir'd with Ramblings, may they still
Around the City growl.
With Hunger, let them strole about,
To get their Wants supply'd;
And spend whole Nights in fruitless Search,
And not be satisfy'd.
But I▪ each Morn, will sing thy Pow'r,
And loud thy Grace confess;
Thou hast my Tow'r, and Refuge, been,
In Day of my Distress.
Therefore to Thee, O thou my Strength,
I'll never cease to sing;
For God is my Defence, the God
Whence all my Mercies spring.

div.head: PSALM LX.
div.l: THOU hast cast off, and scatter'd us,
O God, thou wast displeas'd;
Oh, turn thyself to us again,
And shew thyself appeas'd.
To tremble thou hast made our Earth,
With sore Divisions rent;
Oh, heal the Breaches thou hast made;
It shakes, to Ruin bent.
Thou hard, and grievous Things to bear,
Thy People did'st assign;
And of Astonishment has made
Us drink the deadly Wine.
But now, to them that fear thy Name,
A Banner thou hast rear'd;
And it in Triumph is display'd,
So hath thy Truth appear'd.
That thy Belov'd, as heretofore,
May still Deliv'rance have:
O hear the fervent Pray'rs we make,
And let thy Right-hand save.
God, in his Holiness, hath spoke,
My Joy it cannot fail;
I'll portion out fair Sichem's Soil,
And meet out Succoth's Vale.
Fam'd Gilead, and Manasah, both,
Already own my Cause;
The gallant Ephr'im's Tribe's my Strength,
And Iudah gives forth Laws.
Moab shall serve to wash my Feet,
O'er Edom I will tread;
The proud Philistian Lords shall stoop,
And to my Triumphs add.
But who shall their strong City take,
And bring to our Command?
Who shall to Vict'ry lead our Arms,
Thro' Edom's rocky Land?
Tho' thou, O God, hast cast us off,
Refus'd our Arms to bless;
Wilt thou not, now, our Armies head,
And crown them with Success?
From all our Troubles give us Help;
Man's Help is vain we own.
Thro' God we shall do valiant Acts;
'Tis he our Foes treads down.

div.head: PSALM LXI.
div.l: LORD, hearken to my Cry,
And to my Pray'r attend.
From th' Earth's remotest Parts, to Thee,
My Cry shall still ascend;
When sadly overwhelm'd,
My Heart does fainting lye:
Conduct me to the Rock of Strength,
That higher is than I.
My Shelter thou hast been,
From Foes my pow'rful Aid.
I'll ever in thy Courts abide,
And trust in thy Wing's Shade.
For thou, O God, hast heard;
My Vows before Thee came;
Thou hast appointed me the Lot
Of those that fear thy Name.
Thou to the King wilt add
Long Life, and happy Reign;
As many Generations still,
His future Years maintain.
He shall forever sit,
O God, be • ore thy Face,
Upon his Throne, secured by
United Truth, and Grace.
So to thy Name I'll sing,
My endless Songs of Praise;
And chearfully perform my Vows,
Thro' all my future Days.

div.head: PSALM LXII.
div.l: TRULY, my Soul doth wait on God,
Salvation comes from him alone.
My Rock, my Safety, high Abode,
He is, I shall not be o'er thrown.
How long, against a Man, will ye
Plot Mischief? as a bowing Wall,
Or a loose Fence, you all shall be;
And into sudden Ruin fall.
Their great Consult is, to suppress
My Dignity with lying Arts;
If e'er their Mouth is forc'd to bless,
Yet Cursing rages in their Hearts.
My Soul wait thou on God alone;
From him my Hopes have stedfast prov'd.
My Rock, and Safety, him I own;
My high Tow'r, I shall not be mov'd.
In God my Safety is secure,
My future Glory and Renown;
The Rock in whom my Strength is sure,
My Refuge is in God alone.
Ye People, in his Pow'r, and Grace,
At all Times your fix'd Trust repose;
Pour out your Hearts before his Face:
God is our Refuge from our Foes.
The vulgar are but vain, we know,
And great Men are Deceit, and Lies;
If both you in the Ballance throw,
Lighter than Vanity they rise.
Trust not in Methods of Deceit,
Or Violence; be not so vain;
If by just Means your Wealth grows great,
Set not your Heart on such low Gain.
Once spoken hath the God of Might,
Twice have I heard this Word aloud;
That boundless Pow'r by sov'rain Right,
Doth appertain alone to God.
Not only Pow'r but wondrous Grace,
Also, O Lord, belongs to Thee;
Therefore, to all the human Race,
Thou render'st, as their Works shall be.

div.head: PSALM LXIII.
div.l: O God thou art my Gracious God,
I'll early seek thy Face;
My Soul doth thirst, my Flesh doth long,
For thy refreshing Grace;
As in a dry, and thirsty Land,
Where Waters rare have been;
Thy Pow'r and Glory, to behold
As in thy Courts I've seen.
Because thy Love doth Life excell,
My Lips shall speak thy Praise.
I'll bless Thee, while I live; my Hands,
To Thee, adoring raise
Then shall my Soul 〈…〉
As with rich 〈…〉
My Mouth her joyful 〈◊〉 employ,
Thy Praises wi •• to spread.
Mean Time, while on my Bed I ly,
I will remember Thee;
My Thoughts, in Watches of the Night,
On Thee shall musing be.
Since thou hast been my Help, with Joy,
I'll to thy Courts resort.
My Soul pursues hard after Thee;
Thy Pow'r doth me support.
But those shall to th' Abyss go down,
That seek my Life to slay:
Their Carcasses, fall'n by the Sword,
Shall be the Foxes Prey.
Yet shall the King in God rejoice,
And all that by him sware,
Shall glory; but their Mouths be stop'd.
That full of lying are.

div.head: PSALM LXIV.
div.l: MY Voice, O God, in my Pray'r hear;
Preserve me from the Foes I fear.
From Plots of wicked Men me hide;
And Safety from their Rage provide.
Who whet their Tongues, like keenest Swords,
And cast their Darts, ev'n bitter Words.
To wound the Just they secret ly,
And, fearless, sudden Shafts let fly.
They strengthen one another's Heart,
To act the false, malicious Part;
Their private Snares to lay agree,
And vainly cry, "Who shall us see.
Unweary'd Pains, with Craft they spend,
To drive their wicked Plots an End;
Their inward Thoughts, which they pursue,
And Hearts, ly deeply hid from View.
But God his Vengeance shall let fly,
And wound them unexpectedly.
Upon themselves their Tongues shall prey;
And all that see them, flee away.
Then all around them, struck with Fear,
Shall this the Work of God declare;
For they shall wisely understand
The Operations of his Hand.
The Righteous then, shall, in the Lord,
Rejoice; and firmly trust his Word;
And all, whose Hearts are right with God,
Shall gloriously triumph aloud.

div.head: PSALM LXV.
div.l: THo' th' Earth sit silent, yet thy Praise,
O God, in Sion's heard;
There they perform, with chearful Lays,
The Vows they have prefer'd.
O thou, who do'st thy list'ning Ear
To our Request encline,
All Nations shall, to thee repair,
And in thy Praises join.
Prevailing Sins, an heavy Load,
Might flowing Mercy stay;
But thou our Crimes, O gracious God,
Shalt wholly purge away.
Bless'd Man! thy Choice; who near to Thee,
May in thy Courts reside;
With Goodness of thy Temple, we
Shall then be satisfy'd.
Thy Justice, Lord, in dreadful Styles,
Answers in our Defence;
Of distant Lands, and farthest Isles,
Thou art the Confidence.
The Mountains, by thy mighty 〈◊〉
Fix'd on their Basis stand.
The Seas, and People, cease to roar,
When still'd by thy Command.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Nations, in the remotest Land,
Revere thy Tokens Voice;
The op'ning Morn, at thy Command,
And closing Eve, rejoice.
The thirsty Earth, with fat'ning Rain,
From God's full Springs above,
Thou visitest; preparest Grain,
And mak'st it fruitfull prove.
Thou, on the Ridges, Rain do'st pour,
And on the Furrows bring;
It's soften'd with thy gentle Show'r,
Thy Blessing makes it spring.
The various Months thro'out the Year,
Thou do'st with Goodness crown;
Thy Paths, which in the Clouds appear,
Drop plenteous Fatness down.
They drop on Desert's until'd Ground,
And cloath them in their Pride;
The little Hills are girt around,
With Joy on ev'ry Side.
The Pastures bleating Flocks adorn,
With lowing Herds they ring;
The Vales are cover'd o'er with Corn,
They shout for Joy, and sing.

div.head: PSALM LXVI.
div.l: LET all the Earth, in Shouts, to God,
Their chearful Voices raise;
Sing forth the Honour of his Name,
And glorious make his Praise.
Say unto God, "In thy great Works,
"How terrible art thou?
"Thy Foes, by thine almighty Pow'r,
"To thee, are forc'd to bow.
All Earth shall worship Thee, and sing
The Glories of thy Name.
Come, see the Works of God, his Deeds
Struck Terror where they came.
He turn'd the Sea into dry Land,
Our Fathers pass'd the Flood,
Secure on Foot; there we began
To triumph in our God.
He ever ruleth by his Pow'r,
His Eyes the Nations spy;
Then let not mortal Rebels dare,
Themselves to magnify.
O all ye People, bless our God;
And loudly shout his Praise.
'Tis he who holds our Soul in Life,
And stablisheth our Ways.
For thou, O God, hast proved us;
As Fire the Ore refines.
Thou brought'st us into Straits; and laid
Affliction on our Loins.
Thou mad'st Men o'er our Heads to ride,
With Insult, and Disgrace:
Thou us, thro' Fire and Water, led'st
Safe to a wealthy Place.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: I'll to thy House, with Off'rings, go;
And Thee my Vows will pay:
Which my Lips utter'd, and Mouth spoke,
When Troubles on me lay.
I'll offer Thee burnt Sacrifice,
The very best that are;
The Fat of Rams, the choicest Bulls,
And Goats, I will prepare.
Come, hear, all ye that fear the Lord;
To you I will make known,
The many wondrous Acts of Grace,
The Lord, for me hath done.
My Mouth, to him that rules above,
Pour'd out it's fervent Cry;
He heard; and then my joyful Tongue
Extol'd his Name on high.
God would not hear; if in my Heart,
I any Sin regard:
But, verily, he bow'd his Ear,
And all my Pray'r hath heard.
O blessed be the sov'reign Lord,
Who hath not turn'd his Face
From my Request; nor yet with-held,
From me his wondrous Grace.

div.head: PSALM LXVII.
div.l: BLess, Lord, thine Heritage,
In thine abundant Grace;
Let, on thy Servants, ever shine,
The Brightness of thy Face.
That so thy righteous Ways
May, thro' the Earth, be known;
And all the Nations of the World
May, thy Salvation, own.
In Praise, to Thee, O God,
Let thine own People join;
And may the Gentile World, in Songs
Of Praise, to Thee, combine.
O let the Nations all
Be glad, and chearful sing;
For thou art, over all the Earth,
A just, and gracious King.
In Praise, to Thee, O God,
Let thine own People joyn;
And may the Gentile World, in Songs
Of Praise, to Thee, combine.
Then th' Earth shall Plenty yield;
And God shall bless our Store.
Our own God shall us bless; the World
Shall fear, and, him, adore.

div.head: PSALM LXVIII.
div.l: RISE, Lord, and let thine Enemies,
Abroad dispersed be;
Let them, that impiously Thee hate,
Before thy Presence flee.
As Smoke is driven with the Wind,
So, Lord, the Wicked chase;
As Fire melts Wax, so let thy Foes
Dissolve, before thy Face.
But let the Righteous all be glad,
Before the Lord rejoice;
With Gladness may their Hearts be fill'd,
With Shouts of Joy their Voice.
Sing unto God, Oh! sing his Praise,
With Joy exalt his Name;
Who by the Name Iehovah rides
On Heav'ns extended Frame.
God, from his holy dwelling Place,
Is, as a Father, kind
To Orphans; and a righteous Judge,
In him, the Widows find.
God, for the lonely, Houses builds,
He breaks the Captives Chain,
And sets them free; but Rebels, plagu'd,
In a dry Land remain.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: When God the Lord, from Egypt went▪
And did our Armies Head,
Their Marches, in the Wilderness,
Thro' all their Wand'rings lead;
The Earth did shake, the Heav'ns drop'd,
And thus thy Presence own;
Sinai itself then shook, for God,
Ev'n Isr'el's God, came down.
Thou Lord did'st shake the wat'ry Clouds,
And send a plenteous Rain;
When tir'd with Drought, thou kindly did'st
Thine Heritage sustain.
Thou gavest Canaan to thy Flock,
And fix'd their Dwelling there;
Thou Goodness, Lord, did'st for the Poor,
Abundantly prepare.
In all our many Victories,
'Twas thou that gav'st the Word;
And Virgin-Troops, thus, loud proclaim'd
The Wonders of the Lord:
"Great Captains, with their num'rous Hosts,
"Struck with a Panick, fled;
"And she that stay'd at Home, their Spoils
"Did part, and on them fed.
Tho' ye were Egypt's fully'd Slaves,
Yourselves ye now behold,
Shine, as Dove's Wings, with Silver tipt,
And Plumes, with yellow Gold.
When there th' Almighty scatter'd Kings,
Ye shone as Salmon's Snow.
God's Hill, Mount Bashan, far excells;
Which many Heads can show.
Why do ye leap, ye lofty Mounts?
God hath desir'd this Hill
For his Abode, inhabit here
Iehovah ever will.
The shining Chariots of our God,
Miriads of Angels are;
With them, as once on Sinai's Mount,
Our God is present there.

div.head: Third PART.
div.l: Thou hast ascended up on high,
Thy Churches glorious Head;
Thou hast, Captivity itself,
Captive, in Triumph, led:
Rich Gifts, for Men, thou hast receiv'd,
Ev'n Rebels have their Share;
That God, the Lord, might with them dwell,
And take them in his Care.
Bless'd be the Lord, each Day we live,
Who daily doth us load
With his rich Bounties from above,
Who's our Salvation's God.
For he, that is our God, has all
Salvations at Command;
And all our near Escapes from Death,
Flow from Iehovah's Hand.
But God, with deadly Wounds, shall smite
The Head of all his Foes;
Their Chief, who, in his Trespasses,
Still on presumptuous, goes.
God said, "The Conquest I'll repeat
"You gain'd o'er Bashan's King;
"You, safely, thro' the Depths of Seas,
"Whene'er 'tis needful, bring.
That you, your Feet, may deeply stain
With the high crimson Flood,
Pour'd from your slaughter'd Enemies;
And Dogs may lick their Blood.

div.head: Fourth PART.
div.l: Now, Lord, we've seen what solemn State,
Did thy Procession grace;
The Progress of my God, and King,
Into his holy Place.
Sweet Singers led the Way, then those
On Instruments who play'd;
With Damsels, who to Timbrels sung,
And pleasing Consort made.
These, as they march'd, in Chorus join'd,
"Bless ye our God, (they sung,)
"In your Assemblies praise the Lord,
"Ye who from Isr'el sprung.
The Chiefs of little Benjamin,
And Iudah's Lords, combin'd
With Zebulun, and Napthali,
And the Procession join'd.
Thy God, O Isr'el, Strength commands,
And thee to Union brought;
And now, O God, confirm the Work
Which thou, for us, hast wrought.

div.head: Fifth PART.
div.l: In Honour to thy Temple, Lord,
In Salem's chosen Seat,
May thither Kings their Presents bring,
And worship at thy Feet.
Rebuke the Spear-Men, Bulls, and Calves,
Wild Herds of Rage, and Might;
'Till with rich Presents, they submit;
Crush those in War delight.
Egypt's, and Cushes Princes then
Shall God their Off'rings bring.
Sing unto God, ye distant Realms;
To God your Praises sing.
To him that rideth on the Heav'ns,
In ancient Times that were;
Lo! thence he sends his awful Voice,
A mighty Voice we hear.
Ascribe ye boundless Pow'r to God,
Whose glorious Dignity
Is over Isr'el; and his Strength
Shines in the cloudy Sky.
O God! how terrible art thou,
Out of thy holy Place!
God, Strength and Pow'r, his Isr'el, gives;
To him be all the Praise.

div.head: PSALM LXIX.
div.l: SAve me, O God, for mighty Floods
Rush in unto my Soul.
In Depths of Mire, and Seas, I sink,
Where Surges o'er me rowl.
I'm weary with my constant Cries,
My Throat is parch'd with Heat;
Mine Eyes, with Expectation, fail,
While for my God I wait.
More than the Hairs upon my Head,
My causeless Haters are;
They're mighty, who, most wrongfully,
To shed my Blood would dare:
Then, what I took not, I restor'd,
For Peace gave up my Right.
O God, thou know'st my Foolishness,
My Sins are in thy Sight.
Lord, God of Host, let none, that wait
On Thee, be put to shame,
For my sake; nor, O Isr'el's God,
Despair, that seek thy Name.
For thy sake, I have borne Reproach;
My Face with Shame is spread.
My Brethren, of my Mother born,
Of me a Stranger made.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Zeal, for the Honour of thy House,
Hath quite consumed me;
On me hath fallen the Reproach,
Which they have aim'd at Thee.
When I, with Fasts, my Soul chastis'd,
Before Thee wept, and mourn'd;
My many Tears, and Abstinence,
To my Reproach they turn'd.
I Sackcloth made my Robes; for this
I was their Proverb long.
The Judges me revil'd, and I
Was made the Drunkard's Song.
But, Lord, in an accepted Time,
To Thee, I made my Pray'r;
O God, in thy Salvation's Truth,
And many Mercies hear.
Deliver me out of the Mire,
Let it not prove my Grave;
From all my Haters rescue me,
And from deep Waters save.
Nor Floods to overflow, nor Deeps
To swallow me, permit;
Nor let the Mouth, upon me close,
Of the voracious Pit.
Thy Loving-kindness doth excel,
Hear then, O Lord, my Pray'r;
O turn to me, as manifold
Thy tender Mercies are.
Hide not thy Face, for I'm distress'd;
But speedily me hear.
And to redeem me from my Foes,
Unto my Soul draw near.

div.head: Third PART.
div.l: All my Reproach is known to Thee,
My Shame, and my Disgrace;
My Adversaries, and their Plots,
Are all before thy Face.
Reproach hath broke my heavy Heart,
And when I look'd around,
For some to pity, there was none,
No Comforter I found.
Thirsty, they Vinegar to drink,
And Gall, gave me, for Food.
Their Table shall become their Snare;
Their Trap, what should be good.
Their Eyes be dark, lest they should see;
Their Loins be made to shake.
Thy Fury shall on them be pour'd,
Thy Wrath hold on them take.
Their Palace, and their Tents, be waste;
That they may none receive.
They persecute whom thou hast smote;
With Words thy wounded grieve.
They Sin to Sin shall add, till they
No Part in Mercy claim.
Thou, from the Book of Life, shalt blot,
And from the Just, their Name.

div.head: Fourth PART.
div.l: I'm poor, distress'd, Salvation grant;
Set me, O God, on high.
I'll praise the Name of God, with Songs,
With Thanks, him magnify.
This shall be pleasing to the Lord,
And better in his Eyes,
Than any Ox, or Bullock young,
That's ripe for Sacrifice.
The Meek, with Gladness, shall behold
The Safety I obtain;
Your Heart, who truly seek the Lord,
Shall Life, and Comfort gain.
Because the Lord will hear the Poor,
And set his Pris'ners free:
Let Heav'n, Earth, Seas, and all therein,
To praise his Name agree.
For God will Iudah's Cities build,
And his lov'd Sion save;
His People there shall safely dwell,
And sure Possession have.
His Servant's Seed inherit shall
What falleth to their Share;
And they that love his Name shall dwell,
In Peace, and Safety there.

div.head: PSALM LXX.
div.l: DEliver me, O God;
To help me, Lord, make hast.
Shame, and Confusion, be their Lot,
Who seek my Soul to waste.
Defeat, and put to Rout,
All that desire my Hurt.
Be Disappointment their Reward,
Who make my Grief their Sport.
Who seek Thee, let rejoice,
In Thee be satisfy'd;
Who thy Salvation love, still say,
"The Lord be magnify'd.
I'm poor, distress'd, O God,
Make haste to me, I pray;
My Help, and my Deliv'rer, thou,
O Lord, make no Delay.

div.head: PSALM LXXI.
div.l: IN Thee, O Lord, I place my Trust;
Me never put to Shame.
Hear, save, and cause me to escape,
For righteous is thy Name.
Be thou my dwelling Place most strong,
Where I may still resort;
Thy promis'd Safety, Lord, I plead,
Thou art my Rock, and Fort.
Save me, O God, from wicked Hands,
The cruel, and unjust.
For thou, Lord, God, hast been my Hope,
And, from my Youth, my Trust.
By Thee, I've always been sustain'd,
From my most early Days;
Thou took'st me from my Mother's Womb;
I'll ever sing thy Praise.
To many, I'm a Wonder grown;
But on thy Strength I stay.
Let, with thy Praise, my Mouth be fill'd,
And Honour all the Day.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Cast me not off, now, in the Time,
Old Age doth me assail;
O do not thou forsake me, Lord,
When Strength, and Vigour, fail.
For my malicious Enemies
Against me falsly speak;
And they, who for my Life lay wait,
Together Counsel take.
"Now God, (say they,) has him forsook,
"Pursue, and on him seize;
"There's none to save him from our Pow'r,
"He'll fall our Prey with Ease.
But thou, O God, be not far off
From me, oppress'd with Grief;
O thou, my God, with timely Speed,
Appear for my Relief.
Confound, and bring to Nought, my Foes,
Who, for my Life, combine;
Reproach, and Infamy, be heap'd,
On those my Hurt design.
My stedfast Hope shall still remain,
On Thee, fix'd all my Days;
To spread thy Glory, more and more,
I'll add new Songs of Praise.
Thy Truth, and thy Salvation, Lord,
My Mouth shall daily show;
Whose growing Numbers far surmount
The utmost I can know.
Depending on thy Strength, O God,
I'll chearfully go on;
Thy Righteousness I'll celebrate,
I'll mention thine alone.

div.head: Third PART.
div.l: Thou, O my God, hast from my Youth,
Unto this Day, me taught;
And I have openly declar'd,
The Wonders thou hast wrought.
And now, O God, forsake me not,
When old, and gray, I'm grown;
Till this, and to the future Age,
Thy Strength, and Pow'r, I've shown.
Thy Justice, Lord, in Height transcends
All that we can declare,
Who mighty Works hast done; O God,
Who may with Thee compare;
Thou, Troubles great, and sore, hast made
Me, by Experience, know;
Yet shalt thou me revive, and bring
Up from the Depth of Woe.
Thou shalt my Greatness far increase;
And to me Comfort bring.
Thy Truth, O Iacob's God, on Harp,
And Psaltery, I'll sing.
Then shall my Lips, with Joy, abound,
While I chant forth thy Praise;
My grateful Soul, by Thee, redeem'd,
Shall joyn thy Fame to raise.
My chearful Tongue, thy Righteousness,
Shall ev'ry Day proclaim;
For they're disgrac'd, that sought my Hurt,
And brought to endless Shame.

div.head: PSALM LXXII.
div.l: GIve, Lord, the King, thy clearest Light;
Thy Righteousness give to his Son,
That he may judge t • y People right,
And to the Poor, se • Justice done.
Then, from the lofty Mounts, shall flow
Sweet Peace, and all thy People bless;
The little Hills shall like them grow,
In happy Fruits of Righteousness.
He'll vindicate the injur'd Poor,
And save the Off-spring of the Just;
But, the Oppressor's haughty Pow'r,
Shall break, and crumble into Dust.
They shall Thee fear, while Sun and Moon,
Perform their Course, thro' Ages all,
He'll come, as Rain on Grass new mown,
As wat'ring Show'rs on dry Land fall.
The Just shall flourish, in his Day;
And Peace abound, 'till there's no Moon.
From Sea to Sea, shall reach his Sway,
From River, to the setting Sun.
They who in Deserts, have their Seat,
In Homage, bow before him must;
His Foes shall, couching at his Feet,
In low Prostrations, lick the Dust.
The Kings of Tarshish, and the Isles,
Shall costly Presents to him bring;
Sheba's high Lords shall offer Spoils,
And rich Gifts Saba's wealthy King.
Before him, all the Kings on Earth
Shall fall, and Homage to him pay;
All Nations, from the South, to North,
As sov'reign Lord, shall him obey.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: For, such as want, and helpless are,
He'll free; when they his Help implore.
The destitute, in Pity, spare;
And save the Souls shall of the Poor
From Fraud, and Violence, he will
Redeem their Soul, by his great Might;
Their Blood, unjustly sought to spill,
Shall very dear be in his Sight.
And he shall live; and Sheba's Gold,
To Him as Tribute shall be paid;
Daily his Name shall be extol'd,
While constant Pray'rs are for him made.
Corn, sprinkled on the Mountains Top,
Like Lebanon, shall shake, and sound,
So full the Ears, so thick the Crop;
In Cities Men, like Grass, abound.
His Name forever shall endure,
And be transmitted with the Sun;
All Nations Bliss, from him, procure,
And him proclaim the blessed One.
Bless'd be Iehovah, God most High,
The God of fav'rite Isr'el's Seed;
From him alone, in Earth, and Sky,
The Things that wond'rous are proceed.
And blessed be his glorious Name
Forever; let the whole Earth then
Be filled with his glorious Fame.
To which we shout, Amen; Amen.

div.head: PSALM LXXIII. THIRD BOOK.
div.l: YET truly God to Isr'el's good,
To all the clean in Heart.
Altho' my Feet did nigh decline,
My Steps almost depart.
My Envy at the Foolish rose,
To see the Wicked's Peace.
Because their Strength is firm, no Bands,
In Death, does on them seise.
With Troubles they are not distress'd;
Nor plagu'd like other Men.
They're cloath'd with Violence; and Pride
Hangs round them like a Chain.
Their Eyes stand out with Fatness; they
Have more than Heart could seek.
They are corrupt, their Crimes defend;
And loftily they speak.
Against the Heav'ns they set their Mouth;
Their Tongue walks thro' the Earth.
Thy People, here, return, and joyn
In their full Cups, and Mirth.
"How doth God know? in the most High,
"(They say,) is Knowledge found?
Lo! these, th' Ungodly, prosper here,
In Riches they abound.
Sure then, (said I,) I've cleans'd my Heart,
And wash'd my Hands, in vain.
For, all Day long, I plagu'd have been;
Each Morn renew'd my Pain.
But if I openly assert.
What thus I rashly say,
Lo; then th' Experience of thy Saints,
Each Age, I should betray.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: When this I sought to understand,
It was too deep for me:
Till to the House of God I went,
Then I their End did see.
Sure them thou'st set on slipp'ry Ground,
And down to Ruin cast.
How, in a Moment, are they fall'n!
With Terrors they're laid waste!
As a vain Dream, when one awakes,
Away their Glory flies;
So, Lord, when thou do'st rise to judge,
Their Show thou wilt despise.
Thus did my Heart in Ferment glow;
Pain in my Reins encreas'd.
I was so foolish, ignorant,
Before Thee, like a Beast.
Yet, still I'm with Thee; thou Support
By my Right-hand didst give.
By Counsel thou shalt guide me, then
To Glory me receive.
In Heav'n, whom have I? What, on Earth,
Can I desire, but Thee?
Tho' Flesh, and Heart, should fail, God will
My Strength, and Portion be.
Lo; they that far from Thee depart,
Shall into Ruin fall;
Those who apostatise from Thee,
Thou wilt destroy them all.
But, as for me, 〈◊〉 good I should,
Still, near to God, repair;
I in Iehovah trust, that I
May all thy Works declare.

div.head: PSALM LXXIV.
div.l: WHY hast forever cast us off,
O God? against thy Flock,
In thy delightful Pastures fed,
Why does thine Anger smoke?
Thine ancient purchas'd Flock remind,
The Lot thou did'st possess,
And hast redeem'd; this Sion's Mount,
Thy famous dwelling Place.
Come, see, and speedily requite,
The lasting Ruins wrought;
All that thy Foes, with impious Rage,
Have on thy Temple brought.
Thine En'mies roar, where once thy Tribes
For sacred Worship met;
In Token of their Victory,
Their Banners high they've set.
The Man that hew'd the Mountain Oak,
Was had in great Renown.
But now they Ax, and Hammer, join,
To break it's carv'd Works down.
Thy holy Temple they have cast
Into devouring Flame;
And, level with the Ground, defil'd
The Dwelling of thy Name.
At once, our holy Rites, and us,
To root out, they presum'd;
The Synagogues of God, with Fire,
All, thro' the Land, consum'd.
We see no more our hopeful Signs,
No Prophet calms our Woes;
How long our ruin'd State shall last,
There's none among us knows.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: How long shall our insulting Foes,
O mighty God, defame?
Forever shall the Enemy
Blaspheme thy holy Name?
Why is thy Hand with-held? Stretch, from
Thy Bosom, thy Right-hand.
For God's my Rock of old; who works
Salvation thro' the Land.
By thy resistless Strength, thou did'st
The raging Sea divide;
And crush'd the furious Dragon's Head,
Beneath the refluent Tide.
The Heads of the Leviathan,
Are broken, by thine Arm;
And to the People giv'n for Meat,
That in the Desarts swarm.
Thou clav'st the Fountain, and the Flood▪
Thou dry'st up Rivers Might.
Thine is the Day, the Night is thine;
Thou form'st the Sun, and Light.
Earth's Limits, with her various Climes,
Are fix'd by thy strong Hand;
The Summer's Heat, and Winter's Cold,
Obey thy wise Command.

div.head: Third PART.
div.l: Mind, O Iehovah, how the Foe
Has loaded us with Shame;
And how the foolish People have
Blasphem'd thy sacred Name.
The Soul of thy poor Turtle-Dove,
To Herds of Prey give not;
Nor let th' Assembly of the Poor
Be evermore forgot.
Thy faithful Cov'nant, Lord, regard;
For the dark Parts, we see,
Of th' Earth, are fill'd with rueful Seats
Of monstrous Cruelty.
O let not the Oppress'd return,
Unheard, and fill'd with Shame
But let the Poor, and Needy, still
Have Cause to praise thy Name.
Arise, O God, plead thine own Cause;
And bear in Memory,
With what Contempt, the foolish Man,
Daily, reproacheth Thee.
Forget not, Lord, the scornful Voice
Of thine insulting Foes;
Their Tumult constantly ascends,
And more blasphemous grows.

div.head: PSALM LXXV.
div.l: WE thank, and praise Thee, God;
For that thy Name is near,
Thy Pow'r, and Grace, which succours us,
Thy wondrous Works declare.
When I receive the Tribes,
Strict Justice I'll maintain.
Our Land, and People, are dissolv'd;
It's Pillars I sustain.
Let Fools from Folly cease;
And wicked curb their Pride.
I said, lift not your Horn on high;
Lay your proud Talk aside.
For from East, West, or South,
Promotion never springs.
But God is Judge, who lifts up one,
And down another flings.
For in Iehovah's Hand,
There is a dreadful Cup;
The Wine is red, with bitter Drugs
'Tis fully mixed up:
From thence he poureth out,
To each as he doth please;
But th' Impious all shall wring the Dregs,
And drink the very Lees.
I'll ever speak, and sing,
The God of Iacob's Praise.
I'll cut off all the Wicked's Horns,
The Just to Honour raise.

div.head: PSALM LXXVI.
div.l: IN Iudah, God's most clearly known;
In Isr'el, great is his Renown.
His sacred Tent's in Salem plac'd;
And Sion's with his Dwelling grac'd.
Thou break'st the Arrow, Bow, and Shield,
The Sword, and Battle in the Field.
Thy Glory shines with brighter Ray,
Excelling far the Mounts of Prey.
The stout of Heart are wholly spoil'd;
Death, in their Sleep, has them beguil'd;
And none of all their bravest Bands,
Could find the Vigour of their Hands.
When Iacob's God, in Anger, frown'd,
Chariot, and Horse, in Heap were drown'd.
Thou, thou alone, demand'st our Fear;
Who can thine angry Presence bear?
Thou mad'st, from Heav'n, thy Judgments heard;
The Earth stood still, and greatly f •• r'd.
When God, to save the Meek arose,
And scatter'd Judgments on his Foes.
Man's Wrath shall Praises to Thee gain;
The Residue thou shalt restrain.
Vow then, and pay, to God, your King;
Let all fear 〈◊〉 , and Presents bring.
From Princes he cuts off their Breath,
By an avenging Stroke of Death;
He, to the mighty Kings on Earth,
Dispenseth Terrors, in his Wrath.

div.head: PSALM LXXVII.
div.l: WIth mournful Voice, and ardent Cries,
To God, I made my Pray'r;
I oft to God my Suit renew'd,
And he to me gave Ear.
In my sad Day, I sought the Lord,
My Hands stretch'd forth by Night,
And ceased not; my burden'd Soul
No Comfort could admit.
I thought on God, the great and good,
But yet I found no Rest;
I pour'd out my Complaint, and still
My Mind remain'd oppress'd.
Thou hold'st mine Eyes awake; my Grief's
So great I cannot speak.
From former Days, and ancient Times,
I then Relief did seek.
I call'd to Mind my Songs, by Night
I commun'd with my Heart;
My Spirit search'd the hidden Cause,
And End, with all her Art.
"Forever, will the Lord cast off?
"Will he no more be kind?
"Is Mercy wholly spent; his Word
"Forever out of Mind?
"Has God forgot to shew his Grace?
"Doth Wrath his Love restrain?
"I said, the Change in God's Right-hand.
"'Tis this that gives me Pain.
But I'll remind Iehovah's Works,
Thy Wonders wrought of old:
On all thy Works I'll meditate,
Thy Doings shall be told.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Thy Way, O God, is in the Height;
Great as our God, there's none.
Thou God do'st Wonders; thou, thy Strength,
Hast to the People shown.
Thy People, by thy mighty Arm,
Thou hast from Bondage freed;
The Offspring of thy Favorites,
Iacob's and Ioseph's Seed.
The Waters saw Thee, mighty God,
Thee did the Waters see;
They fled for Fear, the Depths retir'd,
Struck with the Awe of Thee.
The Clouds abundant Waters pour'd,
The Sky sent forth a Sound;
Thy pointed Arrows arm'd with Wrath,
In Vengeance flew around.
Thy awful Voice, from Heav'n above,
In roaring Thunders, broke;
The lower World with Light'nings blaz'd,
The Earth was mov'd and shook.
Thy Way is in the rowling Sea;
(A wondrous Way we own!)
Thy Path thro' mighty Waters lyes,
Thy Footsteps are unknown.
Thou led'st thy People, like a Flock,
By Moses's skilful Hand,
And A'ron's, thro' the Wilderness,
Safe to the promis'd Land.

div.head: PSALM LXXVIII.
div.l: MY People close Attention give,
And my Instruction wisely hear;
To wholsome Words, which I shall speak,
〈…〉 obedient, list'ning Ear.
My Mouth shall Parables relate;
And ancient Mysteries unfold;
Which we our selves have heard, and known;
And what our Fathers have us told.
We'll not conceal them from their Sons.
But to the future Race make known,
Iehovah's Praise, his mighty Strength,
And wondrous Works which he hath done.
A Witness he, in Iacob, fix'd,
In Isr'el his good Laws ordain'd;
And charg'd our Fathers, all their Seed,
In Knowledge of them, should be train'd.
That Generations yet to come,
Piously taught, these Things might know;
Their Children, yet unborn, might rise,
And them to their Descendants show.
That they their Hope, on God alone,
Thro' ev'ry Age, might firmly stay;
The Works of God might not forget,
But learn his Precepts to obey.
And might not, like our Fathers, prove
A stubborn, and rebellious, Race:
Whose Heart was not sincere with God,
Nor Spirit stedfast in his Grace.
The armed Sons of Ephraim,
Train'd to the Use of Dart, and Bow,
In Day of Battle turn'd their Backs,
And meanly fled before the Foe.
They broke the Cov'nant of their God,
And did his sacred Laws despise:
Forg • t his Works, and Miracles,
Which he had wrought before their Eyes.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: He Wonders to their Father's shew'd,

In Zoa •
's Field, in Egypt's Land.
He clave the Sea, thro' which they pass'd,
And made, in Heaps, the Waters stand.
He led them with a Cloud, by Day,
And Fire, by Night; their Way to keep.
He in the Desert, clave the Rocks,
And gave them Drink, as from the Deep.
He fetch'd out Streams, from flinty Rocks,
They ran, like Rivers, by their Path.
Yet, in the Desert, more they sinn'd;
And the Most-High provok'd to Wrath.
For God they tempted in their Heart,
By asking Meat, as Lust them led
Yea, against God they spake, and said,
"Can God, in Deserts, Tables spread?
"'Tis true; he smote the Rock, and thence
"The Waters gush'd, and Streams o'erflow;
"But can he give Supplys of Bread?
"Or Flesh, on all this Host, bestow?
Iehovah heard, was very wroth,
And flaming Fire on Iacob fell;
His burning Anger fiercely rose,
Against unthankful Israel.
Because they God would not believe;
Nor in his Care, and Help, confide.
Tho' his Command, the Clouds above,
And Doors of Heav'n, had open'd wide.
He rain'd down Manna, for their Bread;
And gave them Corn, from Heav'n, to eat.
Thus Man was fed with Angel's Food!
And to the Full he gave them Meat.
In Heav'n he made the East Wind blow,
And rais'd the South, by his Command.
On them he rain'd down Flesh, like Dust;
Wing'd Fowl, as Seas unnumber'd Sand.
He let it fall within their Camp;
And with it spread their Tents around.
So they did eat, and were well fill'd;
For thus their own Desire he crown'd.
Their Lusting still remain'd uncur'd;
But while the Meat was in their Throat,
God's Wrath arose, and slew their Chiefs;
Down Isr'el's chosen young Men smote.

div.head: Third PART.
div.l: Yet, for all this, they sinned still;
His wondrous Works gain'd no Belief.
Thence he their Days consum'd in vain,
Their Years in terrifying Grief.
When some he slew, they sought him then;
And turn'd to God, with early Cry.
They call'd to Mind he was their Rock,
And their Redeemer, God Most-High.
But him they flatter'd with their Mouth;
And with their Tongues they basely ly'd.
For still their Heart was not sincere;
Nor in his Cov'nant did abide.
Yet full of Mercy, he forgave;
Nor brought them to Destruction quite:
Yea, oft he turn'd his Anger by;
Nor once did all his Wrath excite.
For he remember'd, they were frail,
Weak Flesh, whose greatest Strength is vain;
A Puff of Wind, which flyes away,
And never more returns again.
How oft they God provok'd, and griev'd,
In Deserts, where his Pow'r was shown?
They turned back, and tempted God,
Did limit Isr'el's holy One.

div.head: Fourth PART.
div.l: They thought not on the Hand, nor Day,
Which from their Foes Deliv'rance brought.
How God his Signs, in Egypt's Land,
In Zoan's Field, his Wonders, wrought,
He turn'd their Rivers, and their Streams,
To Blood; they could not drink the Gore.
Huge Swarms of divers Flies, and Frogs,
He sent to plague, and to devour.
To Caterpillars, he, their Store,
And Labours to the Locust, doom'd.
Their cheating Vines, he kill'd with Hail;
Their Sycomores with Frost consum'd.
He gave their Cattle to the Hail;
Their Flocks hot Thunder-Bolts devour'd.
On them he cast his fiercest Wrath,
And Troops of evil Angels pour'd.
He weigh'd his Anger's Path, nor spar'd
From Death; the Plague upon them came.
Egypt's First-born he smote, the chief,
And • trength, of all the Land of Ham.
But forth, like Sheep, he led his Tribes;
Thro' Deserts his own Fl • ck did guide.
He led them safely, without Fear,
Where, on their Foes, he rowl'd the Tide.
He them conducted, till they reach'd
The Borders of his holy Land;
Till to this Mountain they arriv'd,
The Purchase of his own Right-hand.
The heathen Tribes, he did expel,
Before their Face; to them divide
Their Lots by Line; and made the Tribes
Of Isr'el in their Tents reside.

div.head: Fifth PART.
div.l: They tempted still, and God Most-high
Provok'd; nor did his Laws obey.
They, like their Fathers, falsly dealt;
Like a false Bow, they turn'd away.
His Anger their high Places stir'd;
Their Idols mov'd his Jealousy.
When God heard this, then he was wroth,
And loathed Isr'el vehemently.
Then Shiloh's Tent he quite forsook;
Where he was wont with Men to dwell:
Th' Ark of his Strength he captive sold;
In Hands of Foes his Glory fell.
He gave his People to the Sword;
Against his Heritage he slam'd.
Their young Men were with Fire consum'd;
The Nuptial Songs were rarely nam'd.
Their guilty Priests fell by the Sword;
Nor did their Widows scarce repine.
Iehovah rous'd, as one from Sleep;
As strong Men shout, enflam'd with Wine.
Then, in the hinder Parts, he smote,
And put to endless Shame, their Foes.
Yet did he Ioseph's Tent refuse;
Nor more the Tribe of Ephraim chose.
But he selected Iudah's Tribe;
The Mountain Sion, which he lov'd.
There rais'd his Temple up on high;
And fix'd it, like the Earth, unmov'd.
He chose his Servant David, whom
He from the Sheepfold did advance;
From tending Ewes, Iacob to feed,
And Isr'el, his Inheritance.
So he the Tribes of Isr'el led,
With great Integrity of Heart;
And guided all their State-Affairs,
With skilfull Hands, and prudent Art.

div.head: PSALM LXXIX.
div.l: THE Heathen, Lord, thy Heritage,
Did furiously invade;
Defil'd thy Temple, and in Heaps,
Ierusalem have laid.
The Bodies of thy Servants slain,
For Meat to Fowls of Heav'n;
And thy Saints Flesh, to savage Beasts,
They cruelly have giv'n.
They round about Ierusalem,
Their Blood, like Water, shed▪
And none was found to pay the last
Kind Office to the Dead.
Our Neighbours load us with Reproach,
Our Fame they deeply wound;
We're made the very Scorn, and Mock
Of all the Nations round.
How long, Iehovah! Shall thy Wrath
Against us ne'er expire?
Shall thy inflamed Jealousy,
Burn like devouring Fire?
On heathen Tribes, who know not Thee,
Thy wrathful Vengeance pour;
On impious Kingdoms, which thy Name
Ne'er rev'rence, and adore.
For they have greedily devour'd
Thy Fav'rite Iacob's Race;
Their Rage has utterly laid waste
His ancient dwelling Place.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Mind not against us former Sins,
Let tender Mercy flow;
Our Ruin speedily prevent,
We're brought exceeding low.
Help us, O our Salvation's God,
For th' Honour of thy Name;
For thy Name's Sake, deliver us,
And purge our Souls from Blame.
Why say the Heathen, "Where's their God?
Among the Nations spread
Thy Fame, in Vengeance, in our Sight,
For Blood of Saints they've shed.
O let, before thy Face, ascend
The sighing Pris'ner's Cry;
By thy great Pow'r, preserve the Sons
Of Death, condemn'd to die.
Into their Bosom seven-fold,
Our Neighbour's Spite reward,
And the Reproach, wherewith they have
Reproached Thee, O Lord.
Then we thy Flock, thy Pasture's Sheep,
Will give thee Thanks always;
From Age to Age, we will shew forth
Our great Redeemer's Praise.

div.head: PSALM LXXX.
div.l: THOU, who led'st Ioseph, like a Flock,
O Isr'el's Shepherd hear;
Who dwell'st between the Cherubims,
Shine forth in Glory there.
Before Manasseh, Benjamin,
With Ephraim, thy Rearward;
Stir up thy Strength, and speedy come,
Our Saviour, and our Guard.
Turn us again, O God, and cause
Thy Face, so us'd to save,
To shine forth upon us, then we
Deliverance shall have.
How long, Iehovah, God of Hosts,
Wilt thou, in Anger, smoke
Against thy People's mournful Pray'r,
And they in vain invoke.
Thou do'st abundant slowing Tears,
For Meat, and Drink, impose.
A Strife we're to our Neighbours made;
A Laughter to our Foes.
Turn us, O God of Hosts, and cause
Thy Face, so us'd to save,
To shine forth upon us, then we
Deliverance shall have.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: From Egypt, thou did'st bring a Vine,
Under Oppression bred;
The Heathen, noxious Weeds, cast out,
And plant it in their Stead.
Before it thou prepared'st Room,
Where it was meant to stand;
There thou did'st make it take deep Root,
It grew, and fill'd the Land.
It's Shade did Mountains over-cast,
And Boughs God's Cedars hide.
Her Arms stretch'd to the Western Sea,
Her Branch Euphrates Side.
Oh! why then hast thou broken down
Her Hedge, and laid her bare?
That all the Passengers that Way,
Do her in Pieces tear.
The Boar, out of the Wood, doth root,
And sadly lay it waste;
The wild Beasts of the Field do make
Her Clusters their Repast.

div.head: Third PART.
div.l: Return, O God of Hosts, we pray,
And let thine Heart incline,
To look from Heav'n, and behold,
And visit soon this Vine.
The Vineyard, which thine own Right-hand
Did plant, and guard so long;
The Branch, which for thy self alone,
Thou mad'st so very strong.
Behold, thy Vine is burnt with Fire,
It's Branches are cut down▪
They perish do at thy Rebuke,
Because thy Face doth frown.
Upon the Man of thy Right-hand,
Let thy Hand be display'd;
Upon the Son of Man, whom thou
Strong, for thyself, hast made.
So we will not from Thee revolt,
Nor more incur thy Blame;
Oh, do thou us revive, and we
Will call upon thy Name.
Lord, God of Hosts, turn us, and cause
Thy Face, so us'd to save,
To shine forth upon us, then we
Deliverance shall have.

div.head: PSALM LXXXI.
div.l: WIth raised Voice, to God, our Strength,
Aloud his Praises sing;
With Shouting, make a joyful Noise,
To Iacob's God, and King.
Strike up a Psalm, the Timbrel bring,
And with your Voices join;
The pleasant Harp, and Psaltery,
In Consort sweet combine.
The Trumpet blow, in the New-Moon;
When our Feast-Days arrive.
To Isr'el, for a Statute Law,
This Iacob's God did give.
This Witness he, in Ioseph, set,
When thorough Egypt's Land
He went; where we a Language heard,
We could not understand.
Then, from his Shoulders, I remov'd,
The Burden on him lay;
His Hands then ceased from the Pots,
And working in the Clay.
In thy Distress, thou call'dst on me,
And I thy Griefs remov'd;
In Thunders secret Place reply'd,
At Massah's Stream thee prov'd.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: "Hear, O my People, my Protest;
"O Isr'el hear my Word.
