"No strange God shall in thee be found▪
"No foreign Lord ador'd.
"Iehovah, I thy God, thee brought
"From Egypt's miry Clays;
"Thy Mouth wide open, I'll it fill,
"With Plenty, and with Praise.
"But Isr'el would not hear my Voice;
"Nor me their Choice would make.
"So I them left to their Heart's Lusts,
"Their own Advice to take.
Oh, that my People me had heard,
And walk'd in my Command.
I would have soon subdu'd their Foes,
And on them turn'd my Hand.
From them that hate the Lord, I would
A forc'd Submission gain;
But as for them, their happy Times
Forever should remain.
I would have fed them with the best,
And finest of the Wheat;
Of Honey, from the Rock distill'd,
They, to their Fill, should eat.

div.head: PSALM LXXXII.
div.l: GOD, in the Congregation, stands,
Among the Men of Might;
The earthly Gods he strict surveys,
Their Actions judges right.
"How long, (said he) then, will you dare
"False Judgment to award;
"The Wicked's Person to accept,
"And partially regard?
"Defend the Poor, and Fatherless,
"And right the Weak distress'd.
"From wicked Hands, deliver those,
"With Tyranny, oppress'd.
They know not, nor will understand,
But walk perversly blind;
The Earth's Foundations all are mov'd,
And greatly undermin'd.
"I said, Ye're Gods; all of you Sons
"Of the Most-High did call.
"But ye shall die, like common Men,
"Like other Princes fall.
Arise, O God, and judge the Earth,
Restore lost Righteousness:
For thou, the Nations of the World,
As Sov'reign shalt possess.

div.head: PSALM LXXXII. 2d Meetre.
div.l: AMidst th' Assemblies of the Great,
The World's great Ruler takes his Seat,
And earthly Gods doth judge; (and says)
"How long will ye pervert the Laws,
"Accept the Person, plead the Cause,
"Of such as walk in wicked Ways.
"Defend the Poor, and Fatherless;
"To such as are in deep Distress
"Impartial Justice let be done.
"Loose the Oppressed's heavy Bands;
"And, from the Wicked's griping Hands,
"Deliver ye the needy one.
They know not, nor will understand,
They walk in Darkness; thro' the Land,
The Earth's Supports are overthrown.
"You I have honour'd with my Name,
"And styl'd you Gods; ye all, in Fame,
"For Sons of the Most-High have shone.
"But ye shall die, like common Men,
"Like other Princes fall; and then
"Account to me, for all your Wrongs.
Arise, O God, to judge the Earth;
For ev'ry Nation from it's Birth,
To Thee, by sov'reign Right belongs.

div.head: PSALM LXXXIII.
div.l: O GOD, to our repeated Cries,
No longer Silence keep;
Hold not thy Peace, as unconcern'd,
Nor let thy Vengeance sleep.
For lo, thine Enemies, O God,
Have a fierce Tumult made;
And those, that impiously Thee hate,
In Pride lift up the Head.
Against thy People they consult,
And all their Craft employ;
Their chief Design's thy hidden ones
Intirely to destroy.
"Come, said they, let us wholly root
"The Nation from the Ground;
"That Isr'el's hated Name, no more
"Be in Remembrance found.
Together they, with one Consent,
In Counsel, have combin'd;
These diff'ring Nations, close in League,
Against Thee, Lord, are join'd.
There's Esau's Sons, who dwell in Tents,
Ishm'el's rejected Line,
Moab, of Incest eldest Brood,
With Hagar's Arabs joyn.
Strong Gebal, Ammon, Moab's Kin,
With Amalek conspire;
The Lords of Palestine's Sea Coast,
And with them wealthy Tyre.
Proud Ashur's pow'rfull Troops, the League,
And common Cause, espouse;
These prove the strongest Arm of Strength,
To Lot's apostate House.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: But let such Vengeance on them fall,
As Midian overtook;
As Sisera, and Iabin, felt,
At Kishon's fatal Brook.
Where all their mighty num'rous Host,
Were put to Rout, and slain;
Who left their Carcasses for Dung,
On Endor's fertile Plain.
As Zeb, and Oreb, make their Chiefs,
Like Vengeance seise them all:
As Zeba, and Zalmunna, fell,
May all their Princes fall.
Who boasting, said, "Let's seise for ours
"Each House of God we find.
My God, to Ruin whirl them round,
As Chaff before the Wind.
As raging Fire consumes the Woods,
With Flames the Mountains blaze.
So with thy Tempest them pursue,
And with thy Storm amaze.
Their Faces fill with Shame, that they
May seek Iehovah's Name.
Or them confound, and terrify,
Until they dye in Shame.
The Nations then shall know, that thou▪
To whom alone pertains
The Name Iehovah, art Most-high,
O'er Earth's extended Plains.

div.head: PSALM LXXXIV.
div.l: HOW amiable, Lord of Hosts,
How pleasant is the Place,
Where thou, 〈◊〉 Earth, art wont to shew
The Glories of thy Face?
My Soul doth long, yea, faint to see
Iehovah's chosen Seat;
My Heart, and Flesh, spring up for Joy,
The living God to meet.
The Birds, near to thine Altars, build
Their Nests, for their Abode;
There hatch their Young; O Lord of Hosts,
My Sov'reign, and my God.
O happy Men, who in thy House
Abide; still they'll Thee praise:
Whose Strength's in Thee, and Hearts are bent
To travel Sion's Ways.
Who, passing Baca's thirsty Vale,
Provide themselves with Wells,
And Cisterns; which the Rain from Heav'n,
For their Refreshment, fills.
Strengthen'd they go, till they, with God,
In Sion's Mount appear.
Lord, God of Hosts, my Pray'r regard,
O Iacob's God give Ear.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: O God, who art our only Shield,
Look graciously on me;
And, with thy wonted Smiles, the Face
Of thine anointed see.
For in thy sacred Courts, a Day,
A Thousand does excell;
My God's House Doors I'd rather keep,
In wicked Tents, than dwell.
Iehovah is our Sun, and Shield,
Will Grace, and Glory, give;
And, no Good Thing, will he deny,
Those who uprightly live.
O thou, the sov'reign Lord of all
The Hosts in Heav'n, Earth, Sea;
That Man is truly bless'd, who puts
His Trust alone in Thee.

div.head: PSALM LXXXV.
div.l: THOU, Lord, thy Land hast Favour shown;
And back thy captiv'd Iacob led.
Thy People's Guilt hast lifted off;
And all their Sin hast covered.
Thou all thine Anger hast remov'd;
Thy flaming Wrath thou do'st appease.
Turn us, O our Salvation's God;
And let thine Anger wholly cease.
Wilt thou, with us, be angry still?
Thro' Ages shall thy Wrath remain?
Wilt thou not us again revive;
That we may Joy in Thee regain?
Iehovah, graciously appear,
And tender Pity to us show;
All the Salvation which we need,
Upon us bounteously bestow.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: I'll wait to hear what God will say,
For to his People he'll speak Peace,
And to his Saints; but let not them·
Return again to Foolishn • ss.
To them that fear his sacred Name,
Sure, his Salvation's near at Hand;
That th' ancient Glory may return,
And firmly settle in our Land.
Mercy, and Truth, shall friendly meet;
Justice, and Peace, kindly embrace
Truth springs from th'Earth, while Righteousness
From Heav'n looks down with smiling Face.
Yea, what is Good the Lord will give;
Our Land it's yearly Fruits display.
Before him, Righteousness shall march;
And guide our Steps in his just Way.

div.head: PSALM LXXXVI.
div.l: BOW down, O Lord, thine Ear, hear me;
Oppress'd, and Poor, am I.
Keep thou my righteous Soul, which doth
On Thee, my God, rely.
To Thee, I daily make my Pray'r;
Have Mercy, Lord, on me,
Joy, to thy Servant's Soul, restore;
Who lifts his Heart to Thee.
For thou, O Lord, art good and kind,
Ready to pardon all;
Plenteous in Mercy unto them,
In Truth, that on Thee call.
Lord, hear my Pray'r, and to the Voice
of my Request attend.
In Straits, I'll call on Thee, who wilt
A gracious Answer send.
Among the Gods there's none like Thee;
Nor any Works like thine.
The Nations all, whom thou hast made,
Shall in sweet Consort join;
Themselves shall bow before thy Face,
And glorify thy Name.
For thou art great; thy wondrous Works
Thee, God alone, proclaim.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Teach me thy Way, O Lord, and I
In Truth will persevere;
Unite, and fix, my wand'ring Heart,
Thy sacred Name to fear.
With all my Heart, I'll praise Thee, Lord,
Thy Glories ever tell.
For thy great Mercy has my Soul▪
Freed from the lowest Hell.
O God, the Proud against me rise,
And pow'rfull Troops have sought
To take my Life; who ne'er employ,
On Thee, one serious Thought.
But thou, O Lord, a mercifull,
And gracious God, art found:
Thine Anger is not soon provok'd,
Thy Grace, and Truth, abound.
O turn to me thy placid Face,
Let Pity now be shown;
Thy Strength, unto thy Servant, give,
And save thine Hand-Maid's Son.
Such Marks of Favour to me show,
As all my Foes may see,
Oppress'd with Shame; because, Lord, thou
Dost help, and comfort me.

div.head: PSALM LXXXVII.
div.l: JEhovah, in the holy Mounts,
Has his Foundation laid.
His Love's, to Sion's Gates, more than
All Iacob's Tents, display'd.
Most glorious Things are spoke of thee,
And spread thy Fame abroad,
O thou Ierusalem; which art
The City of our God.
Egypt, and Babylon, I'll name,
(They somewhat have me known,)
Philistia, Tyre, and Cush; lo there
Sprang some of great Renown.
But this of Sion shall be said,
There many such were born;
And the Most-High himself shall her
Establish, and adorn.
The Lord, when he makes up the Roll,
Shall note, There born was he.
There Singers, and sweet Harpers, join;
My Springs are all in Thee.

div.head: PSALM LXXXVII. 2d Meetre.
div.l: JEhovah his Foundations laid,
On the renowned sacred Hills;
To Sion's Gates, his Love's display'd,
More than the Tents were Iacob dwells.
Most glorious Things are spoke abroad,
Of thee, O City of our God.
I'll Rahab name, and Babylon,
(Which know me,) with Philistia,
And Tyre, and Cush; perhaps there's one,
Sprang from them, famous in their Day.
But Sion's fam'd for bringing forth
Many renowned Men of Worth:
The Highest shall establish her,
With future Worthies her adorn.
When God shall the grand Roll prefer,
He'll note, There such an one was born.
Singers, and Harpers, there abound;
And all my Springs in thee are found.

div.head: PSALM LXXXVIII.
div.l: LORD, God of my Salvation, I
To Thee, by Day, and Night, do cry.
Before Thee, let my Pray'r appear;
And to my Cry encline thine Ear.
Troubles, my Soul, so filled have,
My Life draws nigh unto the Grave.
I'm number'd with the Dead; as one
Whose Strength is lost, and Spirit gone.
As free among the dead am I,
Like slain Men, in their Graves that ly,
Whom thou in Mind no more do'st bear▪
Who by thy Hand consumed are.
Thou'st plung'd me in the Pit most low,
In Darkness in the Depth of Woe.
On me thy Wrath has heavy lain?
And all thy Waves encreas'd my Pain.
Yea, those that mine Acquaintance were,
From me thou hast removed far;
A loathsome Spectacle I'm made;
Shut up, to walk abroad afraid.
Mine Eye, the Marks of Sorrow, wears,
And spends itself in flowing Tears;
To Thee Iehovah, I have pray'd,
And daily stretch'd my Hands, for Aid.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Wilt thou shew Wonders to the Dead?
Shall dead Men rise, thy Praise to spread?
Shall thy great Love the Grave confess?
Destruction speak thy Faithfulness?
In Darkness shines thy mighty Hand?
Thy Justice in Oblivion's Land?
Tho', Lord, I've cry'd in vain, each Day,
Before Thee; still I'll early pray.
Why, Lord, cast'st thou my Soul from Thee?
Why hid'st thy gracious Face from me?
Distress'd from Youth, brought nigh the Grave,
Thy Terrors me Amazement gave.
Thy fierce Wrath over me hath past;
Thy Terrors held, and bound me fast.
Daily, around me, like the Tide,
They flow, and compass ev'ry Side.
Lover, and Friend, I dearly lov'd,
Thou from my Sight hast far remov'd;
And those that my Acquaintance were,
In Darkness hide themselves, for Fear.

div.head: PSALM LXXXIX.
div.l: THE Mercies of the Lord, I'll sing,
And never cease the Song;
From Age to Age, thy Faithfulness
I'll publish with my Tongue.
For I have said, that Mercy shall
Forever built remain;
Thy Faithfulness, thou, in the Heav'ns,
And like them, wilt maintain.
"With mine Elect, I form'd a League,
"An Oath to David swore;
"I'll fix thy Seed, and build thy Throne,
"Secure forevermore.
The Heav'ns, for thy great Wonder, Lord,
Shall with thy Praises ring;
While thine assembled Saints, on Earth,
Thy Faithfulness shall sing.
But who of all the heav'nly Hosts,
May with the Lord compare?
What Sons of all the earthly Gods,
Vie with Iehovah, dare?
God's Terror strikes his Saints below,
With a religious Fear;
And awful Rev'rence guards the Minds,
That round his Throne appear.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Lord, God of Hosts, who's arm'd with Pow'r,
Or girt with Truth, like Thee?
Proud Waves arise, are still, and calm,
As thou do'st rule the Sea.
Thou, Egypt's Pow'r, with deadly Wounds,
Hast into Pieces broke;
Thine Arm of Strength dispers'd thy Foes,
With an avenging Stroke.
Thine are the Heav'ns, the Earth is thine,
Which thou alone hast made;
As for the World, with all it's Stores,
God it's Foundation laid.
The northern, and the southern Poles,
Thou, by thy Pow'r, did'st frame;
Tabor, and Hermon, famous Mounts,
Rejoice shall in thy Name.
Thy Arm is mighty, strong thy Hand,
Thy Right-hand's fam'd in Deed.
Justice and Judgment, found thy Throne,
While Grace and Truth, precede.
Blest Men! who know the joyful Sound;
They in thy Favour walk.
All Day, they in thy Name, rejoice;
Justice shall them exalt.
Thou, Glory of their Strength, shalt raise
Our Horn, thro' Favour shown.
Iehovah's our Defence; our King
Is Isr'el's holy One.

div.head: Third PART.
div.l: "In Vision, to thine holy One.
"Thou said'st, I'll Help impose
"On one that's mig • ty; whom I've rais'd,
"And from the People chose.
"I've found my Servant David; him
"With holy Oil anoint.
"Him shall my Hand confirm; mine Arm
"Support whom I appoint.
"No En'mies Arts shall him deceive;
"Nor wicked Men controul.
"I'll crush his Foes, before his Face,
"And plague the spiteful Soul.
"My Truth, & Grace, with him, shall raise
"His Horn high, in my Name:
"His Left-Hand Bounds, I'll fix the Sea;
"His Right, Euphrates Stream.
"To me my Father, God, and Rock
"Of Safety, he shall cry.
"I'll place him my First-born, above
"All earthly Kings, most high.
"I'll ever Mercy for him keep;
"My Cov'nant standeth fast.
"His Seed shall never fail, his Throne,
"As Days of Heav'n, shall last.

div.head: Fourth PART.
div.l: "But if his Sons forsake my Law,
"And from my Judgments stray;
"If they my Statutes break, and dare
"My Precepts disobey:
"Their Sin I'll visit with a Rod;
"With Stripes, as Crimes prevail.
"But from him I'll not take my Love;
"My Truth shall never fail.
"My Cov'nant I will never break;
"Nor, what I've said, deny.
"Once, by my Holiness, I've sworn;
"I'll not to David lye.
"His Race shall never fail; his Throne
"Shall, as the Sun, endure:
"Fix'd ever, as the Moon; in Heav'n,
"Which, Witnesses, are sure.
But thine Anointed, thou, in Scorn,
And Anger, off hast cast.
Thou mad'st thy Servant's Cov'nant void,
In Dust his Crown debas'd.
Thou, all his Hedges, hast broke down;
His Forts in Ruin laid.
He's spoil'd by all that by him pass;
His Neighbour's Scorn he's made.
His Foes thou causest to rejoice;
Confirming their Right-Hand.
His Sword was blunted, nor could he
In Day of Battle stand.
His Throne thou level'st with the Ground;
And hast eclips'd his Fame.
His Youth, and Reign, thou short hast cut;
And cover'd him with Shame.

div.head: Fifth PART.
div.l: How long, O Lord, wilt thou abscond,
And we thy Absence mourn?
Forever? Shall thy Wrath, like Fire,
Against thy People burn?
Oh, call to Mind, what is the Age
Thou dost for Man ordain?
Wherefore hast thou created all
The Sons of Men in vain.
What Man that lives, can Death escape?
What Skill, or Pow'r, can save
His Soul from his strong griping Hands?
Or rescue from the Grave?
Where's Lord, thy former Love, thou didst,
In Truth, to David, swear?
Remember, Lord, with what Contempt,
Thy Servants treated are:
I've, in my Bosom, the Reproach
Of mighty People borne;
Wherewith thine Enemies, O Lord,
Have poured out their Scorn;
They thine Anointed's Steps traduc'd,
And thus reproached Thee.
Bless'd be the Lord forevermore;
Amen; Amen; say we.

div.head: PSALM XC. FOURTH BOOK.
div.l: THro' all the changing Scenes, have past
Over thy chosen Race;
Thou, Lord, alone, from Age to Age,
Hast been our dwelling Place.
Before the Mountains, Earth, or World,
Were formed by thy Nod;
Thou Lord, from everlasting art,
To everlasting, God.
'Tis thou, to Rottenness, and Dust,
Dost turn weak mortal Man;
For thou hast said, "Ye Adam's Sons,
"Return to Earth again.
And should he reach a Thousand Years,
It would be, in thy Sight,
But as a Day, that's past, and gone;
Or a short Watch by Night.
As with a Flood's most rapid Stream,
Thou dost them sweep away;
Like Dreams they vanish; in the Morn,
As Grass, look fair, and gay:
But howsoe'er it looks, away
It's Morning Beauty flies;
When Ev'ning comes, 'tis all cut down,
It withereth up, and dies.
We, by thine Anger, are consum'd;
Thy Wrath does us afright.
Thou set'st our Crimes, and secret Sins,
All plain before thy Sight.
Thence, all our Days, in thy hot Wrath,
To speedy End are brought;
We spend our Years, as quick as Speech,
Swift as a Breath, or Thought.
Our Days are Threescore Years and Ten;
If Strength to Fourscore stay,
'Tis Grief, and Pain; we're soon cut off,
And hence we fly away.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Oh! Who doth know thine Anger's Force!
Wrath, as thy Fear, is great!
Teach us to number so our Days,
That we may Wisdom get.
Return, Iehovah, O return;
How long shall be the Space?
And let thy yearning Bowels move,
To shew thy Servants Grace.
Oh, let thy Mercy early fill
Our Souls, and Spirits raise;
That we may triumph, and rejoice,
Thro' all our future Days.
May our succeeding Days, and Years,
Abundant Comfort yield:
As all our former Ones have been,
With great Affliction fill'd.
Let this thy special Work of Love,
Be to thy Servants shown;
The Glory of thy promis'd Grace,
To all their Offspring known.
The Beauty of the Lord, our God,
Let on us ever shine;
Guide, and confirm, our handy Work,
And prosper our Design.

div.head: PSALM XCI.
div.l: HE that, the Highest's secret Place,
His sure Retreat, has made,
Secure shall rest, from threat'ning Ills,
Beneath th' Almighty's Shade.
Of this Iehovah, I will say,
"He is my Refuge high,
"My strong Munition, and my God;
"On him I will rely.
Surely; he shall deliver thee,
Out of the Fowler's Snare;
And save thee, when the noisome Plague
Infects the vital Air.
His Feathers shall thee cover o'er,
His Wings Protection yield;
His never-failing Truth shall be
Thy Buckler, and thy Shield.
Thou shalt no nightly Terrors fear;
Nor Shafts that fly by Day:
No fatal Plague, that darkly walks;
Nor Noon's malignant Ray.
Thousands shall fall around thee slain;
Yet shall it not touch thee.
Thine Eyes shall only this behold,
And Sinners Portion see.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Because my Refuge, God, Most-high,
Thy Dwelling thou hast made;
Therefore, no Ill shall thee befall,
Nor Plague thy House invade.
He'll charge his Angels, thee to keep,
In all thy Ways, from Harms,
They, lest a Stone offend thy Feet,
Shall bear thee in their Arms.
On th' Asp, and Lyon, thou shalt tread,
Fearless, when e'er ye meet;
The Lyon young, and Dragons fierce,
Shalt trample under Feet.
"Because his Love is fix'd on me,
"His Freedom I proclaim;
"I'll set him high, from Dangers safe,
"For he hath known my Name.
"When e'er he calls, I'll answer him;
"In Troubles I'll be nigh,
"To rescue him from ev'ry Ill;
"And raise his Honour high.
"With Length of Days, as best shall be,
"I'll satisfy his Soul;
"Then my Salvation to him shew,
"Where endless Pleasures rowl.

div.head: PSALM XCII.
div.l: 'TIS good, and sweet, to thank the Lord;
Praise to thy Name to sing, Most-high.
Each Morn, thy Kindness, to record;
And ev'ry Night, thy Verity.
Upon a Ten-string'd Instrument,
With Psaltery, in sweet Compound;
On sprightly Harp, in one Consent,
With sacred Songs, and solemn Sound.
• hou, thro' thy Work of Pow'r, and Grace,
The Works thine Hand hath wro't, shall raise
My shout to Thee, with thankful Voice.
How wondrous great thy Works are, Lord!
And how profoundly deep thy Thought!
A brutish Man knows not thy Word;
Nor Fools perceive what thou hast wrought.
When, like the Grass, the Wicked spring,
And flourishing, look fresh, and fair;
It is, that thou may'st on them bring
An endless Ruin, and Despair.
But thou, Lord, ever art Most-high.
For lo, thy Foes shall quite decay;
And all that work Iniquity,
In Wrath, shall be dispers'd away.
But thou, mine Horn, on high shalt raise,
Fix'd as the Unicorn's, secure;
Thy fresh anointing Oyl conveys
New Joys to me, unmix'd, and pure.
Mine Eyes shall see th' expected Doom,
Mine Ears the dismal End shall hear,
That on my secret Foes shall come;
And those me open Malice bear.
The Just, like fruitful Palms, shall thrive;
Like Lebanon's tall Cedars grow.
They in the Lord's House planted, live,
And flourish, in his Courts below.
They still bear Fruit, when aged grown;
With Vigour fill'd, and Verdure crown'd.
The Lord, my Rock, thus upright's known;
In him there's no Injustice found.

div.head: PSALM XCII. 2d Meetre.
div.l: 'TIS good to thank the Lord,
And sing thy Praise, Most-high:
Each Morn, thy Kindness to record,
Each Night, thy Verity.
On Ten-string'd Instrument,
With Psalt'ry's tuneful Wind;
On sprightly Harps, in one Consent,
With solemn Voices joyn'd.
Thy Work of Pow'r, and Grace,
Lord, makes my Heart rejoice;
I, in thy handy-Works, will raise,
With Shouts of Praise, my Voice.
How great thy Works are, Lord!
How very deep thy Thought!
A brutish Man knows not thy Word;
Nor Fools what thou hast wrought.
When wicked Men do spring,
Like Grass, look fresh, and fair,
'Tis that to Ruin thou may'st them bring,
And cover with Despair.
Thou'rt ever, Lord, Most-high.
For lo, thy Foes shall fall;
And they that work Iniquity,
Shall be dispersed all.
But thou mine Horn shalt raise,
As Unicorn's, on high;
And with fresh Oyl, thro' all my Days,
Anointed be shall I.
Mine Eye shall see the Doom,
Mine Ear the End shall hear,
That on my Spies, and Foes, shall come;
And such as Malice bear.
The Just, like Palms, shall thrive,
Like Leb'non's Cedars grow:
Those in the Lord's House planted, live,
In's Courts they glorious show.
In Age, their Fruit is bright,
With Strength, and Verdure, crown'd.
To shew the Lord, my Rock, 's upright;
In him no Falshood's found.

div.head: PSALM XCIII.
div.l: JEhovah reigns with Strength begirt,
And Majesty array'd,
The World immovably he fix'd,
On sure Foundations laid.
Thy Throne is founded thence, thou art
From all Eternity.
The Floods, O Lord, lift up their Voice;
They toss their Waves on high.
The Lord, who dwells above, transcends,
In Strength, the roaring Voice
Of many Waters, or the Seas
Most fiercely raging Noise.
Iehovah's Testimonies are
Most sure, they cannot lye;
And everlasting Holiness
Thy House should beautify.

div.head: PSALM XCIII. 2d Meetre.
div.l: JEhovah ever reigns,
With Majesty array'd;
And Strength begirts his Reins.
The World unmov'd is stay'd.
Thy Throne on high
Hath firmly stood,
For thou art God,
Eternally.
The Floods lift up their Voice,
The Sea in Tumult swells:
The Lord the fiercest Noise
Of raging Waves excells.
Most sure's thy Word:
Strict Holiness
Will ever grace
Thy House, O Lord.

div.head: PSALM XCIV.
div.l: JEhovah, God of Vengeance, shine
Forth, in thy Justice, bright,
Arise, thou Judge of all the Earth;
Thy haughty Foes requite.
How long, O Lord, shall wicked Men,
How long, triumph, shall they?
How long throw out, and hard Things speak,
And glory in their Way?
Thy People, Lord, they grind to Dust;
Thy Heritage oppress;
The Widow, and the Stranger, slay;
And murder, Fatherless.
"Yet say they, God doth not behold;
"Nor Iacob's God discern.
Ye bruitish People think; ye Fools,
When will ye Wisdom learn.
Shall he, who plants the Ear, not hear?
Nor see, who form'd Man's Eyes?
He that whole Nations doth rebuke,
Fools shall not he chastise?
Shall not he know, who teacheth Men
The Knowledge they attain?
Iehovah knows the Tho'ts of Man,
That they are very vain.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Blest is the Man! the Lord corrects,
And in his Law has taught.
In e • il Days he rests; till Pits
Are for the Wicked wrought.
The Lord will not cast off his Flock;
Nor Heritage quite leave.
Judgment to Justice shall return;
To it the Good shall cleave.
Against the Wicked and Unjust,
Who'll on my Side appear?
My Soul had soon, in Silence, dwelt,
Had not the Lord, been near.
When e'er I cry'd, my Foot slips; Lord,
Thy Mercy held me right.
Amidst my many troubled Thoughts,
Thy Comforts me delight.
Shall unjust Thrones have Part with Thee,
Which Mischief frame by Law?
They meet, and join, the guiltless Blood
Of righteous Men to draw.
But thou, Iehovah, still hast been,
To me, a Refuge high;
My God, who art my only Rock,
Where I for Shelter fly.
He shall, their own Iniquity,
Upon their Heads, repay;
The Lord, our God, in their own Guilt▪
Them utterly shall slay.

div.head: PSALM XCV.
div.l: O Come, let us, in Consort, join
In Songs to great Iehovah's Name.
The Praise of our Salvation's Rock,
With joyfull Hearts, aloud pro • laim.
Let us, with Thanks, approach his Face;
And our loud Anthems to him sing.
Because Iehovah's a great God;
Above all Gods he's a great King.
the Earth's deep Caverns, with the Strength
Of lofty Hills, are in his Hand.
His is the Ocean, which he made;
His Hands have form'd the firmer Land.
Come, let us worship, and bow down;
Our Knees to our Creator bend.
For he's our God, and we the Flock▪
His Pastures feed, and Hands defend.
To Day, if ye will hear his Voice,
Then harden not your Hearts; as they
In Time of Provocation, did,
On Meribah, and Massa's, Day.
Your Fathers did me tempt, and prove,
While my great Works shone in their Face.
For Forty Years, I patient bore,
Tho' weary'd, with that stubborn Race.
"This People err in Heart, I said,
"My Ways they know not, tho' the best,
"Therefore I sware to them, in Wrath,
"They ne'er should come into my Rest.

div.head: PSALM XCV. 2d Meetre.
div.l: O Come, let us unite, and sing
Unto Iehovah's Name;
The Praise of our Salvation's Rock,
With Joy, aloud proclaim.
With grateful Thanks, before him come;
And joyful Hymns loud sing.
Because Iehovah's a great God;
O' • r all Gods a great King.
The Earth's deep Caverns, lofty Hills,
Are in his sov'reign Hand.
His is the Sea, which he hath made,
His Hands form'd the dry Land.
Come, let us worship, and bow down,
Before our Maker kneel.
For he's our God, and we his Sheep,
He doth us feed, and heal.
To Day, if ye will hear his Voice,
O grow not hard, as they
In Desert did, on Meribah's,
And Massa's woful Day.
Your Fathers did me tempt, and prove;
My Works shone in their Face.
I, forty Years, was grieved with
That stubborn, faithless Race.
I said, this People err in Heart,
My Ways they will not know;
To them I sware, in Wrath, if they
Into my Rest should go.

div.head: PSALM XCVI.
div.l: Sing to Iehovah a new Song;
In this agree let ev'ry Tongue.
Sing to the Lord, and bless his Name;
Daily his saving Health proclaim.
His Glory to the Heathen show;
Make all their Tribes his Wonders know.
God's great, and greatly to be prais'd;
In Fear, above all Gods, he's rais'd.
For Heathen Gods are but a Name;
But Heav'n's wide Arch the Lord did frame.
Majestick Honours on him wait:
Beauty, and Strength, adorn his Seat.
O all ye Kingdoms, ev'ry Tribe,
Glory, and Pow'r, to God ascribe.
Give him the Glory, to him due;
With Off'rings to his Courts come you.
To worship, in his House, repair,
Let all the Earth him rev'rence there.
To all the Nations this rehearse,
Iehovah reigns thro' th' Universe;
The World unmov'd shall stablish'd be,
The People justly judge shall he.
Let Heav'n, and Earth, thereat rejoice,
Seas, and their Stores, with roaring Voice.
Let fertile Fields, and all Things there,
Their Joy, in chearful Shouts declare;
Then all the Trees shall leap and sing,
And Joy, thro' all the Woods, shall ring.
Before the Lord, who comes to bless
The World, with Truth, and Righteousness;
With Truth, and Justice, he shall come,
To pass on all their final Doom.

div.head: PSALM XCVII.
div.l: JEhovah reigns, let all the Earth,
Triumphantly rejoice;
And let the Multitude of Isles
Unite their chearful Voice.
Thick Clouds and Darkness him surround,
His Counsels are unknown;
But Righteousness, and Judgment, are
The Basis of his Throne.
Fire march'd before; his Foes around
Sink in the burning Flood.
His Light'nings blaz'd thro'out the World;
Earth saw, and trembling stood.
The solid Mountains melt, like Wax,
Before Iehovah's Face;
Before that Lord, whose sov'reign Rule,
O'er all the Earth, takes Place.
Th' extended Heav'ns, his Righteousness,
Have publish'd all abroad;
And all the World have clearly seen,
The Glories of our God.
May all that graven Idols serve,
And boast in earthly Clods,
Of all their Folly be asham'd;
Him worship all ye Gods.
Sion, and Iudah's Daughters, heard,
With Joy, thy Judgments, own'd.
For o'er the Earth, thou, Lord, art high,
Above all Gods enthron'd.
O ye that love, and fear, the Lord,
All Evil disesteem;
The holy Souls he'll guard, and them
From wicked Hands redeem.
For just, and upright Men, are sown,
Immortal Light, and Bliss.
Rejoice, ye Just, in God; with Thanks,
Record, his Holiness.

div.head: PSALM XCVIII.
div.l: SIng, to Iehovah, a new Song,
For Wonders he hath wrought;
His Right-hand, and his holy Arm,
The Victory have got.
His great Salvation, to the World,
Iehovah hath made known;
He, all the Nations, openly,
His Righteousness, hath shown.
His Grace, and Truth, to Isr'el's House,
Fully perform'd have been;
The utmost Bounds of all the Earth,
Have God's Salvation seen.
Let all the Earth, their Voice, to God,
In Songs of Triumph, raise;
Make the Air ring, with their loud Shouts,
And jointly sing his Praise.
Sweet Harps, and tuneful Voices join;
In Psalms, the Lord's Praise sing.
Trumpet, and Cornet, take, and shout
Before the Lord, the King.
Let Seas loud roar, the Earth and all
In them, in Shouts combine,
Let Floods clap Hands, and all the Hills
In joyful Consort joyn.
Before the Lord; to judge the Earth,
He comes, in Majesty;
The World with Justice, and it's Tribes,
To judge, with Equity.

div.head: PSALM XCIX.
div.l: JEhovah sov'reign King doth reign,
Let guilty Sinners quake;
He sits between the Cherubims,
The Earth let reel, and shake.
The Lord, in Sion, great appears,
High o'er all People rais'd.
By them, thy great, and dreadful Name,
Which holy is, be prais'd.
The King, in all his Strength, delights
In Judgment; he ordains
What's right; in Iacob, Justice he,
And Equity, maintains.
Iehovah, our great God, exalt,
And worshiping bow down;
Prostrate, before his Foot stool, fall,
For he's the holy One.
Moses, and A'ron, with his Priests,
Sam'el, with those addrest
His sacred Name, call'd on the Lord;
Who answer'd their Request.
God, from the Pillar of a Cloud,
Declar'd to them his Will;
Then they his Testimonies kept,
And Statutes did fullfill.
Thou answer'dst them, O Lord, our God;
Thy People for their Sake,
Forgavest oft, yet on their Works,
Did'st just Revenges take.
Therefore exalt the Lord, our God,
And in his Courts adore;
Because Iehovah, our great God
Is Holy evermore.

div.head: PSALM C.
div.l: SHout to Iehovah all the Earth;
Serve him with chearful, Heart and Voice;
Approach his House with sacred Mirth,
Before him triumph, and rejoice.
Know that Iehovah's God alone,
Who us and all did Being give;
We are his People, not our own,
The Sheep that on his Pastures live.
Enter his Gates with thankful Joy,
And, in his Courts, his Praise proclaim;
Your grateful Songs, in Thanks employ,
And ever bless his holy Name.
Because Iehovah he is good,
His Mercy is forever sure;
His Truth, thro' Ages past, has stood,
And shall, thro' ev'ry Age, endure.

div.head: PSALM C. 2d Meetre. as the old 122.
div.l: TO God, let all the Earth
Agree, with sacred Mirth,
In Shouts, to raise their chearful Voice.
With Gladness serve the Lord,
And come, with one Accord,
Before his Presence, and rejoice.
For this you can't but own,
Iehovah's God alone;
He Life and Breath, to all did give;
His People us he chose,
The Flock his Folds enclose,
And we on his fat Pastures live.
Enter his Gates with Joy,
In Thanks your Hearts employ,
And make his Courts resound his Fame;
Strike up a grateful Song,
From ev'ry Heart, and Tongue,
To bless his great, and holy Name.
Because the Lord is kind,
His Mercy, you shall find,
Is everlastingly secure;
His Truth, thro' Ages past,
Has stood unshaken fast,
And shall, thro' ev'ry Age, endure.

div.head: PSALM CI.
div.l: MErcy, and Judgment, claim my Song,
From Thee alone they spring:
Therefore, O Lord, my thankfull Heart
Thy Praise shall ever sing.
I'll wisely act, by perfect Rules,
When I the Crown receive;
The Pattern of an honest Heart,
To all my Court, I'll give.
No perverse Thing will I intend;
I hate their ill Design,
Who turn aside from sacred Laws▪
Their Works shall not be mine.
The froward, refractory Heart,
Shall from my Presence go;
With bad Men I'll no Friendship make,
Nor Favour to them show.
The private Sland'rer, I'll cut off,
Who seeks his Neighbour's Hurt;
The haughty Look, and proud in Heart,
I'll banish from my Court.
I'll search the Land for faithful Men,
That they may dwell with me;
And he that walks in perfect Ways,
My Favourite shall be.
But artful Men of Fraud, and Guile,
In my House shall not dwell;
Those that addict themselves to Lies,
I'll from my Sight repel.
My early Care shall be, to root
The Wicked from the Land;
That from thy City, Lord, I may
Cut off that impious Band.

div.head: PSALM CII.
div.l: JEhovah to my Pray'r attend;
Before Thee let my Cry ascend.
Hide not thy Face from me, while I,
Daily oppress'd, in Trouble ly:
Encline thine Ear to me, with Speed,
And Answer give, in Time of Need.
My Days, like Smoke, consume away;
Like the burnt Hearth my Bones decay.
My Heart, like Grass, that's smit with Heat,
Withers; that I forget to eat.
By Reason of my constant Groans,
I am reduc'd to Skin, and Bones.
I'm like the Pelican, and Owl,
That lonely, in the Deserts, strole.
As mournful Sparrow, percht alone
On the House Top, I watch, and moan.
My Foes, me daily, treat with Scorn;
Against me madly they have sworn.
I've eaten Ashes with my Bread;
And mix'd my Drink with Tears I shed,
For thou hast thy hot Anger shown,
In Wrath thou do'st upon me frown;
Thou first did'st lift me up on high,
Then down most low hast made me ly.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: My Days decline, like th'Ev'ning Shade;
Like wither'd Grass, my Strength's decay'd.
But thou, Lord, ever shalt endure;
Thy Mem'ry thro' all Ages sure.
Rise, Lord, for Sion's Help appear;
Th' appointed Time of Favour's near.
Thy Servants in her Stones delight;
Her Dust is precious in their Sight.
The Gentiles, Lord, thy Name shall fear;
Earth's Kings thy Glory shall revere.
When God shall Sion's State repair,
He'll shine most bright in Glory there.
The Poor's Request he'll then regard,
And their Petition shall be heard.
To future Ages this record;
That th' unborn Race may praise the Lord.
For he look'd down from's Throne on high;
The Lord from Heav'n the Earth did spy;
To hear the Pris'ners Groans; and give
Leave to the poor condemn'd to live:
In Sion, to declare his Name,
His Praise thro' Salem to proclaim;
When Isr'el there, with one Accord,
And Kingdoms meet, to serve the Lord.

div.head: Third PART.
div.l: My Strength he weaken'd in the Way;
And of my Life cut short the Day.
I said, my God, let not my Sun.
In Darkness, set, while yet 'tis Noon;
Thy Years, no run of Time can waste,
Which thro' all endless Ages last.
Thou first the Earth's Foundations laid;
The Heav'ns are Works thine Hands have made.
They perish shall, but thou shalt last;
They all, like Robes, decay, and waste;
Thou as a Vest shalt change them all;
And, at thy Word, be chang'd they shall.
But thou the same do'st still remain;
No Bounds thy endless Years restrain.
Thy Servants Race shall yet reside;
Their Seed, before Thee, fix'd abide.

div.head: PSALM CIII.
div.l: JOin all thy Powers, O my Soul,
God's holy Name to bless.
The Lord bless, O my Soul; forget
None of his Acts of Grace.
'Tis he doth all thy Sins forgive;
And Sicknesses remove.
He from the Grave redeems thy Life;
And crowns thee with his Love.
He fills thy Mouth with Good; thy Youth,
As th' Eagle's, he renews.
Judgment, and Justice, for th' Oppress'd,
The Lord himself pursues.
His Ways, to Moses, he made known;
His Acts to Isr'el's Race.
The Lord is good, and kind; he's slow
To Wrath, but full of Grace.
He will not always chide; nor mark
Forever, when we swerve.
He chastens not for ev'ry Crime;
For none as we deserve.
The Height of Heav'n's extended Arch,
Above this earthly Frame,
Is far • xceeded by his Grace,
To them that fear his Name.
Far as the East is from the West;
So far, his pard'ning Love
Doth, our Transgressions manifold,
Distant, from us, remove.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: A Father pities his young Son;
So doth the Lord the Just.
He knows how feeble is our Frame,
Remembers we are Dust.
Man's Days like Grass; he flourisheth,
As a Field-Flow'r new blown.
The Wind sweeps o'er, it disappears;
It's Place no more is known.
But, Lord, thy Mercy ever was,
And ever will endure,
To them that fear Thee; and thy Truth
To Children's Children's sure:
To such as keep his Covenant,
And his Commands obey.
The Lord, in Heav'n prepar'd his Throne;
O'er all extends his Sway.
Ye holy Angels, mighty Pow'rs,
Bless ye Iehovah still:
Who hear his Voice attentively,
And constant do his Will.
Bless God, his Hosts, and Ministers,
That do his Pleasure whole.
Thro' his wide Empire, bless the Lord;
The Lord bless, O my Soul.

div.head: PSALM CIV.
div.l: MY Soul, Iehovah bless; my God,
Thy Greatness knows no Bounds;
Unrivall'd Honours compass Thee,
Thee Majesty surrounds.
Who hast array'd thyself, with Light,
As with a splendid Robe;
The beauteous Heav'ns, thy royal Tent,
Hast stretch'd beyond the Globes.
His Palace Beams in fluid Air,
Who lays, and firmly binds;
The Clouds his Chariot form'd; and walks
On Wings of rapid Winds.
Spirits his Angels, Flames of Fire
His Ministers, he makes.
The Earth he founded on it's Base,
Which from it's Place ne'er shakes.
Thou, as a Garment, o'er the Earth,
Did'st spread the mighty Flood;
Above the Mountains loftiest Heads,
The rowling Waters stood.
At thy Rebuke, thy Thunder's Voice,
They hasted, and they fled;
The Mountains rose, the Valleys sunk;
To their appointed Bed.
Thou there, to Bounds unpassable,
Confin'st the wat'ry Main;
That it should never more return,
To cover Earth again.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: He sendeth Springs into the Vales;
Which from the Mountains burst.
There ev'ry Field-Beast drinks his Fill,
Wild Asses quench their Thirst.
The Birds dwell there; among the Sprigs,
They tune their chearful Voice.
The Hills he watereth from his Clouds;
Thy Fruits the Earth rejoice.
He makes the Grass to grow for Beasts,
And Herbs for Humane Use;
That he, abundant Food for all,
May from the Earth produce.
Thence springs the gen'rous Wine, rich Juice,
The Heart of Man, that chears;
The Oyl, which makes his Face to shine,
And Bread, which Strength repairs.
God's Trees abound with Sap; he set
Thy Cedars, Leb'non, there:
Where Birds do build their Nests; her House
The Stork makes in the Fir.
The wild Goats climb the craggy Hills,
And these their Refuge make:
While Rabbets, with the feebler Kind,
The Rocks for Shelter take.

div.head: Third PART.
div.l: He made the Moon for stated Times,
The Sun knows his fix'd Rout.
He Darkness makes, and it is Night;
Then Forest Beasts crawl out.
Young Lyons roar, and hunt their Prey;
From God they seek their Meat.
The Sun ariseth, they unite,
And close in Dens retreat.
Man to his Work, and Culture, goes,
Till th' Ev'ning gives him Rest.
How various, Lord! how wise thy Work!
Th' Earth's with thy Riches blest.
The Sea too, whose wide Arms contain
Numberless creeping Things;
With Animals, both small and great,
That swim by unknown Springs.
There pass the gallant Ships, which cut,
Thro' trackless Paths, their Way;
There huge Leviathan, thou mad'st;
Diverts himself with Play.
All wait on Thee, thou in due Time,
Dost give to each their Food:
They gather from thine open'd Hand,
And all are fill'd with Good.
If thy enliv'ning Face thou hid'st,
In deep Distress they mourn;
Thou tak'st away their Breath, they die,
And to their Earth return.
Thy quick'ning Spirit thou send'st forth,
And a new Life takes Place;
The Earth renew'd, with Vigour blooms,
And Beauty in her Face.

div.head: Fourth PART.
div.l: Iehovah's Glory shall endure,
Forevermore most bright.
When God reviews his various Works,
He's pleased with the Sight.
If he, upon this solid Earth,
But cast an angry Look,
It trembles; if he touch the Mounts,
They vanish into Smoke.
Unto Iehovah I will sing,
As long as I shall live;
While I my Breath, and Being, have,
Praise to my God I'll give.
This shall be grateful to the Lord,
To hear my thankful Voice;
While in Iehovah, and his Works,
I greatly will rejoice.
Let Sinners fail from off the Earth,
And th' Impious cease to be:
My Soul, bless thou the Lord, let all
To praise the Lord agree.

div.head: PSALM CV.
div.l: GIVE Thanks to God, call on his Name;
And make his Deeds to Nations known:
Sing ye, in sacred Hymns, his Praise;
Let all his wondrous Works be shown.
Praise in his holy Name; and let
Your Hearts rejoice, that seek the Lord.
Seek ye the Lord, his Strength, and Face;
Thus ever be the Lord ador'd.
Remember what great Works he wrought;
What Judgments from his Mouth proceed;
O ye his Servants, Abr'am's Race,
And ye his chosen Iacob's Seed.
He's 'specially the Lord, our God;
His Judgments thro' the Earth extend.
His Cov'nant firm has ever stood;
Nor shall a Thousand Ages End.
Which Cov'nant he with Abr'am made;
And with an Oath to Isaac swore:
With Iacob fix'd it for a Law,
And with his Heirs forevermore.
"Canaan, said he, to thee I'll give,
"The Lot your Children shall command:
When they, in Number, were but few,
Yea▪ few, and Strangers in the Land.
When they among the Nations went,
And still from Realm to Realm remov'd;
He suffer'd none to do them wrong;
Yea, Monarchs, for their Sakes, reprov'd.
Touch not, said he, my Servants dear,
Whom I've anointed by mine Arm;
And, at your Peril, see that ye,
Not, in the least, my Prophets harm.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: At length, a Famine thro' the Land,
He sent; which brake the Staff of Bread.
He first a Man, ev'n Ioseph, sent;
Who, sold a Slave, to Ham w • s led.
His Feet they hurt with heavy Chains;
It pierc'd his Soul to wound his Name.
Until the Time his Word took Place;
God's Word, which try'd, and clear'd his Fame.
The King his royal Edict gave,
To set him free from all his Bands.
He made him Lord of all his House;
And Ruler over all his Lands.
Princes at Pleasure to controul;
Wisely his Senators to guide.
Then Isr'el down to Egypt came;
Did there a Sojourner reside.
His People greatly he encreas'd,
And bless'd with num'rous Families:
He made them soon in Strength exceed
Their proud oppressing Enemies:
For he had turn'd their Hearts to hate
His People, they in Love receiv'd;
They sought his Servants to destroy,
Them oft by subtile Arts deceiv'd.

div.head: Third PART.
div.l: His Servant Moses then he sent,
With chosen A'ron, in his Name;
Confirm'd their Word, with pow'rful Signs,
And Wonders, in the Land of Ham.
Darkness he call'd, thick Darkness came;
Nature the sov'reign Orders knew.
He turn'd their Waters into Blood;
Which the amazed Fishes slew.
Their Land abundant Frogs produc'd;
Which climb'd the Chambers of their Kings.
He spake, came Swarms of diverse Flies;
Dust, thro' their Land, to Lice up springs.
For Rain, he pour'd down Storms of Hail;
And flaming Fire their Land annoy'd.
Their fruitful Vines, and Fig-Trees, smote;
And, thro' their Coasts, their Trees destroy'd.
Locusts, and various Reptiles came,
At his Command; their Swarms abound.
Each green Herb, thro' the Land, they eat;
And naked left the fruitless Ground.
Then, by one fat • l Mid-night Stroke,
Which, thro' each Town, and Village, flew,
He all their First-born sudden smote;
The Flow'r of all their Strength he slew.

div.head: Fourth PART.
div.l: With Gold and Silver Spoils, he brought,
Them, forth from Egypt's hated Ground;
None feeble, in their num'rous Tribes;
No, not so much as one was found.
Egypt rejoic'd, when they with-drew;
For on them seized Isr'el's Dread.
A cov'ring Cloud he spread, by Day;
And Fire, by Night, their Marches led.
They ask'd; he bro't sweet Quails; & they,
With Bread from Heav'n, were satisfy'd.
He clave the Rock; the Waters gush'd,
And Rivers in dry Land supply'd.
On's Promise, made to Abraham,
Bound by his Holiness, he thought.
With Joy his People, his Elect,
With Songs of Triumph, forth he brought▪
To them he gave the Heathen's Soil,
Ev'n promis'd Canaan's fertile Lands;
The People's Labours they enjoy'd,
All built, and planted, to their Hands.
That thus oblig'd, his Statutes they
Might carefully observe always;
And ne'er forget to keep his Laws:
Therefore let all Iehovah praise.

div.head: PSALM CVI.
div.l: PRaise ye the Lord, give Thanks to him
He's good; his Mercy ne'er decays.
Who can his mighty Acts declare?
Or who can shew forth all his Praise?
Blessed are they that keep his Laws;
And always do the Thing that's right.
Think on me Lord, and Favour me,
As one in whom thou dost delight.
With thy Salvation visit me,
To see thy Chosen's good Advance;
That I thy Nations Joy may share,
Glory with thine Inheritance.
We, from our Fathers Days, have err'd,
And, like them, from thy Paths have gone;
Our Deeds have been perversly wrong,
Against thee impiously we've done.
Thy Wonders, they in Egypt saw,
Our Fathers did not understand;
Thy many Mercies they forgot,
Provok'd Thee, at the Red Sea's strand.
Yet them he sav'd, for his Name's sake;
The Fame of's mighty Pow'r to spread.
He check'd the Sea, and up it dry'd;
And them, thro' Deeps, as Plains, he led.
So, from the Malice of their Foes,
Who close pursu'd, he them did save;
And from their En'mies 'vengeful Arm,
To them compleat Redemption gave.
But o'er their Foes the Waters rowl'd;
Not one of them escap'd alive.
Then they, a while, believ'd his Word,
And Praise, in Songs, to him did give.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: But soon they all his Works forgot;
Nor would they for his Counsel wait.
They lusted in the Wilderness;
And tempted God, by asking Meat.
He granted their too rash Request;
But Leanness in their Soul was thrown.
They envy'd Moses in the Camp,
And A'ron God's choice holy one.
The gaping Earth Dathan devour'd;
Clos'd on Abiram's factious Crew.
The Fire on their Companions seiz'd;
The Flame their bold Abettors slew.
Then they a Calf, in Horeb made;
And did the Idol Homage pay:
Their Glory, to the Likeness, chang'd,
Of a dull Ox, that eateth Hay.
Their God, and Saviour, they forgot;
Who had, in Egypt great Things done:
Wrought Wonders, in the Land of Ham;
His Terrors, by the Red Sea, shown.
He said, he would destroy them quite;
But Moses, then, before him stood,
And fill'd the Breach, to turn his Wrath;
Lest he his Threat'ning should make good.
Yea; they the pleasant Land despis'd;
And gave no Credit to his Word:
But murmur'd in their Tents; nor heard
The Voice of their most gracious Lord.
Then sware he, there, they ne'er should come;
But perish in the Desert Sands:
Nations should prey upon their Seed,
And scatter them in distant Lands.

div.head: Third PART.
div.l: Yea, they to Baal-Peor· joyn'd;
And eat the Off'rings of the dead.
These Works did so provoke his Wrath,
The dreadful Plague among them spread.
Then Phineas rose, and Judgment wro't;
The Plague was stay'd, the guilty slain.
This Justice was in him esteem'd;
His Race the high Rewards did gain.
They anger'd him, at Meribah;
That Moses suffer'd for their Sake.
For they hi • Spirit so provok'd,
With unadvised • ips he spake.
The Nations they did not destroy;
As God had given them Command.
But mingled with the Heathen were,
And learnt the Manners of their Land.
Yea, their vain Idol Gods they serv'd;
Which them, in woful Mischief, snar'd.
In Sacrifice to Daemons, they,
Their Offspring, cruelly prepar'd.
And guiltless Blood they shed; the Blood
Of their own Sons, and Daughters, slain
In Sacrifice to Canaan's Gods;
The Gore did the whole Land distain.
Thus greatly were their Souls defil'd,
While they on their own Works were bent;
After their own Inventions, they,
With lustful Hearts, a whoring went.

div.head: Fourth PART.
div.l: For this, against his People, flam'd,
The Indignation of the Lord;
That those who, his Inheritance,
Before had been, he now abhor'd.
He gave them up to heathen Pow'rs;
Their Haters rul'd with Rods of Steel.
Their Foes then greatly them oppress'd▪
And made them subject to their Will.
He sav'd them oft, but they as oft,
Thro' their bad Counsels, did rebell,
And mov'd his Wrath; until, beneath
The Weight of their own Crimes, they fell.
Yet, in the Time of their Distress,
His kind Regards to them were shown;
His Bowels with Compassion mov'd,
When e'er he heard their piteous Moan.
His Cov'nant he recall'd to Mind;
In his great Goodness did relent.
He made them pitied be of all,
Where they, as Captives had been sent.
Now save thou us, O Lord, our God,
And from among the Heathen bring;
That we may thank thine holy Name,
And Songs of Praises to Thee sing.
Bless'd be Iehovah, Isr'el's God,
Eternally; with one Accord,
Let all the People hearty join,
And say, Amen. Praise ye the Lord.

div.head: PSALM CVII. FIFTH BOOK. To Travellers.
div.l: GIVE Thanks to God, for he is good
His Mercy ever flows.
So let the Lord's Redeemed say,
Whom he releast from Foes;
And gather'd them from foreign Lands,
From North, South, East, and West.
They strol'd thro' Desert's untrod Ways;
And found no Place of Rest.
Hunger, and Thirst, their fainting Souls
Did grievously oppress.
To God, in Trouble, then they cry'd,
Who freed them from Distress.
He led them forth in a right Way,
And was their faithful Guide;
Till they arriv'd at Cities, where
Their Wants were all supply'd.
Let all with Thanks, Iehovah praise,
And make his Goodness known;
For he among the Sons of Men,
Works wonderful hath done.
The strong Desire of longing Souls
He kindly satisfies;
With Fruits of his Benignity,
The hungry Soul supplies.

div.head: Second PART. To Prisoners.
div.l: Who • it in Darkness, and Death's Shade,
With Grief, and Chains, bow'd down:
Because God's Word, and Council they
Dispis'd, and would not own:
He humbled their proud Hearts with Toil,
They fell, and none could save.
To God, in Trouble, then they cry'd,
And he Deliv'rance gave.
Their Darkness, & Death's Shade, he chang'd
To Light, by his kind Word;
He broke their gauling Bands in Twain,
And Liberty restor'd.
Let all, with Thanks Iehovah praise
And make his Goodness known;
For he, among the Sons of Men,
Works wonderful hath done.
For by his Strength, the Gates of Brass
Are into Pieces broke;
The massy Bars of Iron are cut,
Asunder by his Stroke.

div.head: Third PART. To the Sick.
div.l: Fools rashly break thro' sacred Laws,
To gratify their Sense;
Till with Diseases they're chastis'd,
To punish their Offence.
Their Soul a painful Loathing feels
To ev'ry Kind of Meat;
And they, their near Approaches make
To Death's unfriendly Gate.
To God, in Trouble, then they cry;
Who their Distress relieves.
His sov'reign Word their Sickness heals,
And them from Death reprieves.
Let all, with Thanks, Iehovah praise,
And make his Goodness known;
For he among the Sons of Men,
Works wonderful hath done.
To him, let all their Sacrifice,
With thankful Hearts, be brought;
Declare with Joy, to all the World,
What God, for them, hath wrought.

div.head: Fourth PART. To Mariners.
div.l: Who sail in Ships o'er mighty Seas,
And hope great Gain to reap:
These do behold Iehovah's Works;
His Wonders in the Deep.
He speaks; and stormy Winds arise;
Like Mounts, the Billows rear.
To Heav'n they climb, then sink in Gulphs;
Their Soul dissolves with Fear.
They reel, and stagger, Drunkard like▪
Terrors their Minds oppress.
To God in Trouble, then they cry,
Who frees them from Distress.
He stills the Winds, and calms the Seas,
And quells their rougher Sport.
They're glad of Rest; he brings them safe
To their desired Port.
Let all, with Thanks, Iehovah praise,
And make his Goodness known;
For he, among the Sons of Men,
Works wonderful hath done.
Let them, in private Companies,
His Honour highly raise;
And where th' assembled Elders meet,
Unite to spread his Praise.

div.head: Fifth PART. To Planters.
div.l: Rivers he turns to Desert Sands;
And dries the Fountains Heads.
Provok'd by daring Crimes, with Salt,
The fruitful Soil he spreads.
He turns the Desert into Pools;
Dry Ground, a springing Well.
The Hungry there he seats, who build.
A City where they dwell.
They sow their Fields, and Vineyards plant,
Which bring encreased Stocks.
His Blessing multiplies their Race;
Nor lessens he their Flocks.
But when they sin, they're greatly thinn'd,
And soon brought low again;
By foreign, and domestick Ills,
Oppress'd, and fill'd with Pain.
On Princes, who provoke his Wrath,
He pours Contempt, and Scorn;
He makes them traverse trackless Wastes,
Unpity'd, and forlorn.
The humble Poor he seats on high,
And doth from Trouble keep;
He makes his Families encrease,
Like fruitful Flocks of Sheep.
The Just shall see, and shall rejoice;
But th' Impious silent grow.
The Wise will these Events observe;
And God's great Goodness know.

div.head: PSALM CVIII.
div.l: O GOD, my Heart is fix'd;
My Tongue shall sing thy Praise.
Awake both Psaltery, and Harp;
Myself I'll early raise.
Among the People, Lord,
I'll praise thy glorious Name;
And to the Nations round about,
I'll sing, and spread thy Fame.
Thy Mercy, Lord, the Heav'ns,
Thy Truth, the Clouds, transcend.
O let thy Glory, Heav'ns above,
And o'er the Earth, extend.
That thy Beloved, still,
Deliverance may have;
O hear the fervent Pray'rs I make,
And let thy Right-Hand save.
God spake in's Holiness,
My Joy's it cannot fail;
Fair Shechem's Soil, I will divide,
And meet out Succoth's Vale.
Gilead is on my Side▪
Manassah owns my Cause;
Ephr'im's large Tribe's my chiefest Strength,
And Iudah gives forth Laws.
Moab shall wash my Feet,
O'er Edom I will tread;
The proud Philistian Lords shall stoop,
And to my Triumphs add.
Who to the City strong,
And Edom's Tow'rs shall lead?
Lord, wilt not thou, who cast us off,
Our Armies now succeed?
From Trouble give us Help,
Man's Help is vain we own.
Thro' God, we shall do valiant Acts;
'Tis he, our Foes treads down.

div.head: PSALM CIX.
div.l: GOD of my Praise, hold not thy Peace.
For open'd, to my Wrong,
Are wicked, and deceitful, Mouths;
Which speak with lying Tongue.
Words full of Hatred they throw round;
Causeless my Life ensnare.
They, for my Love, my Foes, become;
But I resort to Pray'r.
They have rewarded me with Ill,
For all the Good I've done;
And for my undisguised Love,
Have cruel Hatred shown.
And close at his Right-hand,
To •••• rmine his dang'rous Plots,
〈◊〉 Adversary stand.
When judg'd, he shall be guilty found,
His very Pray'r displease.
His Days be few, and on his Charge,
Shall then another seize.
His Children Orphans, and his Wife
A Widow shall be made.
His Offspring shall from Ruins creep,
And strole, and beg their Bread.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Gripers shall seize on all was his;
Strangers his Labours rend.
None shall their Pity to him show,
Nor to his Seed extend.
His Race shall cease, and the next Age,
Their Names be quite forgot.
The Lord shall mind his Father's Crimes;
Nor out his Mother's blot.
They shall continually appear
Before Iehovah's Face;
'Till he, from off the burden'd Earth,
Their Memory erace.
Because it ne'er came in his Mind;
Compassion to impart;
The Poor, and Needy, he pursu'd,
To slay the broken Heart.
As he lov'd Cursing, it shall come,
And fall on his own Head;
The Blessing, he despis'd, shall far
Away from him be fled.
Since Cursing, as a Robe, he wore,
It shall, like Water, flow
Thro' all his Bowels; and in his Bones,
Like piercing Oil, shall go.
As Garments, it shall cover him;
As Girdles him controul.
Thus will the Lord reward my Foes;
Who speak against my Soul.

div.head: Third PART.
div.l: But thou, O God, the Lord, deal well,
For thy Name's Sake, with me;
Because thy Mercy's very great,
Appear, and set me free.
For I am poor, and destitute;
My Heart, with Grief, doth swoon.
I pass, like Ev'ning-Shades; I'm tost,
Like Locusts, up and down.
My Knees, with Fasting, weak are grown;
Fat from my Flesh is fled.
I'm their Reproach; and when they look
On me, they shake the Head.
Help me, O Lord, my God, save me;
And make thy Mercy known.
That all may see, this is thy Hand;
Thou, Lord, this Thing hast done.
Let them curse on; but, Lord, bless thou;
And when they raise their Voice
With Insult, let them be asham'd;
Thy Servant let rejoice.
May all my Foes be cloath'd with Shame,
To see their Measures broke;
And, in their own Confusion, wrapt
Around, as with a Cloak.
So will I greatly praise the Lord,
And with my Mouth aloud;
My grateful Thanks I'll to him sing,
Among the Multitude.
Because the Lord, at their Right-hand,
Will stand, to help the Poor;
To save him from th' unrighteous Judge,
Who would his Soul devour.

div.head: PSALM CX.
div.l: JEhovah said unto my Lord,
"Sit thou enthron'd at my Right-hand;
"Till I thy Foes thy Foot-stool make,
"And them subject to thy Command.
The Lord, from sacred Sion's Seat,
The Scepter of thy Strength, shall send;
Thence, in the Midst of all thy Foes,
Thy conquering Pow'r shall wide extend.
Thy People, that victorious Day,
Adorn'd with Holiness thy Seed,
As Dew from Morning's Womb, shall spread.
Iehovah, by himself, hath sworn,
An Oath which he will never break;
"Thou art an everlasting Priest,
"Of th' Order of Melchisedeck.
The Lord, who is at thy Right-hand,
Shall, in the Day of Vengeance smite,
The greatest Monarchs on the Earth,
Who dare his Government to slight.
He shall among the Heathen judge,
And with dead Bodies fill their Plains;
He'll sorely wound the potent Head,
Who over many Nations reigns.
The Torrent he shall stoop to drink,
While he the glorious Way shall tread;
Then, as Reward of all his Pains,
To endless Glories raise his Head.

div.head: PSALM CXI.
div.l: PRaise ye the Lord, with my whole Heart,
I will Iehovah praise;
With private Friends, and the whole Choir,
Who tread his righteous Ways.
God's Works are great; sought out by all
Who Pleasure in them taste.
They glorious shine; his Righteousness
Forever more shall last.
His Wonder's fix'd Memorial shows
The Lord is Good, and kind.
To them that fear him, he gave Food;
His Cov'nant keeps in Mind.
He shew'd his People, by his Works,
The Pow'r of his Right-hand;
To give them, for an Heritage,
The Heathen's promis'd Land.
His Works are all most true, and just,
All his Commands shall last.
They're done in Truth, and Righteousness,
And stand forever fast.
His People he Redemption sent;
His Cov'nant with the same,
He fix'd forever; reverend,
And holy is his Name.
Iehovah's Fear true Wisdom is;
They heav'nly Skill procure,
Who his Commands observe; his Praise
Forever shall endure.

div.head: PSALM CXII. Hallelujah.
div.l: THAT Man is bless'd, who fears the Lord,
And in his Law takes great delight.
His Seed, on Earth, shall mighty be;
Bless'd shall the Race be of th' Upright.
His House, with Plenty, shall abound;
His Justice no Decays shall find.
His Light, in Darkness, shall arise;
He's just, compassionate, and kind.
A good Man Favour shows, and lends;
And his Affairs, with Prudence, guides.
Surely, he never shall be mov'd;
Forever sweet his Name abides.
Fearless, he evil Tidings hears;
His Heart is fix'd, on God relies.
Secur'd from Fear, he waits to see,
Just Vengeance, on his Enemies.
His lib'ral Hand dispers'd his Alms,
And gave the Poor a meet Supply;
His Justice ever shall be prais'd,
His Horn, in Glory, rais'd on high.
The Wicked this shall see, and grieve,
Gnash with his Teeth, and melt away;
While their Unjust, and base Designs,
Blasted, shall utterly decay.

div.head: PSALM CXII. 2 d Meetre.
div.l: COme, let us praise the Lord:
He's bless'd the Lord that fears;
Whose Heart the greatest Love,
To his Commandments bears.
His Seed renown'd,
On Earth, shall be;
His Progeny
With Blessings crown'd.
His House with Wealth shall flow;
His Justice never fails.
The Light shall on him shine,
When Darkness most prevails.
His gentle Mind
The Poor's Grief feels,
He justly deals
With all Mankind.
A good Man Favour shows,
And lends, nor hopes for Gain;
His Business wisely guides;
He shall unmov'd remain:
The just Man's Name,
With Fragrance, shall,
Thro' Ages all,
Still live in Fame.
No evil Tidings shall,
His Mind, with Fear, surprize,
His Heart is firmly fix'd,
And on the Lord relies:
With sweet Repose,
Fearless, to see
The high Decree,
Seize on his Foes.
He wide dispers'd his Alms,
And gave the Poor Supplies;
His Righteousness shall last,
His Horn, in Glory, rise.
Sinners shall see,
Grieve, gnash, and pine,
But their Design
Shall blasted be.

div.head: PSALM CXIII.
div.l: YE Servants of th' Almighty King,
Your joyful Hallelujah's sing,
With Praise his glorious Name confess.
Now raise your Hearts, as heretofore,
Till Time itself shall be no more▪
Iehovah's sacred Name to bless.
From the first Rising of the Sun,
Unto it's latest going down,
Iehovah's Name is to be prais'd.
For o'er all Nations is his Sway;
Above the Realms of endless Day,
Iehovah's Glory's highly rais'd.
Who, like the Lord, our God, excells?
He in the highest Heav'n dwells:
Who condescends, when he surveys
The Heav'n, and Earth, with all their Host;
He lifts the Poor out of the Dust.
From Dunghills doth the Needy raise.
That him, with Princes, he might seat;
With his own People's Princes great.
To equal Dignity might bring.
The Barren he confines at Home,
A joyful Mother to become.
O therefore Hallelujah sing.

div.head: PSALM CXIII. 2d Meetre.
div.l: PRaise ye the Lord; his Servants, praise,
His sacred Name adore.
Oh! blessed be Iehovah's Name,
Both now, and evermore.
From the Sun's Rising, to it's Fall,
The Lord's Name's to be prais'd.
The Lord all Nations rules, above
The Heav'ns his Glory's rais'd.
Who's like the Lord, our God, who sits
Enthron'd above the Sky?
He condescends, on Things in Heav'n,
And Earth, to cast his Eye.
The Poor he raiseth from the Dust.
From Dunghills Needy brings:
Ranks them with Princes, o'er his Tribes,
Seats them on Thrones of Kings.
The Barren he confines at Home,
Her Offspring to afford
A joyful Mother's tender Care.
Sing Praises to the Lord.

div.head: PSALM CXIV.
div.l: WHEN Isr'el was from Egypt freed,
And from strange Language Iacob's Seed;
Then Iudah bore his sacred Name,
And King in Isr'el he became.
The Sea saw this; amazed fled;
Iordan drove backward to it's Head.
The Mountains skipt about, like Rams;
The little Hills, like frighted Lambs.
What ail'd thee, O thou roaring Sea,
That thou, in such a Fright, did'st flee?
Wherefore old Iordan, did thy Tide,
Rowl back, and to it's Fountain glide?
What Terrors, ye fixt Mountains, struck;
That ye, like Rams, so skip't and shook?
Why leap't ye little Hills, like Lambs,
That fly for Shelter to their Dams?
Well may the Mounts, and ev'ry Flood,
Bow, and retire, before their God.
Tremble, O all the Earth, with Fear;
Iehovah, Iacob's God, is here.
Who, b • his Pow'r, the Rocks can brake,
From flinty dry Rocks, by a Word,
Fountains of Waters can afford.

div.head: PSALM CXV.
div.l: NOT unto us, Lord; not to us,
But Glory to thy Name
We render; for thy matchless Grace,
And Truth, this Homage claim.
Why should the Heathen scornful say,
"Where is their God now gone?
Our God, in Heaven, sits enthron'd,
And what he pleas'd hath done.
Their Idols Silver are, and Gold;
By humane Hands design'd.
They're form'd with Shapes of Mouth and Eyes;
But speechless are, and blind.
Their Ears, and Nose, hear not, nor smell:
Nor feel they with their Hands.
Tho' they have Feet, they cannot walk;
Nor Speech their Throat command • .
Those Men that make such Idol Gods,
And trusting to them pray;
Like them are blind, and senseless grown.
And stupid too as they.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: O Isr'el, trust thou in the Lord;
He is their Help, and Shield.
O A'ron's House, in God confide▪
Who only Help can yield.
All ye, who do Iehovah fear,
Upon the Lord depend;
'Tis he, that will your Keeper be,
And as a Shield defend.
The Lord hath former Kindness shown,
And still will do no less;
He Isr'el's Tribes, and A'ron's House,
Assuredly will bless.
To all that fear him, small, and great,
He'll manifest his Grace.
The Lord will more and more encrease
You, and your happy Race.
Ye are the blessed of the Lord;
Who Heav'n, and Earth, hath made.
The Lord doth Heav'n of Heav'ns possess,
But th' Earth to Men convey'd.
The dead, and who to Silence go,
No Praise to God afford.
But we will bless the Lord, both now,
And ever. Praise the Lord.

div.head: PSALM CXVI.
div.l: I Love the Lord, who heard the Voice
Of my Requests for Grace.
Because he bow'd to me his Ear,
I'll pray, thro' all my Days.
Sorrows intense, like Bands of Death,
Encompass'd me around;
The Grave's strong Terrors seiz'd on me,
Distress, and Grief, I found.
Then on Iehovah's Name I call'd,
In this most fervent Speech;
"Deliver thou my Soul, O Lord,
"I humbly Thee beseech.
The Lord is kind, and just from him,
Our God, all Mercies flow.
He keeps the harmless; he me help'd,
When I was very low.
Return, my Soul, unto thy Rest,
The Lord dealt well with thee.
For thou hast from the Snares of Death,
My trembling Soul set free;
My Feet from Falls, thou hast preserv'd,
And wip'd mine Eyes from Tears.
I'll walk before Iehovah's Face,
Thro' all my coming Years.
I did believe, and therefore spake;
Tho' I was greatly griev'd.
And, in my Consternation, said,
I am by all deceiv'd.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: What shall I render to the Lord,
Whence all my Mercies came?
Salvation's Cup I'll take, and call
Upon Iehovah's Name.
My Vows to God, before his Saints,
I'll pay with great Delight.
The Death of all his holy ones,
Is precious in his Sight.
I am thy Servant, Lord, I'm thine,
Devoted to thy Use;
Thine humble Hand-maids Son, my Bonds
Thou kindly did'st unloose.
Off'rings of Praise I'll bring to Thee,
And on the Lord's Name call.
My Vows I'll pay Iehovah, now,
Before his People all.
Within his sacred Courts, where they
Their grateful Voices raise;
In Midst of Thee, Ierusalem,
Let all Iehovah praise.

div.head: PSALM CXVII.
div.l: LET all the Nations, thro' the Earth,
To praise the Lord combine;
Let ev'ry Tribe, and ev'ry Tongue,
In Hymns of Praises, join.
Because his Grace to us abounds,
And runs forever free;
Iehovah's Truth shall ne'er decay:
Therefore the Lord praise ye.

div.head: PSALM CXVII. 2d Meetre.
div.l: YE Nations ev'ry where,
Of Iew, or Gentile, Line,
To praise Iehovah's Name,
With Hearts, and Voices join:
With sacred Mirth,
His Praise be sung,
By ev'ry Tongue,
Thro'out the Earth.
Because his matchless Grace,
In Pity to us, flows;
The inexhausted Store
No narrow Limits knows;
Iehovah's Word
Shall still endure
Forever sure.
Praise ye the Lord.

div.head: PSALM CXVIII.
div.l: GIVE Thanks to God, for he is good;
His Mercy's ever sure.
Let Israel's Tribes now say, his Grace
Forever shall endure.
His Clemency forever lasts,
Let A'ron's House now say.
Let them that 〈◊〉 the Lord declare
His Mercy 'll ne'e • decay.
In my Distress I call'd on God,
Whose Answer 〈…〉 .
The Lord's with me, and I'll not fear,
What Man can do to me.
〈…〉 take my Part,
With those my Cause espouse;
And I shall see a just Reward
O'ertake my envious Foes.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: 'Tis better far to trust in God,
Than upon Man rely.
'Tis safer trusting in the Lord,
Than Princes, e'er so high.
All Nations compass me about:
Yea oft beset me round;
But in Iehovah's Name, and Help,
I smote them to the Ground.
Like Swarms of Bees, they buz'd about▪
And rag'd, like crackling Fire
Of Thorns; but aided by my God,
They're quench'd, and soon expire.
They press'd me hard, to cause my Fall
But God did Succour bring.
From God, my Strength, & Safety, flows;
And I'll his Praises sing.
The just Man's Tent is fill'd with Joy,
And safe in God's Right-hand.
The Lord's Right-hand on high is rais'd,
And Vict'ry doth command.
I shall not die, but live to praise
God's Wonders, with my Breath.
The Lord hath sorely chasten'd me,
But gave me not to Death.

div.head: Third PART.
div.l: Open the Gates of Righteousness,
And I will enter in;
That I may sing Iehovah's Praise,
Who hath my Saviour been.
This Gate's the Lord's▪ whither the Just
Shall enter, on set Days.
Since thou hast heard, and set me safe,
I'll give to thee the Praise.
That Stone which Builders did reject,
Chief Corner-Stone now lyes.
This Work is from the Lord alone;
'Tis wondrous in our Eyes.
This is the Day the Lord hath made;
We'll it with Joy attend.
Save now, O Lord, I Thee beseech
Prosperity now send.
Hosannah! bless'd is he that comes,
In great Iehovah's Name;
A Blessing, from God's holy House,
To you, we loud proclaim.
God is Iehovah; who to us,
Light graciously affords;
Bind to the sacred Altar's Horns,
The Sacrifice with Cords.
Thou art my God, and I'll thee praise;
My God, I'll spread thy Fame.
O bless the Lord, for he is good;
His Mercy's still the same.

div.head: PSALM CXIX. ALEPH.
div.l: THrice bless'd are th' undefil'd in Way;
Who walk as God's Commands require.
Blessed are they that keep his Laws;
Who seek him with their whole Desire.
For they work no Iniquity;
Who in his Ways close Walkers are.
Thou hast commanded us to keep
Thy Precepts, with our utmost Care.
Oh! that to keep thy Statutes, Lord,
Thou all my Ways would'st well direct!
Then shall I have no Cause of Shame;
When I all thy Commands respect.
With Heart's Uprightness, I'll thee praise▪
When I shall learn thy Judgments right,
I'll keep thy Statutes with great Care:
Oh! do not thou forsake me quite!

div.head: Second PART. BETH.
div.l: How shall a young Man cleanse his Way!
Let him, thy Word, with Care, observe.
With my whole Heart, I Thee have sought;
From thy Commands let me not swerve.
I've hid thy Word within my Heart;
Lest I should give Offence to Thee.
For ever bless'd art thou, O Lord,
Thy righteous Statutes teach thou me.
I all the Judgments of thy Mouth
Have, with my Lips, declar'd aright.
I, in thy Testimonies Way,
More than all Riches, take Delight.
Thy Precepts I will bear in Mind;
And have Respect unto thy Ways.
Thy Statutes, my Delight, shall be;
I'll not forget what thy Word says.

div.head: Third PART. GIMEL.
div.l: In Kindness, with thy Servant deal;
That I may live, and keep thy Word.
Open mine Eyes; that I may see,
The Wonders which thy Laws afford.
I'm but a Stranger, on the Earth;
Hide not thy wise Commands from me.
My Soul doth faint, with strong Desire,
Still with thy Judgments to agree.
The Proud thou hast rebuk'd; they're curs'd,
Who from thy Precepts boldly swerv'd.
Shame, and Contempt, remove from me;
Thy Testimonies I observ'd.
Tho' Princes met, and me defam'd;
Thy Statutes I my Study make.
Thy Records are my chief Delight:
Them for my Counsellors I take.

div.head: Fourth PART. DALETH.
div.l: My Soul cleaves fast unto the Dust;
Raise me, according to thy Word.
I shew'd my Ways, thou answer'dst me;
Thy righteous Statutes teach me, Lord.
Make me to know thy Precept's Way;
Thy Wonders then I will declare.
My Soul with melting Grief dissolves;
O let thy Word my Strength repair.
Remove from me each lying Way;
Grant me thy Laws diviner Aid.
For I have chose the Way of Truth;
Thy Judgments I've before me laid.
I to thy Testimonies cleave;
Me from all Shame, O Lord, discharge.
I'll run the Way of thy Commands;
When thou my Heart shalt free enlarge.

div.head: Fifth PART. HE.
div.l: Teach me, O Lord, thy Statutes Way;
And I shall from it ne'er depart.
Instruct me, and I'll keep thy Law▪
I'll it observe with all my Heart.
Me in the Path of thy Commands;
Conduct, for I delight therein.
My Heart unto thy just Records;
And not to Avarice encline.
From all vain Objects turn mine Eyes;
Me in thy Way revive, and chear.
Confirm thy Word thy Servant to;
Who is devoted to thy Fear.
The fear'd Reproach from me remove;
Good are the Judgments thou do'st give;
Lo! how I long for thy Commands▪
Me in thy Righteousness revive.

div.head: Sixth PART. VAU.
div.l: Let Mercies and Salvation, come
To me; as thou hast spoken, Lord.
So shall I answer his Reproach;
For I rely upon thy Word.
Take not thy Word quite from my Mouth;
For on thy Judgments I depend.
So I will ever keep thy Law;
With Constancy, unto the End.
Freed from Restraints, I'll walk at large;
For thy Commands I closely seek.
Boldly, before the greatest Kings,
I'll of thy Testimonies speak.
In thy Commands, which I have lov'd;
Myself, with Joy, I'll recreate.
To thy lov'd Laws I'll stretch my Hands;
And on thy Statutes meditate.

div.head: Seventh PART. ZAIN.
div.l: The Word, unto thy Servant; mind;
On which thou'st kept my Hope alive.
This is my Comfort in Distress;
Because thy Word doth me revive.
The Proud did greatly me deride;
Yet from thy Law I've not declin'd.
Thy ancient Judgments I recall;
O Lord; and solid Comfort find.
I'm struck with Horror, to behold,
How impious Men thy Law forsake.
I, in my House of Pilgrimage,
My chearfull Songs thy Statutes make.
I've kept thy Law; for I recall'd,
Thy Name, O Lord, to Mind by Night.
This, by Experience taught, I had;
Because I kept thy Precepts right.

div.head: Eighth PART. CHETH.
div.l: My Portion thou, Iehovah, art;
I said, that I will keep thy Word.
With all my Heart I sought thy Face;
Thy promis'd Mercy me afford.
I view'd my Ways; and turn'd my Feet
Unto thy Testimonies Way.
I hasted, and deferred not,
All thy Commandments to obey.
By wicked Troops I have been rob'd;
Thy Laws I think on with Delight.
I'll rise at Mid-night Thee to praise;
Because thy Judgments all are right.
Companion to them all am I,
That fear Thee, and thy Precepts keep.
Earth, Lord, is with thy Goodness fill'd;
Teach me thy Statutes, wondrous deep.

div.head: Ninth PART. TETH.
div.l: Thou well with me, O Lord, hast dealt:
As thy Word promis'd, I've receiv'd.
Good Judgment give, and Knowledge teach;
For thy Commands I have believ'd.
Before I was chastis'd I err'd;
But now to keep thy Word I learn.
Thou, Lord, art good, and good thou do'st;
Thy Statutes make me to discern.
The Proud have Lies against me forg'd;
Thy Law I've kept with my Heart's might,
Their Heart, with Fat, is stupid grown;
But in thy Law I take Delight.
It's good for me I've felt thy Rod;
That right thy Statutes I might hold.
Laws of thy Mouth I more have priz'd,
Than Silver Heaps, and Mines of Gold.

div.head: Tenth PART. JOD.
div.l: Thy Hands have made, and strengthen'd me;
Skill, thy Commands to learn, afford.
Who fear Thee me shall see with Joy;
Because I've hoped in thy Word.
Thy Judgments, Lord, I know are just:
In Faithfulness thou chasten'st me.
I pray thy promis'd Kindness may,
Thy Servant's future Comfort, be.
Shew me thy Grace, that I may live:
For in thy Law, Delight I find.
Shame proud ones who me causeless harm:
Thy Precepts I will bear in mind.
Let them, that fear Thee, turn to me:
And those thy Testimonies know.
Sound in thy Statutes make my Heart;
That Shame may not me overthrow.

div.head: Eleventh PART. CAPH.
div.l: My Soul, for thy Salvation, faints;
Thy Word fullfill'd, I hope to see.
My longing Eyes for thy Word fail;
Saying, when wilt thou comfort me?
I'm like a Bottle in the Smoke;
Yet do not I thy Laws forget.
What are my Days? when wilt thou judge,
Those that in Malice me beset.
The Proud for me have digged Pits▪
Who with thy Law do not agree.
Faithful are all of thy Commands;
They rage unjustly, help thou me.
On Earth they almost me consum'd:
But thy Commands I ne'er forsook.
In Mercy me revive; that I
May keep the Laws thy Mouth has spoke.

div.head: Twelfth PART. LAMED.
div.l: Thy Word, O Lord, in Heav'n is fix'd,
Unchang'd forever to endure.
Thy Truth thro'out all Ages lasts;
Thou found'st the Earth, and it stands sure.
They still remain as thou ordain'st;
For all thy ready Servants are.
Had not thy Law been my Delight;
I'd long since perish'd in Dispair.
Thy Precepts I will ne'er forget;
Thou me new Life, by them, hast brought.
I am entirely thine, save me;
For I've thy Precepts daily sought.
The Wicked watch me to destroy;
But I'll thy Testimonies mind.
Of all Perfection th' End I see;
Exceeding broad thy Law I find.

div.head: Thirteenth PART. MEM.
div.l: Oh! how I love thy sacred Law!
It daily my sweet Study grows.
By thy Word, ever with me, thou
Hast made me wiser than my Foes.
More than my Teachers all I know;
For I thy Statutes closely weigh'd.
Than ancient Sages more I see;
Because thy Precepts I obey'd.
From all ill Paths I have refrain'd
My Feet; that I might keep thy Word.
I have not from thy Judgments stray'd;
Because 'tis thou hast taught me Lord.
How sweet thy Words are to my Taste!
Than Honey sweeter to my Mouth!
I, by thy Precepts, Wisdom gain;
And hate the Ways that swerve from Truth.

div.head: Fourteenth PART. NUN.
div.l: Thy Word's a Lamp unto my Feet;
And shining Light unto my Way.
I've sworn, and will the Oath perform;
Thy righteous Judgments I'll obey.
I am exceedingly distress'd;
Revive me, Lord, after thy Word.
My Mouth's free Off'rings pray accept;
Skill in thy Judgments me afford.
My Life is always in my Hand;
Yet I thy Law do not forget.
Nor have I from thy Precepts err'd;
Tho' Snares, for me, the Wicked set.
Thy Laws, my lasting Heritage,
I've chose; for my Heart's Joy they are.
My Heart stands bent to thy Commands;
As long as thou my Life shalt spare.

div.head: Fifteenth PART. SAMECH.
div.l: Vain fluctuating Thoughts I hate;
But fix my Love upon thy Law.
Thou art my hiding Place, and Shield;
My Hopes, from thy pure Word, I draw.
Depart from me ye wicked Men;
To keep my God's Commands I aim.
As thou hast said, support my Life;
Let not my Hope be turn'd to Shame.
Uphold me, then I shall be safe;
I'll to thy Laws still turn mine Eyes.
Transgressors thou hast trodden down;
For they deceiv'd themselves with Lies.
Thou dost ill Men, like Dross, reject;
To love thy Laws, I'm therefore led.
For Fear of Thee my Flesh doth quake;
And I thy awful Judgments dread.

div.head: Sixteenth PART. AIN.
div.l: Judgment, and Justice, I have done;
Let no Oppressors me distress.
Thy Servant's Surety be for good;
Lest haughty Foes should me oppress.
My Eyes have fail'd, with longing Looks,
To see thy Help, and promis'd Word.
In Mercy with thy Servant deal;
Thy righteous Statutes teach me, Lord.
Give me, thy Servant Skill; and then
I shall thy Testimonies know.
'Tis Time, O Lord, for Thee to work;
For Men thy Law do over throw.
Therefore I love thy Statutes more
Than Gold; the finest, and the best.
I all thy Precepts highly prize:
As right; but all false Ways detest.

div.head: Seventeenth PART. PE.
div.l: Thy Testimonies wondrous are;
Therefore my Soul doth keep thy Ways.
The Entrance of thy Word gives Light;
And Wisdom to the weak conveys.
I gape, and pant, for thy Commands;
For after them my Heart's in Flame.
Behold, and pity me, as thou
Art wont to them that love thy Name.
Direct my Walk in thy pure Word;
And let no Sin, in me, bear Sway.
From Man's Oppression set me free;
So I thy Precepts will obey.
O make thy Face, on me, to shine;
And me to know thy Statutes cause.
The Tears, like Floods, stream from mine Eyes;
To see Men violate thy Laws.

div.head: Eighteenth PART. TSADDI.
div.l: Righteous art thou, O Lord; and all
Thy Judgments upright are we find.
Thy Testimonies righteous are,
And faithful which thou hast enjoin'd.
Thy Zeal consumed me; because
Mine Enemies thy Law forget.
Thy Word is thoroughly refin'd;
Therefore my Heart on it is set.
Tho' I am little, and despis'd,
My Mind thy Precepts yet retains.
Thy Righteousness forever lasts;
Thy Law eternal Truth remains.
Trouble, and Anguish, on me seiz'd;
Yet great Delight thy Precepts give.
Thy Laws are just forevermore;
Oh! teach me them, and I shall live.

div.head: Nineteenth PART. KOPH.
div.l: With my whole Heart I cry'd, hear me;
O Lord; thy Statutes I'll obey.
To Thee I cry'd, save me; that I
May keep thy Testimony's Way.
