Before the dawning Light I cry'd;
Thy Promise did me Hope afford.
Mine Eyes prevent the Watch that I,
May meditate upon thy Word.
My Voice, in Loving-kindness, hear;
Lord, in thy Word revive my Heart.
Who follow Mischief near approach;
They from thy Laws far off depart.
But, O Iehovah, thou art near;
All thy Commands, as Truth, endure.
As for thy Word, I know of old,
Thou hast it fix'd forever sure.

div.head: Twentieth PART. RESCH.
div.l: View my Distress, and rescue me;
For I thy Law still bear in Mind.
Plead thou my Cause, and me redeem;
May I, thy Word, me quick'ning, find.
Salvation's far from wicked Men;
For they to keep thy Law ne'er strive.
Great are thy tender Mercies, Lord;
Oh! in thy Judgments me revive.
Many conspire to seek my Hurt;
But from thy Truth I've not declin'd.
With Grief Transgressors I beheld;
For they've not kept thy Word in Mind.
Behold, how thy Commands I love!
Lord, in thy Mercy quicken me.
Thy Word, from th' early'st Time is true;
And lasts 'till Time no more shall be.

div.head: Twenty-first PART. SCHIN.
div.l: Princes me, causeless, persecute;
My Heart, in Awe of thy Word, stands.
I in thy Word rejoice; as one
That mighty Spoils of War commands.
All Falshood hate I, and detest;
But thy just Law, sincerely love.
Sev'n Times a Day I Thee will praise;
Because thy Judgments righteous prove.
Great Peace have they that love thy Law;
No stumbling Stone shall them offend.
For thy Salvation, Lord, I hope;
And thy Commands with Care attend.
My Soul thy Testimonies kept;
And them I love with great Delight.
Thy Law, and Word, I have observ'd;
For all my Ways are in thy Sight.

div.head: Twenty-second PART. TAU.
div.l: Lord, let my Cry approach my Face;
As thou hast spoke, me prudent make.
Let my Request, before Thee, come;
Deliver me, for thy Word's Sake.
Then shall my Lips pour forth thy Praise;
When me, thy Statutes, thou shalt teach.
All thy Commands are Righteousness;
Therefore my Tongue thy Word shall preach.
Let thine almighty Hand me help;
For I, thy Precepts, made my Choice.
Lord, I for thy Salvation long;
And greatly in thy Law rejoice.
Prolong my Life, and I'll Thee praise;
Let me thy promis'd Succour find.
Thy Servant seek, like lost Sheep stray'd;
For I thy Precepts bear in Mind.

div.head: PSALM CXX.
div.l: IN my Distress, to God, I cry'd,
And he redress'd my Wrongs.
Save, Lord, my Soul from lying Lips,
And from deceitful Tongues.
What shall a false Tongue give to Thee?
What Benefits confer?
What? but sharp Arrows of the strong,
And Coals of Iuniper.
Wo's me▪ I am a Sojourner,
In Meshech's barren Plain;
And yet, among the lawless Tents
Of Kedar, I remain.
Long Time, my Soul has dwelt with them,
That Charms of Peace abhor.
I am for Peace; but when, I speak,
They all declare for War.

div.head: PSALM CXXI.
div.l: IF to the Hills I lift mine Eyes,
From whence should come mine Aid?
My Help doth from Iehovah come;
Who Heav'n, and Earth, hath made.
He'll keep thy Feet from dang'rous Falls;
Thy Guardian never sleeps.
Nor Sleep, nor Slumber, touch the Eyes,
Of him that Isr'el keeps.
The Lord's thy Keeper, he, thy Shade,
Stands by thee on thy Right;
Lest scorching Sun offend by Day;
Or Moon's cold Damps by Night.
The Lord shall keep thee from all Harms;
Preserve thy Soul from Ill.
Thy going out; and coming in,
Keeps now, and ever will.

div.head: PSALM CXXII.
div.l: WITH Joy, I heard the People say,
Let's to the Lord's House go and pray.
Our Feet, henceforth, with Pleasure wait,
Ierusalem, within thy Gate.
Ierusalem's a City fair,
Compact, with beauteous Order there.
Thither the Tribes devoutly throng;
The Tribes which to the Lord belong.
To Isr'el's Witness we repair,
To honour God, with Praise, and Pray'r.
The Seats of Justice there have Place;
And Thrones of David's royal Race.
Pray Salem's Peace may lasting be;
For they shall prosper that love thee.
May Peace within thy Walls abound;
Thy Palaces with Joy be crown'd.
For Friends, and Brethren's Sake, I pray
May happy Peace, within thee stay.
Because Iehovah's House is there,
Thy Good shall be my constant Care.

div.head: PSALM CXXII. 2d Meetre.
div.l: MY Heart rejoic'd to hear
The People this declare,
We'll to Iehovah's House ascend.
Our Feet shall henceforth wait
Within fair Salem's Gate,
And sacred Worship there attend.
Ierusalem is built
A City, richly gilt,
Compact, and great shall be in Fame.
God's Cov'nant Ark is there,
Thither his Tribes repair,
To thank, and Praise, Iehovah's Name.
Justice has there it's Place,
With Thrones of David's Race.
O pray for Salem's happy Peace;
They prosper that love thee.
Within thy Walls Peace be.
Thy Palaces, with Joy increase.
For Friends, and Brethren's Sake,
Whose Good my own I make,
Thy Peace shall be my constant Pray'r.
Because the Lord, our God,
His House makes his Abode,
Thy Weal shall ever be my Care.

div.head: PSALM CXXIII.
div.l: TO Thee, for Succour, in Distress,
I lift my longing Eyes;
Oh! thou Omnipotent, Supream!
Who dwell'st above the Skies.
As Servants, eye their Master's Hand,
Their Mistresses, the Maids;
So to the Lord, our God, we look,
For his reviving Aids.
Have Mercy upon us, O Lord,
Oh! Pity to us show;
For loaded with most base Contempt,
We feel the Depth of Woe.
From those that live at Ease, our Soul
Is greatly fill'd with Scorn;
And the vile Insult of the Proud,
We heavily have borne.

div.head: PSALM CXXIV.
div.l: HAD not the Lord, may Isr'el say,
Appeared on our Side;
Had not the Lord us help'd, when Men▪
Rose, like the swelling Tide:
They soon had swallow'd us alive;
So fierce their Wrath did rowl;
The Waters had o'erwhelmed us,
The Stream gone o'er our Soul.
Proud Waters then had o'er us beat,
And swept us quite away.
Bless'd be the Lord; who gave us not,
To their sharp Teeth, a Prey.
Our Soul's escap'd the broken Snare,
As Birds, from Fowler's, fled.
Our Help is in Iehovah's Name;
Who Heav'n, and Earth, hath made.

div.head: PSALM CXXV.
div.l: THey, like to Sion's sacred Mount,
Who in the Lord confide,
Shall stand unmov'd, in midst of Storms,
And ever safe abide.
Lo! how the Mountains, compassing
Ierusalem, ascend;
The Lord, his People, so surrounds,
And ever will defend.
The Rod of Wickedness shall not
Lest righteous Men put forth their Hands,
And them with Evil stain.
To all that are sincerely good,
Thy Goodness, Lord, impart;
O may it freely flow to all
That are upright in Heart.
They that to crooked Ways decline,
The Lord shall force them down,
Where wicked Men are doom'd to go;
But Peace shall Isr'el crown.

div.head: PSALM CXXVI.
div.l: WHen Sion's Captives God return'd,
Such an illustrious Theme,
Struck us with Wonder and Surprise;
We were like them that dream.
Then was our Mouth with Laughter fill'd,
Our Tongue for Joy did shout;
The Heathen said, the Lord, for them,
Great Things hath brought about.
With Joy, we own, great Things, for us,
Are wrought, Lord, by thy Hand.
Return the Remnant; and 'twill be
Like Streams to South parch'd Land.
Who sow in Tears, in Joy shall reap.
They that go forth, and mourn,
Bearing choice Seed, shall sure with Joy,
Laden with Sheaves, return.

div.head: PSALM CXXVII.
div.l: EXcept the Lord do build the House,
The Builders labour all in vain:
Unless the Lord the City keep,
In vain the Guards their Watch maintain.
To rise betimes, and sit up late,
And eat thy Br •• d with Grief opprest,
Is vain; without such carking Cares,
The Lord gives his Beloved Rest.
Lo; Children are God's Heritage;
The fruitful Womb is his Reward.
As Arrows in a strong Man's Hand,
So Sons of Youth are Parents Guard.
Happy the Man, whose Quiver's fill'd
With Shafts, that on him ready wait;
He shall not be asham'd to speak
With th' Adversary in the Gate.

div.head: PSALM CXXVIII.
div.l: THrice bless'd are all that fear the Lord;
And walk in his pure Ways.
Thy Labour shall supply thy Wants;
And prosper all thy Days.
Thy Wife, a lovely fruitful Vine,
By thy House Sides, shall grow;
Thy Children, round thy Table set,
Like Olive Plants shall show.
〈…〉 the Man be blest,
That doth Iehovah fear.
The Lord, who dwells on Sion Hill,
Shall bless thee ev'ry where;
Thou, all thy Days, with joy, shall see
Ierus • lem's happy State:
Behold thy Children's Children rise,
And Peace on Israel wait.

div.head: PSALM CXXIX.
div.l: FROM my Youth up, may Isr'el say,
They oft have me assail'd;
They oft, from Youth, my Ruin sought,
But have not quite prevail'd.
The Plowers long their Furrows plow'd;
And put my Back to Pain.
The Lord is righteous he hath cut.
The Wicked's Cords in Twain.
Let all that Sion hate, with Shame,
And in Confusion, fly.
May they, as Grain, on Houses Tops,
But just spring up and die.
With which no Reaper fills his Hand,
Nor Arms that binds the Sheave,
No Passenger, God bless you, says;
We, you our Blessing, leave.

div.head: PSALM CXXX.
div.l: LORD from the Heart, and Depth of Woe▪
My Cry, to Thee, I send.
Hear, Lord, my Voice, and to my Pray'r,
O let thine Ear attend.
Should'st thou, O Lord, observe our Crimes,
Who could the Tryal bear?
But there Forgiveness is with Thee,
That thou may'st be our Fear.
My Soul doth for Iehovah wait;
And I hope in his Word.
No Watch-men long for dawning Light,
As my Soul for the Lord.
Let Isr'el trust in God, the Source
Of all redeeming Grace;
Who will compleat Redemption grant,
And all their Sins efface.

div.head: PSALM CXXXI.
div.l: O Lord, my Heart's not haughty grown,
Nor lofty are my Eyes;
In Things too great, and high, for me,
Is not mine Exercise.
Surely, I have compos'd my Mind,
And carry'd it as mild,
As Children weaned from the Breast;
My Soul's a weaned Child.
Let Isr'el learn, in God alone,
The God whom they adore,
To place their steadfast Hope, and Trust,
Both now, and evermore.

div.head: PSALM CXXXII.
div.l: THY Promise, Lord, to David, mind,
And all the Chast'ning of thy Rod.
How to Iehovah he hath sworn,
And vow'd to Iacob's mighty God.
I will not go into my House,
Not on my Bed my Limbs, repose;
No Sleep I'll to mine Eyes afford,
Nor Slumber shall mine Eye-lids close;
'Till, for the Lord, I have found out,
And for his Ark, a resting Place;
Which shall the future Dwelling be,
Of the great God of Iacob's Race.
Behold, we heard it's spreading Fame,
At Ephrata; but now have found
The chosen Spot, for it's Abode,
Where Hills of mighty Woods surround.
We'll go into his sacred Tents,
Our Worship, at his Foot-stool, pay.
Arise, O Lord, into thy Rest;
And with thine Ark of Strength there stay.
Array thy Priests with Righteousness;
Let all thy Saints aloud rejoice.
And for thy Servant David's Sake,
Despise not thine Anointed's Voice.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: The Lord, to David, sware in Truth,
The Oath he never will disown;
"That, one, descended from thy Loins,
"Shall surely sit upon thy Throne.
"And if thy Sons my Cov'nant keep,
"And to my sacred Laws submit;
"Their Children also, evermore,
"Upon thy royal Throne shall sit.
Because the Lord hath Sion chose;
And there desir'd to have his Seat.
This is my Rest forever; here
I'll dwell; for I've desired it.
I'll surely bless her growing Stores;
And satisfy her Poor with Food.
Her Priests, with my Salvation, cloath;
Her Saints, with Joy, shall shout aloud.
There David's Horn I'll make to bud;
There mine Anointed's Lamp ordain.
With Shame I'll cloath his Foes; on him
His Crown shall flourishing remain.

div.head: PSALM CXXXIII.
div.l: BEhold; how charming is the Sight!
How good too doth it prove!
When Brethren in their Hearts unite,
And live in Peace, and Love.
It's like the precious Ointment, pour'd
On A'ron's sacred Head;
Which down his Locks the Perfume shower'd,
And o'er his Garments spread.
So Hermon's, and Mount Sion's Dews
Descend, and bless the Plains;
For there the Lord his Blessing shews,
And endless Life ordains.

div.head: PSALM CXXXIII. 2d Meetre.
div.l: BEhold! how good it proves!
How charming is the Sight!
When Brethren, dwell in Love
In firmest Bonds, unite;
When all agree
To act their Part,
As with one Heart,
In Charity.
It's like the precious Oyl,
That casts a fragrant Smell,
Which pour'd on A'ron's Head,
A down his Locks it fell;
From thence it shed
It's trickling Globes,
On's priestly Robes,
And Odours spread.
So the refreshing Dews,
From Hermon's Top, that flow,
Or rowl down Sion's Mount,
Revive the Plains below:
Iehovah there
His Bliss ordains,
With Life that reigns
For ever fair.

div.head: PSALM CXXXIV.
div.l: LO; all ye Servants of the Lord,
Who nightly stand, and wait,
Attending in his sacred House,
Iehovah celebrate.
Bless ye the Lord, lift up your Hands
Within his holy Place;
The Lord, who Heav'n, and Earth, hath made,
Thee out of Sion bless.

div.head: PSALM CXXXV.
div.l: LET's join, and Hallelujah sing;
Praise ye Iehovah's Name;
O all ye Servants of the Lord,
His glorious Praise proclaim.
Who, in the House of God attend,
Or in his Court Yards meet;
Praise ye the Lord, for it is good,
To praise his Name is sweet.
Because Iehovah Iacob chose,
His own by special Grace;
For his peculiar Treasure took,
Isr'el, and all his Race.
The Lord is great; our God is high
Above all Gods we own.
Who, what he pleas'd in Heav'n, and Earth,
In Seas, and Depths, hath done.
He makes the Vapours to ascend,
From Earth, in Clouds combin'd;
He bringeth Light'ning, with th • Rain,
From unknown Stores the 〈◊〉 .

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Egypt's First-born, of Man, and Beast,
He smote, thro' all their Coast.
His dreadful Signs and Wonders, sent
On Pharaoh, and his Host.
He many Nations, mighty Kings,
Did, by his Pow'r, subdue.
He, Sihon, King of th' Amorites,
And Og, of Bashan, slew:
He Canaan's num'rous Kingdoms smote,
And freed from Tyrants Hands.
An Heritage, to Isr'el's Tribes,
He gave their fertile Lands.
Thy Name, O Lord, by thy great Acts,
Shall be forever known;
And we'll transmit thy Name, and Praise,
To future Ages down.
The Lord, his People's Cause, will judge,
Who now oppressed mourn;
Will, for his Servants Sake, repent,
And from his Anger turn.

div.head: Third PART.
div.l: The many Idol Gods ador'd,
By all the Heathen Bands,
Are Gold, and Silver, shining Dust;
The Labour of Men's Hands.
Their Mouths no Pow'r of Speech retain,
And sightless are their Eyes.
Their Ears are deaf; no vital Breath
Their Mouth, or Breast, supplies.
All those that make such Idols vain,
And Homage to them pay;
Who put their Trust in them for Help,
As sensless are as they.
O House of Isr'el, bless the Lord;
O A'ron's, praise his Name.
The Lord, O House of Levi, bless;
Ye Just, his Praise proclaim.
O let Iehovah blessed be,
From Sion, with Accord,
Who dwelleth in Ierusalem,
Sing Praises to the Lord.

div.head: PSALM CXXXVI.
div.l: YOUR Thanks, to God, most good repeat;
His Mercy still prevails.
Praise him, the God of Gods, most great;
His Mercy never fails.
Give Thanks unto the King of Kings;
His Mercy lasts always.
Who only doth most wondrous Things;
His Mercy ne'er decays.
Whose Wisdom gave the Heav'ns their Birth;
His Mercy shall endure.
Above the Waters rais'd the Earth;
His Mercy's ever sure.
To him, who did great Lights display;
His Mercy still prevails.
His Mercy never fails.
The Moon, and Stars, to rule the Night;
His Mercy lasts always.
Did Egypt, in their First-born, smite;
His Mercy ne'er decays.
Who Isr'el led from slavish Land;
His Mercy shall endure.
With stretch'd out Arm, and mighty Hand;
His Mercy's ever sure.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: The Red Sea he asunder clave;
His Mercy still prevails.
And Isr'el Passage thro' it gave;
His Mercy never fails.
But Pharaoh's Host, with Seas, o'er spread;
His Mercy lasts always.
His People, thro' the Desert, led;
His Mercy ne'er decays.
To him who did great Monarchs smite;
His Mercy shall endure.
And slew Kings, famous for their Might;
His Mercy's ever sure.
Sihon, who th' Am'rites Sceptre sway'd;
His Mercy still prevails.
And Og, whom Bashan's Towns obey'd;
His Mercy never fails.
For Heritage, he gave their Lands;
His Mercy lasts always.
Into his Servants Isr'el's Hands;
His Mercy ne'er decays.
Who thought on us, when we were low;
His Mercy shall endure.
And us redeemed from the Foe.
His Mercy's ever sure.
Who to all Flesh their Food conveys;
His Mercy still prevails.
The God of Heav'n, O therefore, praise;
His Mercy never fails.

div.head: PSALM CXXXVII.
div.l: THere we sat down, and wept, by Streams,
Which glide by Babel's Walls;
While Sion's melancholly Themes,
Our mournful Mind recalls.
Our Harps, which us'd their Part to bear,
When Sion's Songs we sung,
On Willow-Trees, that flourish'd there,
As useless now we hung.
Stern Lords who did us Captive bring,
Insulted thus our Wrongs;
"Come, take your Harps, and chearful sing
"Us, one of Sion's Songs.
How can we, Lord, thy Songs repeat,
To Aliens, in strange Land?
If thee, Ierus'lem, I forget;
Her Skill may my Right-hand.
My Tongue cleave to my Roof; if I,
Of thee, forgetful prove;
Or ever entertain a Joy,
Ierusalem above.
Remember, Lord, how Edom's Sons,
In Salem's woful Day,
Cry'd, "Rase it, rase the lowest Stones,
"And with the Ground it lay.
O Daughter of proud Babylon!
Whom we are doom'd to see;
Happy's the Man, the Wrongs thou'st done
To us, returns on thee.
Bless'd Man! who, at the high Command,
Shall take thy little ones,
As thou did'st ours, in cruel Hands,
And dash against the Stones.

div.head: PSALM CXXXVIII.
div.l: WITH my whole Heart, my Sacrifice
Of Praise, to Thee, I'll bring;
And openly, before the Gods,
Thy Praise, my God, I'll sing.
Towards thy holy House I'll bow,
Thy Grace, and Truth, proclaim;
For over all, thou by thy Word,
Hast magnify'd thy Name.
God, in the Day I made my Cry,
A speedy Answer gave;
Did Strength encrease thro' all my Soul,
And from my Tears me save.
Lord, Thee, all Kings on Earth, shall praise;
When they shall hear thy Word.
They, in Iehovah's Ways, shall sing;
For great's thy Glory, Lord.
For tho' the Lord's enthron'd on high,
The Humble he respects;
But he far off beholds the Proud,
And with Disdain rejects.
Tho' circled with Distress, I walk,
Thee quick'ning me I have;
Thou'lt stretch thy Hand on my Foe's Wrath
Thy Right-hand will me save.
What Mercy has for me begun,
The Lord will perfect make;
Thy Mercy fails not, Lord; the Work
Of thy Hands ne'er forsake.

div.head: PSALM CXXXIX.
div.l: O Lord, thou do'st me search, and know,
Whether I sit, or rise.
My Thoughts, far distant from my Breast,
Thy piercing Sight descries.
My Path, and Bed, thou do'st surround,
And knowest all my Ways.
There's not a Word couch'd in my Tongue,
But, Lord, thine Eye surveys.
Behind, before, thou hast beset,
And on me laid thine Hand.
Such Knowledge is too wondrous high,
For me to understand.
Where shall I from thy Spirit go?
Or from thy Presence fly?
If Heav'n I climb, thou'rt there; lo there,
If deep in Earth I ly.
If on the Morning Wings, I flee
To utmost Bounds of Seas:
Thy Hand must first conduct me there,
There would thy Right-hand seise.
Or should I think to hide, behind
The Curtains of the Night;
Ev'n Night itself would round me shine,
As Noon Days strongest Light.
No Darkness can obscure thy Sight;
Thus Day, and Night, agree;
The darkest Night, and brightest Day,
Are both alike to Thee.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: My inmost Reins, which thou didst form▪
Are still possess'd by Thee;
Thou, in the Womb, with tender Care,
Did'st wrap, and cover me.

Thy Wonders, in my curious Fra •••
▪
My Admiration raise;
My Soul, thy marv'lous Works, •• ows well,
And gives to Thee the Praise.
My Substance was not hid from Thee,
Who me in Secret wrought;
And, in the Depth of Earth, the Parts
To closest Union brought.
Thine Eyes beheld my unform'd Mass,
The daily Growth it took;
And all my Members yet unshap'd,
Were entred in thy Book.
How precious are thy Thoughts to me!
O God, how wondrous kind!
From first, to last, how great's their Sum!
No Power of mine can find.
Should I attempt to number them,
They far surpass the Sand;
Whene'er I wake, I'm still with Thee,
Supported by thine Hand.

div.head: Third PART.
div.l: Surely the Men that wicked are,
Thou wilt destroy, O God;
Therefore, from my Society,
Depart, ye Men of Blood.
For their vile Tongues against Thee speak,
And impiously proclaim;
Thine Enemies, perfidious take
In vain thy sacred Name.
Are not those Men, that hate Thee, Lord,
Most hateful in mine Eyes?
Is not mine Heart ev'n broke to see,
Against Thee, how they rise?
Such Men, I utterly abhor,
And number with my Foes.
Search me, and know my Heart; and all,
My secret Thoughts disclose.
Discover ev'ry harbour'd Crime,
That lurketh in my Breast;
And lead me, all my future Days,
The Way to endless Rest.

div.head: PSALM CXL.
div.l: LORD, save me from the evil Man,
And such as violent are.
Who Mischief in their Hearts contrive,
And daily meet for War.
Like Serpents, they make sharp their Tongues,
To hiss out Calumnies;
Conceal'd, beneath their guileful Lips,
The Adder's Poison lies.
Keep me, O Lord, from wicked Hands,
From violent Men me free;
Who would precipitate my Steps,
And think to ruin me.
The Proud have laid their Snares, & Cords,
And secret spread their Net
Across my Path; and artfully
Around me Toils have set.
The Lord, I then address'd, and said,
"Thou art my God alone;
"Lord, hear my Supplication's Voice,
"O hear my piteous Moan.
O Lord, my God, my Safety's Strength!
Thy Shield o'er me was spread,
When I in Battle was expos'd,
And covered my Head.
Grant not, O Lord, the Heart's Desire
Of those that wicked be;
Nor further thou their ill Designs;
Lest they triumph o'er me.
Upon their Head, who compass me
With Falsehood, and Deceit,
Shall all the Malice of their Lips,
Come down, with all it's Weight.
Hot burning Coals on them shall fall;
They shall be burnt with Fire;
In Pits, from whence they ne'er shall rise,
Deep plung'd shall they expire.
Let not an evil Speaker find,
On Earth, a resting Place:
Evil shall hunt th' injurious Man,
And him to Ruin chase.
The Lord, I know, for the Oppress'd,
And Poor, will Judgment give.
Surely, the Just shall praise thy Name;
And in thy Presence live.

div.head: PSALM CXLI.
div.l: TO Thee, O Lord, I cry,
Make haste, for me appear;
And when I call on Thee for Aid,
My Voice, in Mercy, hear.
Before Thee, let my Pray'r,
As Morning Incense, rise;
The lifting up my Hands accept,
As Ev'ning Sacrifice.
Let, Lord, thy constant Guard,
Before my Mouth, attend;
And keep the Door of my vain Lips,
Lest rashly I offend.
Bow not my Heart to Ill;
Nor let me ever share,
With wicked Men, in their bad Deeds,
Nor on their Danties fare.
Let just Men's kind Reproof
Smite me, it shall not break
My Head, but heal like Balm; my Pray'r,
In their Distress, I'll make.
When cast into the Rock,
Their Chiefs lay at my Feet,
Within my Pow'r; they heard my Words▪
But, Oh, how soft! how sweet!
Our Bones about the Graves,
Ly scatter'd all around;
As when one ploweth up the Earth,
And teareth up the Ground.
But, Lord, my God, to Thee,
Directed are mine Eyes;
Let not my Soul be naked left;
My Trust on Thee relies.
O keep me from the Snares,
Which they have laid for me;
And from the Nets which they have spread,
Who work Iniquity.
But let the Wicked fall,
Together, in their Net;
While I, o'er all, in Safety pass,
And out of Danger get.

div.head: PSALM CXLII.
div.l: I Cry'd aloud, unto the Lord,
And fervently I pray'd.
To him I pour'd out my Complaint;
My Griefs before him laid.
When Sorrows overwhelm'd my Soul,
Then thou my Path didst know:
They laid their private Snares for me,
Wherever I should go.
On my Right-hand I look'd, and saw,
That not one Friend was there;
All Refuge fail'd, ev'n Flight was fled,
None for my Soul did care.
To Thee, O Lord, I cry'd, and said▪
"Thou art my Hope alone;
"My Portion, while on Earth I live,
"And when from hence I'm gone.
I, to the last Extreams, am brought,
O hear my earnest Cry;
Me from my Persecutors save,
Who stronger are than I.
From this dark Prison bring my Soul,
That I thy Name may praise;
The Just shall me surround, for thou
Shalt me reward with Grace.

div.head: PSALM CXLIII.
div.l: HEAR, Lord, my Pray'r, to my Request,
Let thy kind Ear attend;
And in thy Truth, and Righteousness,
A gracious Answer send.
Let not thy Servant, by strict Rules,
Of Justice, Lord, be try'd;
For in thy Sight, no Man alive,
Could so be justify'd.
The Foe pursu'd my Soul, my Life
Down to the Ground did tread,
In Darkness made to dwell, as those
That Ages have been dead.
Therefore my Spirit sinks in me;
My Heart is desolate.
Past Times I call to Mind, and on
Thy Works I meditate.
With out stretch'd Hands, thine Aid I crave;
For Thee my Soul doth pant,
As thirsty Lands, in Summer's Heat,
That cooling Showers want.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Hear me with Speed, hide not thy Face,
My sinking Spirit save;
Lest I should soon become like them,
That lye down in the Grave.
Let me thy Kindness early hear,
For I in Thee confide;
Shew me the Way where I should go:
I look to Thee, my Guide.
From all my threat'ning Enemies,
O Lord deliver me;
For Shelter, from their Rage, I fly,
To hide myself with Thee.
Thou art my God, teach me thy Will
Forever to obey;
Let thy good Spirit me conduct,
In thy most righteous Way.
Revive me, Lord, and spare my Life,
That all thy Name may sing;
For th' Honour of thy faithful Word,
My Soul from Trouble bring.
In Mercy to me, rout my Foes,
Thy gracious Aids afford,
Destroy all that afflict my Soul;
For I'm thy Ser •• nt Lord.

div.head: PSALM CXLIV.
div.l: FOrever blessed be the Lord,
My Rock; who doth instruct me right▪
To guide the War; and Strength affords
My Hands, when I engage in Fight.
My Goodness he, Safe-guard, and Pow'r,
My great Deliv'rer, and my Shield,
In whom I trust; who, to my Pow'r,
Makes Tribes submit, and Nations yield.
Lord! what is Man! or his frail Race!
That thy Concern thou him hast made!
Man is but Vanity, his Days
Fly swiftly, as a passing Shade.
Lord bow thine Heav'ns, and come down,
But touch the Mountains, Smoke shall rise.
Cast Light'nings, rout, and them confound
With pointed Arrows from the Skies.
From Heav'n, send forth thy mighty Hand,
Rescue, and save me, from the Pow'r
Of Aliens; who like Waters stand,
Wide gaping, ready to devour.
Whose Mouths, with their vain Boasts, abound,
And utter Speeches full of Lies;
Their Right-hand's plighted Faith is found,
But broken Leagues, and Perjuries.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: New Songs to Thee, O God, I'll sing;
My Voice, and Psaltery, agree,
The Ten string'd Instrument I'll bring,
And join in Hymns of Praise to Thee.
God, with Salvation, Kings befriends,
And Vict'ry to their Arms affords;
His Servant David, he defends,
From the keen Edge of h • rtful Swords.
Still save from Sons of foreign Land,
Whose Mouths speak Vanity, and Lies;
The plighted Faith of whose Right-hand,
Is nought but Fraud, and Perjuries.
Then shall the Fruits of Peace abound;
Our Sons, like thriving Plants shall grow;
As polish'd Pillars Courts surround,
Our blooming Daughters beauteous show.
Our Magazines be fill'd with Store,
Of ev'ry Kind of pleasant Grains;
Our num'rous Flocks encreasing more,
In Thousands spread the neighb'ring Plains.
Our Oxen fat, and strong, shall grow;
And no invading Foe be fear'd,
No Marchings out we sadly know,
Nor Murm'rings in our Streets be heard.
O happy are that People, who
Flourish in such a State as this;
Thrice happy People, that can shew,
Their God, the great Iehovah is.

div.head: PSALM CXLV.
div.l: I'LL Thee extol, my God, and King,
And ever bless thy Name.
I'll bless Thee ev'ry Day, and sing,
With endless Songs, thy Fame.
The Lord is great, all Praise his due,
His Greatness Thought exceeds.
One Age the next, thy Works, shall shew▪
And sing thy mighty 〈◊〉 .
I'll speak the Glories of thy State,
And Wonders thou hast done.
While Men thy Terrors shall relate;
Thy Greatness 〈◊〉 make known.
Thy matchless Goodness, they shall praise
With chearful Heart, and Tongue;
Thy Righteousness, in all thy Ways,
Shall be their constant Song.
God's good, and kind, and rich in Grace;
But unto Anger slow.
He's good to all; in ev'ry Place,
His tender Mercies flow.
Thee, all thy Works, O Lord, shall praise;
And Thee thy Saints shall bless:
Abroad thy Kingdom's Glory blaze;
Thy mighty Pow'r confess.
To make all Nations know his Pow'r;
And Kingdom's glorious State.
Thy Kingdom ever shall endure;
Thy Reign's of endless Date.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: The Lord preserveth all that fall;
And raiseth up the low.
All look to Thee; Thou Food to all,
In Season, dost bestow.
Thine open Hand to all conveys,
According to their Needs.
Thou, Lord, art just in all thy Ways,
And bountiful in Deeds.
The Lord is nigh, to help them all
That his kind Aid implore;
He'll none reject that on him call,
And him in Truth adore.
But he'll their just Desires fulfill,
That his great Name revere;
To their Request attend he will,
And save them from th ••• Fear.
All, who the Lord sincerely love,
Protection shall enjoy;
But who perversly wicked prove,
He'll utterly destroy.
Raptures divine my Tongue inspire,
To sing Iehovah's Fame;
Let all Flesh join the sacred Quire,
And ever bless his Name.

div.head: PSALM CXLVI.
div.l: PRaise God; my Soul praise thou the Lord.
I'll praise my God, and King,
Thro' all my Life; whilst that I am,
Praise to my God I'll sing.
On Princes, who no Help can give,
Nor on Man's Son, rely.
His Breath departs, he turns to Earth,
His Thoughts then with him die.
O happy Man; who hath the God
Of Iacob for his Aid;
Whose Hope upon the Lord, his God,
Alone, is firmly stay'd.
Who made the Heav'ns, the Earth, and Sea▪
With all that they contain;
Who keeps the Truth forever sure
His Promises remain.
Who righteous Judgment executes,
For those oppress'd that be;
He gives the Hungry Food, the Lord
Doth set the Pris'ner free.
The Lord illuminates the blind;
From burden'd Souls removes
Their heavy Loads, and lifts them up;
The Lord the righteous loves.
The Lord saves Strangers, he supports
Widows, and Fatherless;
But up-side down he turns their Ways,
Who wickedly transgress.
Iehovah shall forever reign;
Thy God, O Sion, sways.
The Scepter, while all Ages last
O give Iehovah praise.

div.head: PSALM CXLVII.
div.l: PRaise ye the Lord; 'tis good to sing
The Praises of our God, and King;
Praise is the most delightful Theme,
And nothing more becomes our Frame.
The Lord Ierus'lem doth repair;
And bring his scatter'd Exiles there.
He kindly heals the broken Heart;
Binds up their Wounds, allays their Smart.
He numbers all the starry Flames;
And calls them by their various Names.
Great is our Lord, of boundless Might;
His Understanding's infinite.
The Lord the Meek hath rais'd, and crown'd;
But cast the Wicked to the Ground.
To God your thankful Praises sing;
And join the Harps melodious String.
Who clouds the Sky, prepares the Rains;
Makes Grass to grow on Mounts, and Plains,
His Treasures, Beasts with Food, supply;
And the young Ravens, when they cry.
He, in the Strength, or nimble Flight,
Of Horse, or Man, takes no Delight.
The Lord takes Pleasure in the Just;
And those that in his Mercy trust.

div.head: Second PART.
div.l: Ierusalem, Iehovah, praise;
Sion, thy God, with sacred Lays.
He, thy Gates Bars with Strength possess't;
In thee thy Children he hath blest▪
He gives thy Borders Peace most sweet;
And fills thee with the finest Wheat.
On Earth he sends forth his Decrees;
His Word, like Light'ning, swiftly flees.
Like Wool, he cloaths the Ground, with Snows;
His hoary Frost, as Ashes, throws:
Fragments of Ice casts from his Hand;
And who before his Cold can stand?
He sendeth forth his high Commands,
The Glebe is loosen'd from it's Bands;
He bids the warmer Breezes blow;
The Ice dissolves, the Waters flow.
His Word, and Will, by Act of Grace,
He hath reveal'd to Iacob's Race;
To Isr'el, whom he chose his own,
His Laws, and Judgments, are made known.
There's none of all the Nations round,
With him, such Favour, e'er have found;
To them, he never did afford,
His Judgments. Therefore praise the Lord.

div.head: PSALM CXLVIII.
div.l: LOUD Hallelujah's sing:
From Heav'ns Iehovah praise;
His Fame th' Empyrial ring,
In the sublimest Lays.
Angels begin
The lofty Song;
His Hosts great Throng,
To praise strike in.
Praise him, ye Sun, and Moon,
Which rule the Day, and Night;
His Praise be all your Tune,
Ye glitt'ring Stars of Light.
Heav'n's Heav'ns vast Frame,
Waters that rise
Above the Skies,
His Praise proclaim.
Let them in this Accord,
To praise Iehovah's Name;
For he but spake the Word,
And they from Nothing came.
He fix'd them fast,
From Changes free,
By his Decree;
Which firm shall last.
Praise God from Earth below;
Ye Dragons, and each Deep;
Fire, Hail, and Mist, and Snow,
And Storms, his Word which keep.
Hills, Mountains high,
Trees bearing Fruit;
Cedars that shoot
So near the Sky.
Beasts wild, and tame, and Things
That creep, or wing the Air;
All Subjects, and all Kings,
Princes, and Judges here:
His Praise be sung,
By hoary Heads,
Young Men, and Maids,
And th' Infant's Tongue.
Let all address his Throne,
In Praise, with one Consent;
Iehovah's Name alone,
Is wondrous excellent:
His Glories far
Above Earth rise,
Transcend the Skies,
And ev'ry Star.
His People's Horn he rais'd,
And high advanc'd their Fame;
By all his Saints is prais'd
His ever glorious Name:
By Isr'el's Race,
A People near,
And to him dear.
Iehovah praise.

div.head: PSALM CXLIX.
div.l: PRAISE ye the Lord; sing unto God,
A new melodious Song;
Shew forth the Honour of his Name,
Assembled Saints among.
Let Isr'el's Heart, with holy Joy,
In him that made him, spring;
And Sion's Sons their Triumph make,
In their illustrious King.
Let them the sounding Pipe employ,
To praise his holy Name;
The Harp, and Timbrel, join, and sing,
And loud his Praise proclaim.
The Lord takes Pleasure in his Saints,
Whom Sinners treat with Scorn;
With his Salvation, humble Souls,
He'll gloriously adorn.
Because such Glory he bestows,
Let all his Saints rejoice;
And thus secur'd, upon their Beds,
In Singing, raise their Voice.
Their Mouth be fill'd with the high Praise
Of their almighty Lord;
While their Right-hand does grasp, and wield,
The 'vengefull Two-edg'd Sword,
On Heathen just Revenge to take,
And punish those design'd;
To chain their Kings, and noble Peers
In Iron Fetters bind.
Judgment on them to execute,
Which sacred Rolls record;
This Honour all his Saints shall have.
Sing Praises to the Lord.

div.head: PSALM CXLIX. 2d Meetre. Messi'rs a • e and Brady's Version.
div.l: O Praise ye the Lord,
Prepare your glad Voice.
His Praise in the great
Assembly to sing.
In our great Creator,
Let Isr'el rejoice;
And Children of Sion
Be glad in their King.
Let them his great Name
Extol in the Dance;
With Timbrel, and Harp,
His Praises express:
Who always takes Pleasure
His Saints to advance:
And with his Salvation
The humble to bless.
With Glory adorn'd,
His People shall sing
To God, who their Beds
With Safety does shield.
Their Mouths fill'd with Praises
Of him their great King;
Whilst a two-edged Sword
Their Right-hand does wield.
Just Vengeance to take
For Injuries past;
And punish those Lands
For Ruin design'd.
With Chains, as their Captives,
To tie their Kings fast;
With Fetters of Iron
Their Nobles to bind.
Thus shall they make good.
When them they destroy,
The dreadful Decree
Which God does proclaim;
Such Honour, and Triumph,
His Saints shall enjoy.
O therefore forever
Exalt his great Name.

div.head: PSALM CL.
div.l: PRaise God: praise him in's House below:
Praise him ye Heav'ns, his Pow'r which show.
Praise him for all his mighty Deeds;
Praise him whose Majesty exceeds.
Praise him with Trumpet's piercing Noise;
Praise him with Psalt'ries, Harps soft Voice.
Praise him with Timbrel shrill, and Flute;
Praise him with Organ, and sweet Lute.
Praise him with Cymbals ringing Veins;
Praise him in Cymbals lofty'st Strains.
Praise him let ev'ry breathing Thing;
Praises eternal to him sing.

div.head: EXODUS XV.
div.l: I'LL sing the Triumphs of the Lord,
Who's glorious in Renown;
The Horse, and him that rode thereon,
He in the Sea hath thrown.
The Lord's my Strength, my Song, Defence,
My God; for him I'll raise
A Mansion; he my Father's God,
I'll celebrate his Praise.
The Lord is the great God of War;
Iehovah is his Name.
Proud Pharoah's glit'ring Cars, and Host,
Tha • to the Ravage came,
In the Red Sea he cast; there were
His chosen Captains drown'd.
The Depths o'er whelm'd them; like a Stone,
They sank in the Profound.
The mighty Pow'r of thy Right-hand,
O Lord, most glorious shows;
Thy Right-hand, Lord, in Pieces dash'd
The proud insulting Foes.
Excelling Greatness those o'er throw
Against Thee who presum'd;
Thou sendest forth thy flaming Wrath,
Which them, as Chasf, consum'd.
Thy Nostril's Blast the Waters drove
Together in an Heap;
They stood upright, in the Mid-sea
Congealed was the Deep.
The En'my cry'd, Pursue, o'ertake,
I will the Spoil divide;
I'll draw my Sword, and them destroy,
Till Lust is satisfy'd.
But thou, with thy strong Wind, didst blow,
The deep Sea o'er them spread;
In mighty Waters down they sank,
As if they had been Lead.
Who, Lord, 's like Thee, among the Gods?
Thy Holiness exceeds
In Glory; fearful is thy Praise,
And wonderful thy Deeds.
Thou stretched'st out thy strong Right-hand,
The Earth them swallow'd quite.
In Mercy thou led'st forth thy Flock,
Which thou redeem'dst with Might:
And thou did'st guide them, in thy Strength,
Unto thine holy Hill.
Nations shall hear, and fear, and Dread
Seize Palestina will.
Then Edom's Dukes shall be amaz'd,
Moab's mighty Men be struck
With Terror: Canaan's Hearts shall melt,
As the dissolved Brook.
Thro' Fear, and Dread, of thy great Pow'r,
Still, as a Stone, they'll ly:
Until thy People, Lord, which •• ou
Hast purchas'd, shall pass by.
Thou shalt conduct, and plant them, where
The Place, for thy fix'd Residence,
Which thou, O Lord, hast made:
The chosen holy Place thine Hand,
O Lord, hath settled fast.
Thy Reign, O thou eternal King!
Forevermore shall last.
For Pharaoh's Chariots, Horse, and Men,
Thro' Seas audacious went;
And the returning Waves in Rage,
The Lord upon them sent:
But Isr'el's Race, a num'rous Host,
Under divine Command,
Walk'd thro' the Midst of dang'rous Seas,
Securely on dry Land.

div.head: MIRIAM's ANSWER.
div.l: SING ye the Triumphs of the Lord,
Who's glorious in Renown;
The Horse, and him that rode thereon,
He in the Sea hath thrown.

div.head: MOSES's Prophetick SONG. DEUT. XXXII.
div.l: LET Heav'n's wide Arch, while I shall speak,
Give an attentive Ear:
And hear, O Earth! th' important Truths
My Mouth shall now declare.
As Rain from Heav'n, my Doctrine drops,
My Speech, as Dew, distills;
As gentle Rains on tender Herbs,
And Show'rs on grassy Hills.
While I, Iehovah's glorious Name,
Shall publish all abroad;
With awful Reverence, ascribe
Ye Greatness to our God.
A Rock, whose Work Perfection claims,
His Ways all Judgment are;
A God of Truth, unspotted pure,
And just beyond compare.
But they themselves corrupted have,
Their Spot's, they're not his Sons;
They're a perverse, and crooked Race,
A Race of wicked Ones.
Oh! foolish People, and unwise!
Do'ye thus the Lord requite?
Thy Father is he not, who bought,
Thee made, and girt with Might?
Remember ancient Times, review
The Ages past and gone;
Thy Father ask, and Elders, they
Will tell what God hath done.
When God the Nation's Lots assign'd▪
To Adam's Sons their Place;
He set their Bounds with special Eye
To Isr'el's num'rous Race.
Iehovah, for his Portion, doth
His People high advance;
Iacob he chose the special Lot
Of his Inheritance.
In Sinai's Desert howling Waste▪
There found him the Most-High;
He led, and taught, and kept him safe,
As th' Apple of his Eye.
As th' Eagle flutters o'er her Young▪
And chears the feeble Things;
Her Pinions spreads, and takes them up▪
And bears them on her Wings.
So did the Lord alone sustain,
And lead them in his Care;
And to assist him there wss none,
No foreign God was there.
On Earth's high Places made him ride
Rich Fields supply his Want;
To suck sweet Honey from the Rock,
And Oyl from th' Adamant:
Butter of Kine, and Milk of Sheep,
Fat Lambs of Bashan's Brood,
With Goats, and finest Wheat, to eat;
And drink the Grapes pure Blood.
But Iesh'run waxed fat and kick'd;
High pamper'd, and adorn'd,
His Maker he forsook; the Rock
Of his Salvation scorn'd.
His Jealousy provok'd they with
Strange Gods, their fond Delights;
And kindled up his burning Wrath,
With their detested Rites.
To Idols, Devils, not to God,
They Altars madly rear'd;
To unknown, new and upstart Gods,
Their Fathers never fear'd.
The Rock of Ages thee begat,
Sure thou remember'st not;
The God that form'd, and nourish'd thee,
Thou vilely hast forgot.
When this Iehovah saw, their Deeds
His just Abhorrence mov'd;
Because a Provocation great
His Sons, and Daughters, prov'd.
Therefore he said, I'll mark their End,
From them I'll hide my Face;
For they are froward Children grown,
A very faithless Race.
Since they, with that which is not God,
Have mov'd my Jealousy;
My Anger greatly have provok'd
With lying Vanity;
Their Rage I'll with a People move,
Who're only so in Name;
And with a foolish Nation I
Their Anger will enflame.
A Fire is kindled in my Wrath,
Which down to Hell shall burn;
The Earth's Encrease, and Mountains Base,
Shall into Ashes turn.
I'll Loads of Mischief on them heap;
My pointed Arrows spend.
Hunger to burn, and Heat devour,
With bitter Deaths I'll send:
I'll order Teeth of savage Beasts
Their vital Blood to spill;
The crawling Serpent of the Dust
Shall them with Poison kill.
The Sword without, Terror within,
Shall seize young Men, and Maids,
And slay them, with the sucking Child,
And Men of hoary Heads.
I said, that I would scatter them,
In ev'ry distant Coast;
Make their Remembrance among Men
To be entirely lost.
But that I fear'd the Pride of Foes,
Lest insolently they
Behave; and our high Hand, not God,
Hath done all this should say.
For they're a Nation void of Sense,
Nor Wisdom's Rules attend.
Oh! were they wise, this understood,
And thought on their last End.
How should One chace a Thousand? Two
Ten Thousand put to Flight?
Except their Rock had sold them Slaves,
The Lord restrain'd their Might?
For their weak Rock can ne'er with our
Almighty Rock compare;
Our Enemies themselves must own,
If they the Judges were.
Their Vine's of Sodom's vicious Stock,
And from Gomorrah's Fields;
Which brings forth nought but Grapes of Gall,
And bitter Clusters yields.
There Wine's the Dragon's Poison, fell
Venom of Asps congeal'd.
Is not this kept in Store with me;
And with my Treasures seal'd.
Vengeance, and Recompence, are mine,
They'll fall the Time decreed;
Their woful Day is near at Hand,
Their Mis'ry comes with Speed.
Yet God his People's Cause will plead,
For's Servant Sake repent;
When none shut up, and left, he sees,
And all their Strength is spent.
Then will he say, "Where are your Gods,
"You look'd to for Defence?
Where's now your Rock of Strength, in whom
"Ye plac'd your Confidence?
"Which on fat Sacrifices fed,
"And crown'd with Wine the Board?
"Now let them rise, Protection give,
"And needed Help afford.
Know ye, that I, ev'n I am he,
"No God with me I have;
"I kill, revive, I wound, and heal,
"None from my Hands can save.
"For I to Heav'n, my Throne above,
"Lift up my Hand on high;
"And solemnly I sware, as sure
"As ever live do I.
"If I shall whet my glit'ring Sword,
"And hold on Judgment lay;
"I'll render Veng'ance to my Foes,
"My Haters I'll repay.
"I'll make my Sword devour their Flesh,
"Mine Arrows drunk with Blood
"Of slain, and Captives; on their Chiefs
"Revenges I'll make good.
Ye Nations join his People's Joy;
For he will on their Foe
Revenge their Blood; but to his Land
And People, Mercy show.

div.head: The Song of DEBORAH. IUDGES V.
div.l: PRaise ye the Lord, who hath aveng'd
His Isr'el, on their haughty Foes;
When the brave People freely did
Their Lives, for Liberty, expose.
Hear, O ye Kings, Princes give Ear,
Whilst I to great Iehovah sing;
In sacred Numbers shout the Praise
Of Isr'el's God, th' almighty King.
When God from Mount Seir march'd in State,
And turn'd from Edom's losty Tow'rs,
Th'Earth shook, the Heav'ns in Thunders dropt,
The Clouds pour'd down their rapid Show'rs.
The Mountains flam'd, and melting flow'd,
Nor could Iehovah's Presence bear;
So Sinai unknown Terrors felt,
When Isr'el's God was present there.
In Shangar's Anath's valiant Son,
And famous Iael's former Days,
The Roads, by Trav'lers were untrod;
Who fearful, walk'd thro' secret Ways.
The Villages were broken up,
Their Lands uncultivate were lay'd;
Untill I Deborah was rais'd
And Mother in God's Isr'el made
New Gods their sickly Fancies chose,
Fierce Wars their Gates invaded then;
Was Shield, or Spear, in Isr'el's Tents
Seen among Forty Thousand Men?
My Heart is set on Isr'el's Chiefs,
Who offer'd of their own Accord,
Bravely to join, and head the Troops
In Battle: Blessed be the Lord.
Sing ye that on white Asses ride,
And now secure in Judgment sit.
Ye Trav'lers join the sacred Song,
Who safely go where ye think fit.
Ye that from th' Archer's Noise are freed,
Lurking at ev'ry wat'ring Place,
Iehovah's righteous Doings, now
May there rehearse, in Songs of Praise:
The truely gracious Actions he
To Isr'el's Villages hath shown;
That now the People of the Lord,
Safe to their Borders, may go down.
Wake Deb'rah, wake, excite thy Pow'rs,
His Fame, in sacred Hymns, to spread;
Rise, Barak, thou Abinoam's Son,
Thy captiv'd Foes, in Triumph, lead.
Thus Cannan's Nobles he reduc'd,
And put beneath his Remnant's Feet;
The Lord, to my Dominion, forc'd
Their mighty Captains to submit.
From Ephraim's Mount there came a Root,
Which with fierce Amalek engag'd.
Benjamin follow'd close, and join'd
His Forces, where the Battle rag'd.
From Machir's Stock, renown'd of old,
There come great Captains, famous Men;
And Zebulun sent such as knew
To weild the Sword, and use the Pen.
The noble Lords of Isachar
To Deborah their Forces led;
On Foot they march'd down to the Vale,
With gallant Barak at their Head.
But Reuben seperate remain'd,
Distant in Mind, much more than Parts:
The Conduct of which potent Tribe
Made great Impressions on our Hearts.
Did'st fear the losing of thy Sheep,
That thou among the Sheepfolds stay'd▪
Thee, has the Bleating of thy Flocks,
To base Neutrality betray'd?
Truly thy Conduct, Reuben, who
So wholly seperate remain'd;
And would not join so good a Cause,
Our Hearts has griev'd, thy Glory stain'd.
So beyond Iordan, Gilead stay'd:
And why did Dan in Ships abide?
While Ashur clung to his Sea Shore,
To hide in Creeks, or curb the Tide.
But Zebulun, and Naphtali,
Were ready, for the publick Good,
In the high Places of the Field,
To risk their Lives, and spend their Blood.
Confederate Kings of Canaan came,
With Iabin join'd, and for him fought,
In Tannach, by Megiddo's Stream;
But lost the Booty which they sought.
They fought from Heav'n, th' marshal'd Stars,
Each active in their stated Course,
Exert their Influence, and fought;
Against proud Sis'ra bent their Force.
The River Kishon swept them off;
That ancient River, here well known
A Brook, now to a River swol'n:
Thou, O my Soul, hast Strength trod down!
The fierce Rencounters of their Horse,
In hasty Flight, each other wound;
Their Speed is stop'd, they tumbling cast
Their mighty Riders to the Ground.
Curse Meroz, said God's Angel, Curse
All bitterly to her belong;
For they refus'd to help the Lord,
To aid his Arms against the strong.
Bless'd Iael, Kenite Heber's Wife,
Shall be above all Women-kind;
Her Fame, beyond her Sex, shall spread,
In ev'ry Tent, to ev'ry Wind.
He Water ask'd; to qu • nch his Thirst,
She gave him Milk, beyond his Wish:
She brought forth Butter to regale,
And serv'd him in a lordly Dish.
She took the Tent Nail in her Hand,
Her Right-hand seiz'd the Hammer fast;
Thro' Sis'ra's Temples drove the Spike,
And then cut off his Head at last.
He started, stagger'd, in a Maze,
He fell, down at her Feet lay spread;
Close at her Feet he bow'd, he fell,
There where he bow'd, he fell down dead.
His Mother thro' the Window look'd.
And cry'd, impatient for her Son,
Why does his Chariot stay so long?
Why do the Wheels so slowly run?
Her prudent Ladies answer'd her;
Yea, eager, she herself reply'd,
Have they not sped? and now a Prey,
To each a Maid or two, divide?
Is n't Sis'ra choosing, from the Spoils,
Rich Robes, which beauteous Colours deck,
Of Needle Work, on either Side,
Fit to adorn the Conqu'rour's Neck?
So, Lord, may all thine Enemies
In Ruin sink, and perish quite:
But those that love Thee, like the Sun
Be when he marcheth in his Might.

div.head: PROVERBS VIII. Abridg'd.
div.l: HARK, 'Tis the Voice of Wisdom cries,
In ev'ry publick Place;
To you, O Sons of Men, I call,
Come, taste my heav'nly Grace.
Silver, and Gold, and precious Stones,
And all thou can'st desire,
Bear no Proportion to the Gifts
My Votaries acquire.
Ere Earth, and Seas, and Heav'ns wide Arch,
Their Being did receive,
I, with the Lord, his chief Delight,
From everlasting live.
The habitable Earth, with Joy,
Appeared in my Sight:
I then beheld the Sons of Men,
And in them took Delight.
Come then, ye Chrildren, hear my Voice;
Be wise, and keep my Ways:
He's bless'd that hears, and at my Gates,
There daily watching, stays.
Who finds me, wins immortal Life,
And with the Lord finds Grace;
But he that sins, wrongs his own Soul;
Who hate me, Death embrace.

div.head: ISAIAH II.
div.l: THE Mountain of Iehovah's House
Shall, in the latter Days,
Above the Tops of Mounts, and Hills,
It's Head, in Glory, raise:
To it, as Rivers to the Sea,
Shall all the Nations flow.
Thither they flock, and cry, come ye,
Let's to the Lord's Mount go.
There, in the House of Iacob's God,
He'll teach us his pure Ways;
And in his sacred Paths we'll walk,
All our remaining Days:
For out of Zion shall go forth
A Law, that's full of Grace;
And from Ierus • lem, thro' the Earth,
The Word of God take Place.
Come then, O House of Isr'el, come,
Nor special Favour slight;
Submit to what the Lord reveals,
Walk in his saving Light.

div.head: ISAIAH II •
div.l: NAtions, that long in Darkn •••
Have now beheld a gloriou 〈7 letters〉 t
On them, who dwelt in Shades of Death,
The Light hath shined heav'nly bright.
For lo! the Virgin's Child is born,
To us the Son of God is giv'n;
Upon his Shoulders shall be lay'd
The Government of Earth, and Heav'n;
His Name is called Wonderfull,
The Counsellour, the mighty God,
Eternal Father, Prince of Peace:
Peace dearly purchas'd with his Blood.
His Government shall know no Bounds,
But far and wide, o'er all extend;
And happy Peace, the glorious Fruits
Of his just Reign, shall know no End.
O'er David's Kingdom, on his Throne,
To rule, and stablish it secure;
With Judgment clear, and Justice right,
His Reign forever shall endure.

div.head: ISAIAH XLV.
div.l: FROM ancient Times I have declar'd,
I am the Lord alone;
A righteous Lord, thy Saviour God,
Besides me there is none.
Then look to me, ye burden'd Souls,
From ev'ry distant Land;
And cordially receive, with Joy,
Salvation at my Hand.
I by my self have sworn, my Words
Both true, and righteous are;
That ev'ry Knee to me shall bow,
And ev'ry Tongue shall sware.
Sure Men shall say, we, in the Lord,
Have Strength and Righteousness;
And to him come; but all his Foes
Shall endless Shame oppress.
In Thee, Iehovah, Isr'el's Seed
Shall all be justify'd;
In Thee, shall triumph, while on Earth,
In Heav'n be glorify'd.

div.head: ISAIAH LIII.
div.l: LORD, who hath our Report believ'd?
Who thy Messiah hath receiv'd?
In him no Form, or Beauty's found.
Despis'd, disown'd, to Sorrows born;
From him we turn'd our Face in Scorn.
Truly, our Pains, and Griefs, he bore;
When God, we thought, had smit him sore.
But for our Sins he Wounds endur'd,
Our Trespasses his Griefs procur'd;
His Chastisement our Peace has bought,
His grievous Stripes our Healing wrought.
Like Sheep, we all have gone astray,
We turn'd, each one, to his own Way;
And God, upon his guiltless Head,
Hath all our Crimes, in Mercy, laid.
Silent he bore the heavy Load,
Nor once complained of his God;
No Lamb, when to the Slaughter come,
Nor Sheep, at shearing, are so dumb.
Snatch'd from Distress, from Judgment freed,
Who shall declare his Rise, or Seed;
Yet was his Life cut off betimes,
He suffer'd for my People's Crimes.
With Sinners, to the Grave, consign'd,
And with the Rich, in Death, he's join'd;
Because no Violence he had done,
Nor in his Mouth Deceit was known.
Him God it pleas'd to bruise and grieve;
When's Soul a Sin-Off'ring he'll give;
He'll see his Seed, prolong his Days,
And prosper in God's Works of Grace.
With joyful Satisfaction, he
The Travel of his Soul shall see;
And by his Knowledge justify
Many, for whom he'll bleed, and die,
I'll therefore with the strong, and great,
Him high, in lasting Honour, set;
Because he shed his precious Blood,
And interceeds for Sinner's Good.

div.head: ISAIAH LV.
div.l: HO! ev'ry one that thirsteth, come,
Where living Waters flow;
Come, buy, eat, drink, my Wine, and Milk,
Tho' ye no Worth can show.
Why do ye spend your Cost, and Pains,
On empty earthly Toys?
Hear me, and eat the Good; delight
Your Souls with heav'nly Joys.
Encline your Ear, and come to Me,
Hear, and your Souls shall live;
I'll, the sure Mercies of my Son,
By endless Cov'nant, give.
Him, Witness to my Flock, I've giv'n,
And set him on a Throne.
The Gentile Nations thou shalt call,
And they to Thee shall run:
Because thy God, the holy One,
Hath glorified Thee.
Seek ye the Lord, in finding Time;
And while he's near, call ye.
Let Wicked Men forsake their Ways,
And turn unto the Lord;
Our God▪ in his great M • rcy, will,
With 〈◊〉 , them reward.

div.head: LUKE I: The Song of MARY.
div.l: MY Soul, to magnify the Lord,
Unites her Pow'rs, and Voice.
In God, my Saviour, whom I trust,
My Spirit shall rejoice.
For to his humble Hand-Maid, he
Hath graciously express'd
Himself: and lo, all Ages shall
From hence forth call me bless'd.
The Great, for me, great Things hath done,
And holy is his Name.
To them that fear him, Mercy flows,
From Race to Race, the same.
Almighty Strength He clearly shew'd,
By what his Arm hath wrought;
The Proud he scatter'd, and their vain
Designs to nothing brought.
He drew the Mighty from their Seats;
And raised up the Low.
With good the Hungry fill'd; the Rich
In Want were forc'd to go:
His Servant Isr'el help'd, as he,
In Mercy, had decreed;
And to our Fathers Promise made,
To Abr'am, and his Seed.

div.head: LUKE I. The Song of ZACHARIAS.
div.l: BLess'd be the Lord, ev'n Isr'el's God,
Praise be our constant Theme;
Who came to visit his poor Flock,
And them with Price redeem.
He our Salvation's Horn hath rais'd,
His Servant David's Heir:
As, by his holy Prophets Mouth,
He did from first declare.
That we should, from our Enemies,
Compleat Salvation gain;
And from the Hand of all us hate
Deliverance obtain.
The Mercy promis'd to perform,
And's holy Cov'nant mind;
The Oath, by which, Himself, he did▪
To Father Abr'am, bind.
That us, from Foes Hands freed, he would,
Fearless, to serve him, give;
In Holiness, and Righteousness,
Before him, whilst we live.
Thou Child, the Prophet of the Lord,
Shalt go before his Face,
The Herald of the Highest styl'd,
Sent to prepare his Ways.
By Pardon of his People's Sins,
To make Salvation known.
The rising Sun, thro' boundless Grace,
From high hath on us shone:
T' enlighten those in Darkness fit,
And in Death's Shade abide;
The Way to Peace, and Happiness,
Our wand'ring Feet to guide.

div.head: LUKE II. The ANGEL's Message, and Song.
div.l: WHilst Shepherds, in the open Field,
Watch'd o'er their Flocks, by Night;
God's Angel shone in Glory round,
And all their Minds affright:
But the kind Angel to them said,
Let Nought disturb your Mind;
Good News I bring you, which shall be▪
〈…〉 to all Mankind.
For unto you, in David's Town,
(As sacred Rolls record,)
This very Day a Saviour's born,
The promis'd CHRIST, the LORD.
And this shall be your certain Sign;
You'll find (the Seraph said,)
The Babe enwrap'd in swadling Cloths,
And in a Manger laid.
Then strait, there with the Angel join'd,
A num'rous shining Throng
Of heav'nly Spirits, praising God;
And thus unite their Song.
Glory to God, who dwells on high,
By Angels round his Throne;
Bless'd Peace hath visited the Earth,
Good Will to Man is shown.

div.head: LUKE II. The Song of SIMEON.
div.l: NOW Lord, as thou hast said, dismiss,
In Peace, thy Servant, to his Rest▪
Because my longing Eyes, with Sight
Of thy Salvation, have been blest.
Which thou hast wondrously prepar'd,
Open, before all People's Face;
A Light to Gentiles, shining clear,
And Glory to thine Isr'el's Race.

div.head: REVELATION I. The Song of JOHN the Divine.
div.l: NOW unto him, whose Love was shown
To us, in dying Strains;
Who, by his own most precious Blood,
Hath wash'd away our Stains;
And made us Kings, and Priests, to God,
His Father, we adore,
Be Glory, and Dominion, now,
And henceforth evermore.

div.head: REV. IV. The Song of the FOUR LIVING CREATURES.
div.l: O Holy, holy, holy Lord,
Almighty God's thy Name;
Who was, and is, and art to come,
Eternally the same.

div.head: REV. IV. The Song of the ELDERS.
div.l: THou, Lord, the Glory, Honour, Pow'r,
Art worthy to receive;
For thou mad'st all, thy sov'reign Will
To all does Being give.

div.head: REV. V. The Song of the CHURCH.
div.l: THOU worthy art to take the Book,
And open ev'ry Seal;
For thou wast slain, and, by thy Blood,
Redeem'd us from all Ill,
To God; from ev'ry Nation, Tongue,
And Tribe of humane Birth;
And made us Kings, and Priests, to God,
And we shall reign on Earth.

div.head: REV. V. The Song of the ANGELS, and CHURCH.
div.l: THE Lamb is worthy that was slain;
Riches, and Pow'r, to him belong,
Wisdom, and Strength, and Honour high,
Glory, and Praise, from ev'ry Tongue.

div.head: REV. V. The Song of all the Creatures.
div.l: LET Heaven, and Earth, unite, to pay
All Blessing, Honour, Glory, Pow'r,
To him that sitteth on the Throne,
And to the Lamb, forevermore.

div.head: Long Meetre.
div.l: TO Father, Son, and Holy Ghost,
Be Glory, as in Ages past
From the Beginning was, is now,
And shall thro' all Duration last.

div.head: Common Meetre.
div.l: TO Father, Son, and Holy Ghost,
The ever blessed One,
Be Glory, as it was, is now,
And ever shall be done.

div.head: Short Meetre.
div.l: TO God the Father, Son
And Spirit, we adore,
Be Glory, as it was, is now,
And shall be evermore.

div.head: As Psalm 50th. 2d. Meetre.
div.l: TO Father, Son, and Holy Ghost,
The God, whom all the heav'nly Host▪
And humble Saints on Earth, adore,
Be Glory, as in Ages past,
Is now, and shall forever last,
When Time itself shall be no more.

div.head: As Psalm 148th.
div.l: TO God the Father, Son,
And Spirit, God of Love,
Be Glory here below,
And in the Heav'ns above,
As heretofore
It was, is now,
And shall be so,
Forevermore.

div.head: As Psalm 45th. 2d Meetre, and 149th.
div.l: TO Father most high,
And Son of his Love,
With Spirit Divine,
The God we adore,
All Glory be given,
As't ever did prove,
Is now, and shall be so,
When Time is no more.

div.head: ERRATA. The Author's Distance from the Press has admitted the following Errata.

row.cell: 2d Meet. f. they are, r. thou art
f. Whom we, r. Who Wo • art.

div.p: In various Places read Desart, and Desarts: Many Errors in Pointing have slip'd the Press, which an intelligent, Reader will easily correct.

div.p:

Observe▪ each Line, and Space, is a distinct Key. B. is Mi's natural Place; which prod •••• two natural Keys, one ending in C. which is sharp, the other in A. which is flatt • but to suit the • arious Tunes to the sire Lines in Treble, and Bass, the Tune ends in some other Key, and Mi. is then accommodated to its natural Place by Flatt • (♭) and Sharps (♯) set at the Beginning of the Tune▪ which run thro' the whole Tune, unless where a contrary Flatt or Sharp is placed.

2. Find the Mi. Observe, the last Note of the Tune is the Key. A greater Third (two whole Notes) above the Key▪ is a sharp Key: a lesser Third (one Note and half.) above the Key is a flatt Key. In all sharp Keys, the half Note below is Mi. In all stall Keys, the whole Note above the Key is Mi. or thus.

3. Name your Notes right. All Notes above Mi ascending are fa. sol. la. All below Mi descending are la. sol. fa. Every Eighth is the same. From Mi to fa, and la to fa, are half Notes. A (♯) raises a Note half a Note higher; a (♭) sinks it half a Note lower.

4. Keep Time. Common Time is thus marked, 𝇍, Triple Time thus 3, or slower 3/2. The Proportion of Time is, thus.
𝆹 Semibreve
톹텥 톹텥 Minim
톺텥 톺텥 톺텥 톺텥 Crotchet
톼텮 톼텮 톼텮 톼텮 톼텮 톼텮 톼텮 톼텮 Quaver
On • Semibreve is 1 Beats of a Pendulum.
A Minim is 2 Beats of a Pendulum.
A Crotchet is 1 Beats of a Pendulum.
A Quaver is 1/2 Beats of a Pendulum.
A Prick on the right Side of a Note make it half as long again, as 𝆹· is 𝆹톹텥 or 톹텥톹텥톹텥. so 톹텥· is 톹텥톺텥 or 톺텥톺텥톺텥 &c.

5. Observe your Marks. as 𝄞 sol re ut. 𝄡. Medius. 𝄢. Bass Cliff. The Medius is usually non pricked on the 𝄞 sol re ut Cliff.

6. Make yourself Master of this plain Song first. 〈♫〉 .
